I like this toy for its flexible rubber surface, which won't damage my dog's teeth if he chews too hard -- a risk with hard plastic toys marketed for hard chewers. I recommend purchasing through amazon for the discounted price. This item sells for full price in pet stores.

My dog tore this thing up in about a half hour unfortunately. We also have the Tire by the same company and that thing is still great! I would only recommend the "Jack" maybe for puppies (you can hide treats in it!) but certainly not any dog that has a history of making short work of cheap toys.

It is a little hard to put food or treats in - seems like anything you get in would either fall out or be hard to get out.  Might be ok as just a dog toy but my dog is 50-50 about playing with it - sometimes he will play with it for a couple of minutes but there are a lot of toys he likes a lot better.

This toy was not spongy like other Orka toys. I have an aggressive+++ chewer. The soft sponginess of the other toys meant that it gave so the teeth didn't penetrate. This was hard. When teeth meet hard toy toy loses and so do you. 15 min.NOT FOR AGGRESSIVE CHEWERS!!!
summary: I have praised other ORKA products

reviewText: This toy is great; our dog loves it.  It bounces all over in an unpredictable way, which is very fun to watch him chase all over the house, sliding around trying to catch it.  We've had better luck with they toy lasting than the other reviewer.  Our dog is a 70 lb. black lab/border collie mix.  He has not destroyed this or even made a dent in.  If you have a moderate to heavy chewing dog, you will be safe with this toy.
Excellent product. The dogs loves play whit it.

reviewerName: Jeri Zerr "formerly a Road Warrior of the Nth...
reviewText: Our German Shepherd Aiko absolutely LOVES the ORKA Jack!  When we (or he) tosses it, it bounces at odd angles, springs back into action, then rebounds and bounces again, giving him loads of action gaming! We've had to limit which rooms we play with the Orka because when I tossed the Jack it bounced at an odd angle, our boy chasing after it, almost sliding head first into a dangerous situation.  No bother, we just play in other rooms now!We supervise our boy when he has access to toys such as this.  So far this is amongst his favorites so he (usually) doesn't destroy his most prized possessions (our socks on the other hand...) I found the Orka Jack at our local veterinarian's office (well the store next door owned by the same veterinary team); I would CERTAINLY buy the Orka Jack and other Orka toys again!From the package:* Durable material great for power chewers* Hollow ends can be filled with treats if desired* Appealing "chewy" feel that dogs love! (ours do!) (and will gnaw on at great length)* It FLOATS and BOUNCES (yes yes yes Aiko loves playing with the Orka Jack his "kiddie pool"!)* Multiple textures add interest and massage gums when chewed* Fun, unpredictable bounce pattern makes play more exciting (we found this to be true!)The ONLY Con... Made in China.
summary: German Shepherd Approved - Aiko loves to chase after the jack as it bounces at odd angles off the wood floors!

reviewText: I have a four month old corgi and she refuses to play with this.  Its much bigger than I expected from the pictures.  We've tried putting peanut butter and other treats in this toy, but my puppy just barks at it.
This was supposed to be long lasting but my dogs made quick work of it.  Recommended by my vet, though I'll stick with kong products (I've had much more success with these).

My black lab mix loves this.  She is a major chewer and she is on her second one in almost 4 years.  It is great to play fetch with because you never really know where it's going to go, but make sure you have plenty of room. Her's has bounced into the neighbors yard a time or two.
summary: My black lab mix loves this!

reviewText: Got this as a replacement to one we've had a couple of years at least. Our dog is a real chewer and he likes this whether it has treats in it or not. He's pretty funny because if he gets tired of trying to get the treats out, he brings it over to us to get it out for him. So far it's as durable as the last one.
summary: Keeps dog occupied for some time...

reviewText: Well its much bigger than I anticipated, but that's okay. Its very sturdy and bounces in crazy patterns as I thought it would, but none of my dogs have so much as picked it up. I tried putting treats in it and that kept their attention briefly, but that was about it. I put a tug rope through it to try to peak their interest, but alas, no one care. My kids like it though haha

I own one pit bull and foster pit bulls, one at a time, for a local rescue group until they find their adoptive home.  These dogs have all been strong chewers.  I purchased this toy 6 months ago and it is one of my all-time favorite toys for the dogs (and one of the dogs favorites, too).  They love to chase it when I throw it, and they like to chew on it, too, for long periods of time.  Amazingly, it has survived very well, with only one bump having been chewed off to date.  What's more, it seems to be a toy that the dogs seek out.  I will buy this toy again.

This toy worked great until one day I forgot to put it out of Bouli's reach after we finished playing "catch" with it. Left with it on his own, he almost instantly tore up the hollow part. My advice for this toy would be not to leave it around for the dog to chew on. It's wonderful for chasing and water play, and as others have said, the crazy bounces are good for hours of fun. I'll buy it again but maybe in a larger size, and I'll be more careful.
This toy is really fun because it bounces all around so he plays with it and then tries to get the treats out.

I HIGHLY recommend this toy for medium to large dogs that are light to medium chewers. It is a ton of fun to play chase or fetch games with and most dogs really like the texture for chewing. But be warned. No matter what the package says, THIS IS NOT A TOY FOR STRONG CHEWERS!!!My Australian Cattle Dog LOVES the Orka Jack Chew, but she loves it a little too much and ends up destroying it. She will meticulously chew off one leg at a time. It is amazing to watch. But the product is borderline pricy for something that is destroyed (all 6 legs removed) in less than 2 weeks. Also, I worry about her health as many small pieces are swallowed no matter how close I watch her with the toy.This toy is AWESOME for chase or fetch. It bounces like crazy and floats. But the dog prefers to chew this toy, so the human ends up doing most of the running and fetching to keep the toy in one piece. We have lots of other toys that fit the "fetch" category which I don't have to watch like a hawlk. So now that two which we bought are dead and gone, we will not be repurchasing this toy.Toys that pass the ACD chew test:Kong (we still use the Red, have not had to upgrade to Black yet)LARGE sized Nylabone for Heavy chewersFresh moose antlerschuck it balls (but these are always getting lost)Pickle PocketToys we thought would work that failed:Kong Frisbee (died in 5 minutes of fetch)Kyjen Fire Hose (died in 5 minutes of fetch/chew)Orka Chew (died in 2 hours of chew, GREAT for fetch but dog prefers this toy for chew)West Paw Bumi (died in 5 minutes of chew, GREAT for fetch and tug)PawTrack (dogs just don't like chewing it, loved shredding the rope)Any Rope toy is shredded into a mess in minutes (OK for tug, but still gets messy)
summary: Fun for playing, NOT for power chewing!!

reviewText: Interesting toy but too easily shredded by 5 month old cocker spaniel puppy. Got a large size Orka Bone that lasted longer, but it also got chipped and shredded fairly fast. Avoidable.

2 pit bull mixes find this toy boring. They don't chase it, but it is exciting when it bounces erratically. We stuck a rope in it to make it more exciting. They don't want to chew on this, it really just sits on the floor untouched. Usually the more durable toys are less interesting to them so I'm not surprised.

I have 5 golden retrievers who love to mouthe, chew and gnaw on just about everything. This chew is one of the few things that has managed to maintain relatively intact since I bought it in April 09.  They've managed to bite half of it off, but they all still run around behind it, chase which ever dog has it, and one of my males even sleeps with it.  Excellent product. I'm buying a few more for their Christmas presents!

Best toy ever, I don't think it will ever break.  I bought the large Orka for my 7 month old black lab and she loves it.  It bounces off in every direction, so she's zig zagging to catch it.  She also likes shaking this toy so watch out for your shins.

My Australian Shepherd absolutely adored this toy from the moment I gave it to him. He loves to throw toys for himself and this was perfect as it bounced all over from even just dropping it. Be careful in confined spaces, he was knocking everything over!The jack arms were perfect for his mouth and he was having a blast playing with it. I come back an hour later and he has destroyed one of the arms. Pieces were coming off and I had to take it away so he wouldn't eat them. I'm so sad that it ruined it, it was a promising toy.I wouldn't really discourage most people from buying it though. Even though my dog is just an average chewer, he is very smart and breaks things so fast. If your dog is (pardon me..) a little unintelligent, they would probably chew away happily without ever figuring out how to break it. He used the hollow arm to his advantage and broke that ridge. Wonderful idea and design, just need to work on the material and maybe offer one that isn't open ended at all.

My dogs have the Orka bone shaped chew and it has held up well. Their Bulldogs, and are fairly strong chewers. I really liked the shape of Orka Jack Chew, and felt it would be fun for them. They love them, I ran a colorful nylon rope through the middle and made a loop & knot on each end. They carry them around the house swinging them, and can hold them steady on the floor while their chewing away. Also treats inserted into the spare holes have been entertaining. Their 6 inches across, kind of heavy, good for medium to large dogs. I would get more if these ever wear out.

My dog loves to chew but really didn't care for this toy.  It is definitely high quality though.  I decided to cut the egg shaped ends off with a sharp knife.  They are now used to make frozen peanut butter,tahini, and plain yogurt treats for the dog.  Can be filled with about 2 Tablespoons of anything.  I usually put one teaspoon of PB inside and it takes him about 5 minutes to lick out.
summary: My Dog Didn't Care For It, So I made Peanut Butter Treat Holders Out of It

reviewText: my english bulldog has had this jack for over 6 months. i fill it with peanut butter or stick treats in the holes and he plays with it for hours. he usually tears up everything, but he hasn't managed to do so yet, even with non-stop chewing. the blue okra stick with the pretty rope in it arrived today, but i guess it wasn't a strong as this jack because it only lasted an hour before  blue chunks were everywhere.......jan 2013 and the jack is still intact!! i highly recommend it for strong chewwers and to keep a bored dog busy.

I loved the ORKA tennis balls for my power chewing pittie, so I thought I would try this. It is worth it's weight in gold if you have a chewer like mine! Now my lab has decided that he likes it too, so another one is on it's way! The Petstages ORKA toys have been lifesaver's for me and the bright blue color is an added bonus. We have plenty of grass and they stand out like beacons!
summary: The Best Toys For A POWER CHEWER!!!

reviewText: Please ignore the negative reviews and just take this line of toys with a grain of salt - these toys are NOT designed for adult dogs, super-chewers, or whatever else people think they are and ignore how Amazon advertises them - these are toys specifically designed for TEETHING PUPPIES - they are made of soft rubbery stuff, with nobs to massage sore gums - the idea that any dog toy is supposed to "last" is just ridiculous - the point of a dog's toys is that they can be destroyed and save your shoes, and anything else of yours - from being chewed on.If you have a teething PUPPY - that's a normal chewer (NOT - i repeat, NOT a power chewer) these are the best toys your money can buy.
This is a high quality chew toy but my puppy doesn't seem very interested in it.  Maybe it doesn't make enough noise - the bells are kind of soft.
Our little silky terrier loves to fetch thisIt flies and so does she.....I love to buy all the pet stages toys and this was shipped very quickly

This toy makes my 3 month old French Bulldog very happy. He loves that he can carry it around and that it rattles instead of squeeks. He's had it for almost a month and has yet to do any damage to it.

My puppy is a chewer and seeing how he loves this thing the first time I took it out, I put it away after each play session.  I play fetch with him every day with it and he just loves those little balls.  So much so that one of them has been gutted with white cotton-looking stuffing spilling out.  I think it's the rattling that the balls make that just gets his attention.  It's different than any of the other toys I have.May need to get another one soon.
summary: Hours of fun, but don't leave it alone with the dog

reviewText: I just received this toy in the mail today, and within minutes of giving it to my yorkie puppy to play with, she had gutted two of the balls!!  I ended up cutting off all of the balls, and now she just plays with the ring.  If you're looking for a sturdy toy for your puppy, this isn't it!!

Bought it for then 3 month old German shepherd puppy......"puppy" is now 7 months old and 64 pounds and this is the ONLY  dog toy that is still intact.  He has pretty much destroyed every other toy we have purchased.  He loves to play tug w/this toy and sometimes just runs around w/it in his mouth shaking his head back and forth entertaining himself.  It truly is a great buy.

If this toy was more durable I'd give it five stars in an instant!My dogs loved it and there were plenty of places to grip and hold on to.I'd say it would be the perfect toy for smaller less destructive dogs.

Bought this to replace a smaller similar tug toy for my miniature pincher (5kg/11 pound). It would be too big for him to play by himself, but works well as a tug toy and has a lot of rope for him (and me) to hold. May not work well with larger dogs with more power, but perfect for my dog.  Nice on their teeth and my hands. Only unfortunate part is that because you don't know which colour you will get (it comes in either purple/green/pink or purple/pink) we got the purple/pink version for my male dog, not that he will care and it stays hidden most of the time, but i would have preferred the other colours. That said, there is nothing about the actual toy I can say bad . However, I am slightly biased as I have had other fleecy clean toys which my dog enjoys so I had no doubts that he would like this one.On a final note, I have a small inside dog who is not a destructive chewer and will not have access to the toy unsupervised. It may not stand up to a bigger, stronger dog who will always play with the toy.
First time buying and both dogs love to play with this.  So far it has stood the test of many tug of wars.

It looks vulnerable. But it isn't. Tug-a-war is my dog's favorite game and we play it everyday. This toy holds up well after a month's of daily use. You may think since it's fabric made the dog will tear it up pretty easily--in fact the braided part is very hard to chew through. I used to use rope toys and here are some pluses that the fleece toy has: The tassels don't get tangled like the ropes, and you never need to worry about grass/seeds/leaves/crumbs/mud clinging to it. easy to wash, gentle on your hand, and gentle on the dog's teeth too.

I like the idea in theory but in practice large dogs are going to rip it to shreds.. even my smaller 70lb boy ripped it up. I'd say dogs 50 lb's or smaller it might be a good toy. I accidently left it in the backyard with them and am now hoping they didn't eat a bunch of it.
summary: Nice for a few days.. Not a big dog toy

reviewText: After reading such glowing reviews as "best toy ever" I decided to give this a shot. My large dog needs sturdy toys, and this one does NOT fill the bill. About five minutes after removing this from the package to play tug with it, pieces started falling off. Not a good start. The toy is large but not durable, and not worth the money.
summary: Not a durable tug toy for large dogs

reviewText: I have a 2 year old lab. She does not chew household items, but LOVES to play and 'destroy' her toys - I pick up toy shreds daily. I can NOT buy stuffed animals or those without the stuffing b/c they are just too cheaply made - she likes them, but they don't last a day in our house. THIS toy has lasted. Yes, she is able to tear it apart eventually, but I'm talking 4-6 months before it is withered down to just pieces. Plus, it doesn't shred, which is a big plus for me! Good tug-o-war toy as well as a teeth cleaner. Good for throwing in the house (as it is soft) too. If you read A LOT of other dog toys - the mfg will tell you this or that toy is not a chew toy;  would like to know what those manufacturers expect a dog to do with a toy (i.e., KONG). I can't tell you how much I've spent on toys for my dog, but I can tell you this toy is definitely one I will buy again!!!
summary: One of THE longest lasting of all my dog's toys.

reviewText: I have two chewers.  They alternate between toy bones and these soft toys.  After a while they unravel and I find strands around the house, but for my dogs its part of the fun.

I gave this to two dogs who love to play tug with each other. They're not particularly rough, but they've managed to shred this into a dozen strips of fleece. They still love it (no matter how small the piece), but I can't imagine this toy would last long with more aggressive chewers.
summary: With two dogs, doesn't last long -- but they LOVE it

reviewText: There were 2 type's of reviews here, some people loved it, some hated it. I didn't know who to believe. I place it somewhere in the middle of those reviews. While i see what people are saying about it being junk, for the $5 i paid for it my puppy has been working on it for about a month now and while he has shredded a good portion of it up with his razor puppy teeth, i got my $5 out of it. I wouldn't leave it with my puppy alone because i believe he could swallow parts of it, but playing with him it isn't bad for $5.

This tug toy is one of those inventions that you buy and say, "Wait a minute.  Why didn't I think of that?!  Helloooo?!!"  It's pieces of fleece tied together.  Okay.  It's different colors of pieces of fleece tied together; however, since dogs don't see colors that well, I don't think they would - or could - care less about the different colors.This toy is much better than a rope toy because there are no little strings that the dog can pull off and swallow potentially creating a ball of string in her/his stomach that requires expensive and dangerous surgery.  Instead, the pieces of fleece are tied in knots to create a friendly tug toy!  Now, dogs that are adept chewers will chew off large pieces and untie some of the knots.  Quite alright!  Tie the pieces back onto the larger toy!  And, if they are too small to tie back on, throw them away!Now, back to my first statement.  If you have some old fleece hanging around, or if you went to the craft store scrap materials bin, you could probably make this toy yourself.  However, for around $6, it's worth it to just buy it!

My dogs don't really understand this toy... it doesn't have the rope threads to rip off or a squeaker.  I think they both just checked it for squeakers then never touched it again.  My dogs don't like to play tug of war and aren't really mouthy though.  If your dog is this would be better than a rope that has threads.

My pup (5-month-old, 8 pound) is crazy for those pig ears. It took him less than 30 mins to finish up 3/4 of the ear (The ears are quite big). I only give him 1 pig ear per week due to the weight control. Good treats for your beloved pal!!!
Simply put. Dogs like it like we like potato chips. Have to order enough to last a week. Arrived within a week.
My Akita loves these.  She's very picky on treats but she will eat these every time without exception.  Good deal!!
Like a wonderful holiday for a dog when these come out. Quality is great. Clearly the taste is great!  Price is great.
I've tried others but Jack says they don't hold a candle to these Smokehouse pig ears.  And that's why I buy them.  They're the best!

Well, she loves to chew, and I bought this product for its healthy production and made in the USA.  Unfortunately, she's a bit so-so about it.  Maybe it's because of the smoky flavor.  Will continue to experiment.

My 60 lb aggressive chewer pit likes this. got it at goodwill for a few bucks. She got the treat out right away and then spent 20 minutes consuming the treat. Treat made her sick all of next day, not  ever buying those again. I put pieces of frozen meat inside and she spends up to an hour licking, sucking, and pawing them out. shows no wear after several hours of intense chewing. if it lasts a few months ill keep buying more, so worth it!

I bought this at petco after speaking to an associate on a new toy for our boxer puppy who loves to chew. At 20$ this is an expensive toy but after talking to her and hearing how much her dogs love it and play with it, I thought why not.  When I took it out of the package it has a horrible chemical smell. My boxer immediately started growling and barking at it, she wouldn't get closer than a few feet and would run from the smell. When I started doing research on the toy I found that a lot of vets consider it to be a choking hazards due to the plastic can be easily chewed and come a choking hazards. Ours didn't get played with at all and is going to the trash. Another lesson on why I need to read reviews on products before buying.

My dogs love these. The don't rip them apart. When empty the toss them and roll them like a ball. Great entertainment value. They love all the flavors of the treats, so much so that I have to take them away to keep them from spending too much time with them and eating the whole thing in one day. I recommend getting the next size up than what is recommended. The small is too small for my 13lb poodle mix, she can take the treat out too easily. The medium can keep a 14, a 17 and a 23 lb dog happy for hours and hoursThe show no wear and tear and I've had them for months. Have the treats auto ship every month
I thought I had found the perfect treat for my orally-fixated lab. When I recieved it, I saw it was made in China. I don't trust it to give to my dog.

As with the large one, the big treats are very hard to get into the ball.  I have had to use a screwdriver to get them in and sometimes it just doesn't seem worth it.  At first I though this was a wonderful idea, until I tried to get the large treat in.  Really haven't used them in a month or so because it takes so long to get them set up.
my 7 month old lab puppy likes this toy, but not for very long.  he licks at it for a bit and then gets bored when he realizes he can't get the treat out.  it also smells a little weird!
summary: keeps him occupied, for a bit

reviewText: I bought the Everlasting Treat Ball (Large sized) for my 45 lb mixed breed dog, who is an aggressive chewer. This is the same dog that went through a red Kong in a day, and a Kong Extreme in a few months, and will liquefy any tennis ball in seconds. I heard great reviews on this and read about it in a book as well, and after MONTHS of debate decided to pick this up at my local pet store when it was on sale. I just gave it to her less than 20 minutes ago and she already has several chunks out of it.It did "challenge" her for a few minutes, as I put kibble and treats inside. She got the disk out in a few minutes and enjoyed that (chicken flavor) then went crazy getting at the food inside. So crazy, that she has taken several chunks out of the plastic already. And eaten them. Great. She did seem to have fun rolling it around getting the food out, but then went to chewing on the plastic.For a replacement, I got theEverlasting Fun Ball Largein large from the same company- and its been over a week so far and she loves that toy!!! Its basically the same thing as this instead it is actually a green ball with more room for treats inside, and made of more durable material. Also, unlike the treat ball, it does not have any ridges for my dog to bite into and rip pieces off. And, its a bit cheaper. I'm writing this after I've had that ball for at least 6 months, and she plays with it EVERY DAY and there isn't even a mark in the thing.So, all in all, skip this and go for the FUN BALL instead!!!

When I got my miniature Labradoodle puppy, the breeder recommended getting one of these.  I am so glad I did.  This will entertain your dog for hours.  The inserts are a little expensive but well worth the price for the amount of time your dog will enjoy this product.  So far she has not been able to damage the ball itself, after 8 months.  For me that means it should last about two years or more before I have to replace it.  For a puppy/dog toy that is "everlasting".  I love it and highly recommend it.  Just a note: my dog is small and the medium size ball seems perfect.
Not very everlasting for my Beagle who got the big treat out in 5 minutes and chewed it up to get the little treats out...
MY SMALL DOG WAS ABLE TO CHEW THE RUBBER UP QUITE EASILY.  DISAPPOINTED IN IT.  BUT... A FRIEND HIGHLY RECOMMENDED IT.  I'M STICKING WITH BULLY STICKS AND KONGS...

There wasn't anything "everlasting" about this treat ball.  My dog had the treat polished off in less than 30 minutes.  The ball itself is pretty tough, so I now put treats inside the slots were the everlasting treat was.  It works out much better and is far cheaper than replacing the treat itself.
summary: Tough ball, but remove the treat.

reviewText: my dog has no interest in this toy at all. i have the treats in it and all and she doesnt even roll it around. waste of money.

This toy billed to keep dogs entertained for hours lasted my dog 20 min.Be very careful with this toy. My boy ended up swallowing a big piece which made him sick and resulted in a very expensive trip to the vet. Fortunately it did not cause a blockage, but I'm not taking the risk.

The way this is shaped makes it easy for a dog to get a hold of and rip apart. The rubber is cheap and tears easily. Once your dog tears a piece off the over priced treat inserts won't stay in place making the whole system worthless. Buy kong brand, their rubber seems to last.
The perfect toy/treat for our dog!!  When he wants a treat, we tell him to go get his "ball", he brings it to us, puts it in our hand, gets a treat and keeps him busy and happy for awhile!!
summary: The perfect toy/treat for our dog

reviewText: I have a mixed breed herding puppy. She is a moderate chewer. I bought a medium and a large Everlasting Treat Ball as well as plenty of refills. When she gets in a chewy mood she'll work on one for an hour or so. She does not obsess over them and with 2 balls (4 treats) out at once I probably replace one or two treats a month. Her teeth have not made a mark in the ball. If your dog is single-mindedly attempting to destroy the ball then I'm sure it will be destroyed. I'd reccommend it for moderate chewers.

I bought this toy in medium for my Cockapoo puppy because he is a big chewer and had been destroying blankets and comforters during the night.  Thanks to this toy I haven't found anything else destroyed.  He gladly chews on it for hours and is challenged enough that he still hasn't been able to get out all of the treats I put inside and it's been several days.  Despite this he persists on and is happy to continually knaw.  I also haven't had any issues with him getting the everlasting treat off.  It is still 100% intact.  This toy does a great job of standing up to his chewing and shaking.  While many other toys (including a stuffed bunny) have been distroyed this one is still intact without the smallest sign of a bite mark.  He doesn't seem to tire of playing with it and is as happy to be left alone chewing on it as he is to playing fetch with it.Overall this is a great toy and easily one of his favorites along with hisKONG Classic Kong, Large Red.  He loves both of them equally and they have done a great job distracting him from his distructive behavior.
summary: Entertains my dog and distracts him from chewing on something valuable

reviewText: My dogs like gnawing on this.  It is a real pain, though to load the big treat discs into it.

Within the first day of giving this to my dog ( a large breed puppy), he chewed off several chunks of the ball on the side that holds the small treats and ate most of the "everlasting" big treat, but it kept him busy.  He chased it and chewed it, and even when I thought the treat was too gone for him to lick any more, he still was able to get more out of it.  While it's not as durable as it claims, it's durable enough and my dog does love it.  Also, it's dishwasher safe!
summary: Not quite "indestructible" but keeps dog busy

reviewText: I timed my dog with this treat. It took him half an hour to devour the treat. Which stinks. I won't be buying more everlasting treats. I was also a bit upset that it only came with one everlasting treat even though the description says it'll come with two. When I'm paying that much money for a toy I expect to get everything in the description. The only reason I'm giving this four stars is because the actual toy part (the blue thing) has become one of my dog's favorite toys. He has not destroyed it at all even though he does chew on it quite a bit. I stick other toys through the opening and he LOVES trying to get them out. Sticking food inside the ball isn't the best idea because it just falls through the other opening. Overall, I don't regret buying this, but if given the chance I probably wouldn't buy it again.

I don't think my puggle had it for 3 minutes without getting the treat out. This was frustrating but if you put other small treats in the middle it works great! It is very difficult to get to and occupies his mind. I wouldn't waste your money on the treats, if you have a treat obsessed dog. My dog has yet to destroy the ball but give it time....
summary: The treat ball is great for other treats, but the everlasting treat can be easily popped out

reviewText: We save this treat for when he has to go in the kennel(during the day) he loves it. We actually have to hide it from him because he wants it all the time. He's a pretty powerful chewer and using it the way we do, the cookie lasts a few days.
summary: Engages my Great Dane for hours!

reviewText: This toy was highly recommended by my trainer, so I thought I'd give it a try, desperate to find anything to keep my "little" guy (70+ lb Lab mix puppy) and my adult German Shepherd busy for more than a couple minutes.  The first time, the treats stayed in for about an hour but were devoured 5 minutes later.  I then tried the caps with the screw rod in the middle, my puppy had it disassembled and devoured in under 10 minutes (far less time than it took me to assemble).  Went back to the original caps and this time around they too only lasted about 10 minutes before they were completely devoured as well.  Soon after, my puppy had one side torn completely off and reduced to little blue plastic bits.  While both of my dogs really loved it while it lasted, for the price of the toy and the price of the refills (which sell out from my local store so quickly I have a hard time getting them), for my guys, it just wasn't worth it, but for less aggressive chewers, this would be great.

Excellent for my small-breed dog. Your dog may prefer specific flavors so try them all as they come in two chews to a pack, small size treat for small size ball/holder. My pup likes the chicken it came with, but does not care for the liver; I put a different flavor on each side. My dog loves to lick and chew this and it seems to not be affected. I think this is my dogs favorite chew toy and I highly recommend your dog try one of these. The chews seem to last a long time and not break apart, so far. I recommend all chewing devices be supervised during use.
The Everlasting Treat Ball paired with the Everlasting treat keeps my dog busy for hours.  I can also put several pieces of kibble or tiny treats in the middle for her to work at getting out.

I have a Newfoundland, a Golden Retriever, and a Westie.  Large, Medium, and small.  Each of them have their own toy and it keeps them occupied for HOURS.Okay ... yes, it can be a pain to force the treat into the ball.  And sometimes, they get the treats out quickly.  But when they stay in, it is a wonderful toy.I have taken toys before and placed wet dog food inside with some treats and froze them.  This works extremely well.  and since this toy is dishwasher safe, I just plop them all in the dishwasher with their food and water bowls and clean everything at once.I don't think you will be disappointed if you get this toy.
summary: The best dog treat I have found!

reviewText: I thought this was a wonderful idea. We went through FOUR  of these in increasingly larger sizes before I finally gave up. Our husky mix tore through the sides and ripped the "everlasting" treat out in about an hour. Thought it was our fault so we bought bigger ones for his strong jaws. Didn't do any good. Just ripped through those too. I like the idea, but it's not for us.Wouldn't buy again. Too expensive for the dog to chew up in hours.
summary: Did not last long in our house

reviewText: My younger dog has gotten bored lately, and chewing anything she can get ahold of in our shed.  I went out last night in an attempt to find something that will keep her occupied.  For $20 I bought this, took it home and had hope for about 7 minutes.  She got the treat out, and I messed up by pushing it in too hard, and getting it stuck in between the 2 sides.  (In theory, this was the most amount of time the toy went without having the treat popped out.)  After she licked at that for a while, I was able to push the treat out and get it back to the place that it belonged.  Pop. Pop. Pop.  She is now a pro treat grabber, who can get these everlasting discs out within 3 seconds flat. 2 if you don't count the time she sniffed at it.  Now I have a $20 ball to play fetch with.
If you have a dog that loves food or is strong willed then skip this toy my yellow lab had gotten that done with in 30 min

So my pup is smarter than the average... Pup. And she figured out this thing in less than an hour. I literally had just put it together and gave it to her new and when I got back home an hour later she already had one side out, and was working on the second already. To her credit she didn't need to shred the silicone mold to get the end treat out, but none the less, this shouldn't be bought as a stimulation toy.
This is a strong and lasting toy/treat.  Get a size appropriate item however.  this one works for my 9 & 12 lb dogs.  Way too small for a dog over 30lbs.  Get the larger size for bigger dogs.

My dogs love these balls, but after a few weeks, the ridge that holds in the treat started to fissure from them chewing on them, and now my dogs can get the treat out within a few minutes.  I prefer the medium ball (even for a small dog - my 6 lb maltese carries it all over the house with ease), the treats are impossible for them to get out, but keeps them very entertained.
summary: It was great for a while

reviewText: I ordered this with treat ball.  Dog loves it.  It is very close to impossible to insert in the ball. When used up, impossible to remove. The manufacturer has a video on their site showing how to do it.  Grandson  had to use a claw hammer to remove the part remaining in ball in order to replace it.  Outside the ball it lasts only minutes.  Inside, a day to a week.  I monitor use, and only use it for special rewards.
summary: This goes in their large Treat Ball.

reviewText: My dogs love toys with treats inside. Its good stimulation for them to have to work at it. After they eat the included treat you can refill with more of the same or do what I do and improvise. I stuff Meaty Bones in it and it takes them a while to get it all out. It is a good toy for filling with treats and can be quite challenging for the dogs to get them out.

My 6 month old rottie pup bit out a fairly large hunk of the ball and swallowed it within the first 10 minutes of having this. Unacceptable. She still isn't at full strength on her "big girl" teeth and jaws. For the price, the size "Large", general description the name "Everlasting", I expected more than one 10 minute chewing session before the destruction and a dangerous intake of a piece of the actual ball into my puppy's body.
summary: Pup removed treat and bit out large hunk of ball in first use

reviewText: Our golden retriever is the worst combination of dog: massive chewer and smart. By smart, I mean rocket science smart. I thought we had come upon the perfect toy for him. He was licking and biting at the treat and it was great. He had something to do and it seemed the treat would last forever. That's when he figured out a better way to get the treat. He figured out if he could pull the rubber off the edge around the treat, he could get the whole treat out. He set out to do that so we were taking big rubber pieces out of his mouth. Still thinking the treat was pretty solid in there, we let him have it back. Soon he had the whole disk of the treat in his mouth! We added a treat to the other side a week later and he set out to dismantle that side. Our dog opens gates and figures things out very easily so this toy was no match for his genius, but evil, smarts or crazy chewing skills. He just happens to be able to figure out angles to achieve his goals so this toy was a fail for us. I think it's a great toy for most dogs and the treat should last a long, long time for hours of fun. If your dog isn't such an evil genius or a huge chewer of rubber, then it would be a great toy.
summary: Not for Super Chewer Smart Dogs

reviewText: indistructable to datewill bounce like a ball - but also off centrecan put a few treats in it to leave with the doga favorite of mine and the dogs - but they do love the fireplug moreFANTASTIC PRODUCT FOR LABS

I have had the medium one for a couple months. In that time my dog's adult teeth have come in. When she first got the treat ball, she would bark and whine at it in frustration because she couldn't figure out how to get the treat after she licked it flat. She has her adult teeth now. It takes her a while but she can get the treat mostly eaten now; she hasn't figured out how to pop the treat out yet. That's a good thing! I gave a large one of these to a Lab friend who had it for all of 10 minutes before popping both treats out. For now this is still a great treat for my dog, but I don't leave it out unsupervised because our other dog gets jealous even though he doesn't really care to chew on it (he has never been a big chewer). So, I don't know if she would chew through the plastic if I left it out all the time like I've seen in some of the reviews.
summary: great treat to occupy my dog

reviewText: Neat concept...but disappointing results.  Our dog figured this toy out very quickly.  I agree with the other poster, it is hard to load the treats, so I do not know how a dog can get them out so quickly.  The fun only lasted for at most 2 minutes.  She still plays with the blue part of the toy every now and then, just with no treats.

Yup, the title says it all.  My pup loves her new toy and will work on it for an hour or so then fall asleep with it.To avoid inserting a new treat disc from becoming a frustrating challenge, work one side of the treat into the groove and then push to "pop" in the other side.  There is also an interior cavity where you can hide additional treats or kibble for more play or if you decide not to buy additional discs.Even though the price point of this toy is a bit steep the item is very durable.  My pup, Lucy, is a chewer and will rip apart fire-hose toys in no time.  After a week of chewing and playing with the Everlasting Treat Ball it's still looking as good as new.  This makes it a winner in my book.

I purchased this to give my dog something to do while he is in his crate while we are away at work. Just to see if he liked it I gave it to him earlier today, he's chewed on it nonstop for hours. I actually took it away from him a few times because he seemed to get a crazied addiction to it and probably should have breaks.  He's never shown any sign of toy or food aggression before but boy he did not like when we took it away.I would say that after about 4hrs of a 6 month lab chewing on it, it probably has a few more days before we need more of the discs. There is not a single tooth mark on the blue rubber piece. Overall I think this is a really quality product that he has a blast playing with and hopefully will never get bored of and we can use for years to come. Most of all I enjoy the freedom of having something that holds his attention longer than 5 minutes, I like that he is now able to be out of his crate while we watch a movie or do chores and not worry about him wandering off and getting into stuff.

I have a very smart, often bored Australian Shepherd. She's about 40 pounds and I'd consider her a moderate chewer. She's not really destructive, but if she wants something bad enough, she makes it hers. We affectionately call this her "puppy crack dispenser". She brings it to us to fill up when she's finished the discs and she's PUSHY about it. To say she's addicted is putting it mildly. It keeps her attention for an hour or so at a time, which is a godsend. Right there, it makes this purchase worth it for us. As a matter of fact, we've just bought our second one. Which brings me to the bad...In no way is this an everlasting sort of toy, not in the ball part and not in the disc part. The first one we got her lasted for about 3 months of HARD use which really isn't bad considering the abuse it's gone through. We've replaced it now that little bits of blue plastic have started coming off and now that she can pry the discs out way too easily. Just as it started to get easier to put them in, due to use, it meant it took her WAY less time to get them out. The refills are just too expensive for three hours of entertainment when it would take her a couple of days to pry them free when the ball is new.Also, the slits in the middle to insert smaller treats open too wide to make it much of a challenge for my girl to empty it, so we skip that part.Overall, the fact we've replaced this toy when it started to wear speaks volumes. She loves it and we love anything that keeps her happy and distracted from her velcro-like tendency to stick to us when we're trying to cook or putter around the house.
summary: My Dog Loves It but It's Not Perfect

reviewText: Put in the everlasting treats into the treat ball and my dog Samson goes nuts for hours. rolling playing kicking and eating his treats.Pros:the ball is durable.Its fun to roll as it goes all over the place.My dog loves this toy/treat combo.It keeps him actively running around happy.Hes not able to pry them out so he cant eat it all at once.Cons:everlasting treat is full of starches and other not so good for your dog ingredients. (this is the recommended treat for the ball but you can put others inside instead)Overall i love this for a once a month treat. But if your overly worried about your dogs diet i would move onto a different treat such as Pet 'n Shape Chik 'n Rice Balls Dog Treats. which can also be put into the ball.

This product is a Godsend! I work from home and have a 1-year-old German Shepherd who constantly panders for attention. She's a very strong chewer and usually tears through anything I give her within one day, at most. The Everlasting Treat Ball has withstood the test of time! It usually takes her a week to get through one of the treats and she'll spend several hours working on it, which helps me get a lot of work done. She usually loses interest once she gets it down to a half-inch "teething ring" type shape, so I pop it out using a butter knife and give her a fresh one. I highly recommend this product, with no complaints!

Our Maltese puppy loves treat balls so I thought this would be a good gift for her. Within half an hour she managed to pry the disk from the ball and ate the treat. I liked the concept of the treat toy but it didn't work for us. Was afraid to give it to her again because she swallows greenies and treats  whole. Was afraid she would choke.

I waited until my dog was older to get this for his.  I was so excited because I thought it would last.  He is only a medium chewer and  it did not take him long to eat the treat, maybe an hr and a half.  That would have been fine.  The thing that i did not like was that the plastic can be easily eaten off.  My dog ripped apart the blue part and then later vomited the treats and plastic.  This is fine if your dog is a very light chewer but any stronger and I would be very careful.  I don't think it is worth the money.  I will stick with the himalayan bones
The treat centers only last about 15 minutes with my dogs.  I use the rubber housing to hold peanut butter now.
summary: The centers only lasted 15 minutes.  But I continue to use the rubber part with peanut butter.

reviewText: Our dogs love theses. We had to upgrade our smaller dog to the blue treat ball because it tougher than the small orange treat holder.

Yes the treats can be popped out and gobbled up, but with a little work I've almost taught my dogs not to pop them out. ONE correction and then the toy gets taken away till another time. That way it becomes a lot more enjoyable for them to leave the treats in. Win-win. Except if I leave the room for more than a few minutes, but we're working on that :D

This toy has saved my sanity and my furniture!  Instead of my puppy chewing the furniture, he chews on this toy instead.  My puppy, who usually tires of toys in a day, has had this one for over a month and it is still the first toy he goes to each morning and the last toy he plays with before going to bed at night.  It took him an entire week of daily, constant chewing to just get through one of these cookies and when he did, he was very excited and pleased with himself!  Once he finished that one cookie, he went on the attack the second one.  I also put treats inside the ball, under the cookies and my dog loves trying to get through one cookie just to get to the treats inside.  I have never seen a cookie as hard and sturdy as these are and my dog loves every flavor he has tried so far.  I highly recommend this toy!  It has kept my active, hyper puppy amused, occupied and happy, every day.  I can not say enough good things about this toy, which is good for puppies and older dogs alike.  The only problem I have found is trying to keep enough of the cookie refills stocked in my home.  I wouldn't dream of running out of the cookie refills  for this toy !

My dog loves theStarMark Day-Glo Everlasting Fun Ball, Medium, Greenthat you can stick treats into or just roll around and play fetch. I bought this one because I wanted him to chew on treats longer. He'll take his time with a small bully stick, but those get expensive. These would be more expensive because he had the treat out in a few seconds and chewed it up in a few minutes. Bummer!
summary: treat out in <1 min. devoured in about 5 minutes

reviewText: Have an agressive Yorkie and he had the biscuit removed in less than 10 minutes.  States it doesn't tear, but it rips. Wasted money.

The idea was on the right track, but it look my thirty pound dog about a minute to dislodge the "everlasting" treat (which took him about ten minutes to consume). He's not a power chewer either. The pockets, inside the treat ball, made my financial loss a little more bearable - the ball itself will be useful.Pros: Won't have to buy the everlasting treats every so often.Cons: Will have to find something else to occupy him.

My dog is very high energy and pretty smart.  She loves this thing, but she always managed to pop out the inserts and eat them whole in under 5 minutes.  What I've started doing instead is inserting a small treat or two into the folds of the center.  This is much harder for her to get out and now this toy occupies her for hours.  It's a pretty durable material, but I'm sure it won't last forever.  I will happily buy another one, though, should it ever fall apart because she LOVES it so much now!  For instance, my dog usually flips out when we say the word "potty" (running laps around the house in excitement) because she knows she is going to get to go outside.  Well, when there is a treat in this thing, I practically have to pry it out of her mouth and hide it just so she will pay attention to the leash!  She almost carried it outside with her the first time I stuffed it with treats.  It's been a long time since I've seen my dog this happy with a toy and remain so content for so long.  Even when she shows interest in a toy initially, she usually gets bored with it rather quickly. Not this though!  I highly recommend this, even if you don't use it as intended!

I had a friend who bought this for her malamute and told me he loved it, but that he figured it out very quickly and would somehow get the treat out in a few minutes. My dog is a more gentle pointer mix, so I thought I would still give it a try. I ordered it and have been extremely happy with it ever since! My dog is more of a "licker" than trying to chew or bite the treats off, so it lasts him at least an hour, and he absolutely loves it! He gets so excited when I bring it out for him to play with! I also love that you can buy a lot of great flavors. We started with the beef but they were so stinky and my dogs breath smelled awful, so we tried the mint ones and my dog loved them just the same AND his breath smelled better! The only downside is that my dog seems to have a little big of GI upset after chewing these in that his stool is a little softer. He also has a pretty sensitive GI tract in general, and my friend never reported her malamute having any issues so it's probably more of a "my dog" issue than with the treats themselves. I'm definitely happy with how the treat ball stands up to my dog's chewing and playing with it, and the one that belongs to my friend's malamute is still intact after years of use. This truly is a great product!I have definitely heard though of some other dogs finding a way to chew this apart, so if you have a very powerful chewer and want to try it, I would make sure to supervise them the first few times you let them have it.
summary: Keeps my dog busy for hours!

reviewText: I ordered the small and my little maltese loves it!  She licks it, carries it around, bounces it, etc.  But the other dog tried to get the treat out and when she couldn't (and she's pretty tough)-- she lost interest.I'm leaving off a star because I think the price point is too high.  I've had just as much success entertaining and stimulating my dogs with other treat balls...like the Omega orange ball.  That one can be filled with a treat(food) of your choice and you're not bound to buy one specific filler.
summary: Great or a flop, depending on your dog

reviewText: Okay - the whole concept is a great idea. I just have a dog that seems to really be too smart for his own good. He has figured out all activity puzzles within the first 2-3 minutes. This "Everlasting" treat ball? 2 minutes the treat was out of the ball and another 2 minutes and it's totally gone.
summary: A bit of a waste with my dog.

reviewText: Well- my mastiff is able to get the whole thing in his mouth and bite down- which pops the treat out immediately. So I thought- "great- another waste of money". So I did not bother to replace the treats anymore...but it turns out that he just likes to chew on it. And he does- alot!. This is a different kind of really tough and flexible material and it is still intact after several months. So- turns out it was a hit after all!!

Our dog just loves this thing. Goes nutz for it. The treat is really easy to get in and out if you use a screwdriver. Otherwise I've done some damage to my manicure! He will chew on this thing for two hours if we let him. Although he goes through them quicker than I'd like, especially if he has one for a while all at once, the treat gets more maleable from his slobber and he scraps it away easier. To avoid this, I only let him have it for 30 mins at a time usually, that way the treat lasts quite a bit longer.

I bought one of these, left my dogs with it, came back home a couple hours later and one or both of them has already eaten the entire thing.  That's far from everlasting.  It would have been a complete waste of money, but they do like the rubber toy (so much they fight over it) and I can still fill it with other treats, peanut butter, or cheese like I do with their Kong toys.  So, it is still useful and they seem to prefer it over the Kongs.
Order extra refills as you can put two lockers in this ball. Dog loves it and cannot decide which side to lick first.

we got this for our pitbull puppy, and he loves it! it lasted for a while, no damage to the toy, and he is heavy chewer. we havent bought any new everlasting treats, but we dog shove dog treats in the middle and it works great!
This is a great idea, and my dogs really loved the treat! However, our big Lab who is an agressive chewer pop those treats out in minutes. The smaller pup loved licking and chewing it for hours.
summary: Tough Ball but not for Agressive Chewers

reviewText: We have a 50lb lab mix that needs to stay occupied or else she's constantly whining and barking. We go through tons of raw hide and bull sticks, but really needed something that could occupy her time for longer. This toy is it! We had a beautiful 3 hours of peace and quiet while she went at the treat. Because of the domed shape, there's no way for her to bite the treat out, so it stays put! After two hours she gnawed the treat down to a flat level and within another hour she'd managed to wear down the middle of the treat (so it looked like a donut)...but it was still securely held in the toy. I'd imagine it'll last another hour or so...ultimately she'll get 4 hours of enjoyment (and so will we) out this one treat. I can only imagine what would happen if we put a treat on each end!
My dog loved the treat inside, but the treat would not stay in the holder! It came out 3 times within the first 5 minutes.

The Everlasting Treat Ball is a great concept but poorly executed. The Everlasting Treat end caps come off very easily with a minimum amount of slobber. My puppy would lick them (because I'm sure they taste great) and within 5 minutes, the caps were off of the ball. The soft rubber makes it very easy to get them out this way. And they're a little too expensive to be made so poorly.My puppy loves to chew the ball to get any inner treats and food out, but there are better products on the market for that. Very disappointing product.
summary: Not a great product for its cost

reviewText: My 2 mini dachshunds LOVE these balls! (I can't emphasize this enough). The medium size is a bit bigger than a baseball, but the size isn't too big for a 12 lb dog. I don't particularly like the everlasting treats that come with because they get all slimy and they are a bit pricey. I generally just stuff small size milk bone biscuits inside and it keeps my dogs busy for 15-20 minutes. My dogs even like to play with the balls when there aren't any treats in them.

I love this toy for our dog.  I crate him at night when we go to bed and it is one that I don't mind giving him in his crate.  He will go get it from his crate and carry it wherever he is.  The refills are a little pricey but they usually take my dog about 2-3 weeks to go through.  Definitely worth it for anyone who has a dog that needs something to do.

My pit mix is a pretty devoted chewer.  I put one everlasting treat into each side of my large everlasting treat ball (and I should mention that this itself took about ten minutes - those things are NOT easy to get in).  My superchewer managed to finish both treats in a marathon 3 hour chew fest. She hurt her leg this week and is supposed to be resting, so it was nice to be able to keep her happily occupied for a while.The ball itself is something we inherited from a friend's dog and we've had it for a while. I don't think it's indestructible but it's one of those toys that she prefers to carry around and play with than to chew.  We sometimes put her kibbles inside the toy and she likes that too - I would say that it ranks fourth in her heart after scented jolly balls, waggle toys and new tennis balls.
summary: 1 ball, 2 treats = 3 hours for my pit

reviewText: A friend got the Everlasting Treat ball and 2 extra refills for my 17lb. dog.  My dog is not a destructive chewer but he had chunks of the blue part torn out within 20 min. It makes me mad when I think of how much it and the replacement treats cost and now it is trash.  That is why I am writing this review.

I bought this toy for  my 1 1/2 year old corgi, I bought the medium sized. The "everlasting treat" lasted about 2 minutes, but the blue portion is GREAT. I have been stuffing dried chicken chews in there or even a medium sized soft treat and it takes my dog at least an hour to get it all out. He love the toy and it keeps him busy for a long time. Skip buying the treat refills because they are too easy for the dog to pop out and gobble down, just buy a fairly large, hard treat and wedge it in there and then it becomes "everlasting". I bought mine at Pet Club and it was MUCH cheaper than amazon and petsmart. The medium size was I think $14.99 and the treat refills were something like $3.00. This is my favorite "interactive" toy so far and it keeps my dog busy the longest with the smallest amount of treats.

This toy came highly recommended to me by someone who also fosters pitbulls. This toy itself and this brand are about the only toys that a pitbull cannot destroy. The treat part is kinda yucky and only last about 2 minutes with an aggressive chewer that is able to pop it out and eat it right away. All-in-all still a great product for aggressive chewers. I just stick a large milk bone inside and that gives him something to work on. They also love to carry this around in their mouths and it bounces when they drop it.

I have an Australian Cattle Dog who, like most ACD's, tends to fixate on things . . . in the case of toys, this means destroying them as quickly and as thoroughly as possible (and then looking disconsolate because he has no toy). When I first put this down for him (with one of the everlast treats it came with), he wasn't particularly interested (though he did get anxious when the cats went near it, so clearly it was on his mind). But eventually he got into it. He worked the treat out pretty quickly and ate it with gusto. So I moved on to treats on the inside (a little jerky and some liver biscotti); it doesn't take him long to get them out, but he sure enjoys it. He's also getting a kick out of playing with it and chewing on it even now that it's empty. So far it's holding up, but I worry about those little flaps for treat entry; I can't imagine they're long for this world with his obsessive chewing. Frankly, I don't expect it to "everlast" -- but he's so happy in the meantime that I'm okay with it.

I thought it would be a good product for my rottie and bullmastiff, not so much, I was super mad that I spent so much money on something that didn't work. These are not cheap, and the refills are not cheap.Pros:Keeps them entertainedgives them a yummy treatCons:keeps them entertained for about 5 minutes until they separate the treat from the ball. On the large size it is super hard to get the treat in the ball for the first time, but after the first round of play it becomes easier- there's a reason- the seal isn't any good anymore, so it's super easy for the dog to hold down on one side of the ball, and lift out the treat.expensivesuper messy, slobber and treat goo get all over this thing and on your floorhard to wash and get dirt out of center folds

I have 2 dogs a 17 year old German shepherd husky. He loves this thing he will lick it all day long bite at it and stay totally zoned in for hours. He has never actually been able to get the treat out, but he will lick it until falls asleepMy other dog is a 90lb 3 year old German shepherd The first time I gave this to him it lasted a few weeks before he got the treats out. Then I bought another pack and he got it out within a few days. Now I get a pack and it's out within 20 minutes, so he figured out how to get the treats out, so I tried something new. Put the treat in upside down. It is beyond difficult to get in this way, but it will go. It made it even harder for my husky to eat more of it, but my 3 yr old got the first disc out in 10 minutes, but the second disc he just licked and lick and it took him a few weeks to get out, also he wasn't trying non stop. I guess its off and on with how long he can get them out. I wish it lasted longer in there, but I rated it 4 star because they both adore it like crazy. My 3 yr old shepherd is a super chewer and he hasn't made one hole in the blue ball. Also even with no treat in he loves it carrying it around the house and its the only toy he will play fetch with. It's a wonderful product even if the treats don't last all the time.

My dogs loved this treat ball. They have allergies and distracting them from sratching was easy with the treat ball using the corn wheat and soy free dental treats. ps - my dogs are on allergy serum shots but still get itchy and need distracted from scratching and seriously irritating their skin.. THANK YOU AMAZON for carrying this treat ball!!

We have a 75 lb doberman who is constantly on the move. We bought this toy and he loves it. He was able to pop the treat out within the first 15 minutes but we took it and crammed the whole thing in the middle of the toy. He now works at getting it out for an hour or more at a time. If he leaves the room where the toy is and comes back to find it, he immediately picks it up and starts playing with it again.He has only had it for 2 days but it seems to be holding up well.
summary: Keeps an active dog busy for almost an hour at a time

reviewText: My 6 month old Great Pyrenees mix is a relentless chewer. I am always looking for safe chew toys that he can't destroy in 10 minutes. The Everlasting Treat Ball is a great concept and he took right to it. Unfortunately, he had an extreme intestinal reaction to the treat. I checked the ingredients and I can see why that happened (his normal diet is grain-free kibble, rice, and veggies). The first three ingredients are wheat gluten, gelatin, and, and glycerin. These are not good choices if your dog has a sensitive digestive system.He also chewed off some of the soft plastic rim that holds the treat in place. He only had one session with the treat so I don't think it would have taken him long to render the holder unusable. I returned the Treat Ball and I continue to search for a safe, long-lasting chew toy.
summary: Pup loved it but the treat made him sick

reviewText: My adult dog was easily able to remove the included treat within a few minutes even when it was inserted backwards as another reviewer suggested, so I don't plan to buy refills. However, when I filled the toy with kibble, Regal and our Malinois foster puppy both had to work for a couple of hours to empty it. Neither of them damaged the toy so it seems to be pretty safe for them. However, as with any toy, I will continue to monitor them frequently to be sure they haven't managed to chew off a piece that could be ingested. The puppy still has most of her baby teeth so I don't know how the toy will fare with her in a couple of months when her mouth will resemble that of a crocodile, but Regal (a Bulldog/Siberian Husky mix) didn't faze the material and he is a dedicated chewer. I'd feel better about this toy if it were made in the United States rather than China but I believe it will be OK with restricted use. Regal gets all of his meals from food puzzles and this one adds some variety to the mix.I'm adding to this review because we have been using it for several months now. I raised the rating to 5 stars because it has been so useful and the dogs have not damaged it at all. The puppy mentioned above got all of her adult teeth but I was still able to put peanut butter in the toy to pacify her in the crate when she fussed. It kept her happy for a couple of hours and she was never able to bite off a piece of the material. We now have our own adult Malinois, Sizzle, and we use it with him as well. I put kibble in it and let him get his dinner that way when he needs to be crated. I bought another one so that I can give Regal and Sizzle their own. The new foster puppy is doing well without a peanut butter pacifier for now, but I won't hesitate to use it with her if necessary. I still suggest watching any dog carefully with a toy. They are all different, but so far our three serious chewers have safely enjoyed this toy for several months so I recommend it highly.
If you buy the treats, best order the ball or one of the other two apparatuses to use with the everlasting treats.

My siberian loves this and it's holding up like new, but the only problem is after she gets more of the center of the treat eaten, she can't really get to the rest so she gets bored.  Bonus tip; if you put the treat in with the done side inward, they last far longer
summary: great toy, but almost too hard for the dog to get the treats out

reviewText: GREAT idea!!!!  My dog loves it but be careful.  If your dog is smart he/she will find the way to remove it from its container.

If you have an aggressive chewer DO NOT BUY THIS.  My 18 month old pit mix was able to pop the end out within minutes.  I put it back in and gave it to him.  within 5 minutes the rug had bits of blue plastic as the holder is very easily chewed.Such a waste of money as that toy is a bit pricey.
summary: Serious waste of money for aggressive chewers

reviewText: This is one of Mama's favorite toys. Sometimes I put small training treats and some larger treats inside. I don't bother to buy the refill discs. They are smelly, messy, and slimy. Plus, once they pop out if you aren't watching, they will be devoured in seconds!She has been unable to destroy it and has had it for at least 4 months.She can squish it in half with her chewing, but she has been unable to "tear" pieces off of it. She will play with it filled or not filled and she seeks it out when it is put away.Easy to fill by lifting a flap with one finger and stuffing (or dumping) treats inside.It's pretty heavy for a toy, but I've seen our yorkie pick it up and run off with it. (He prefers the Large Bento Ball).Large sizes are expensive at Pet Stores. If you don't need this toy right away, save the $$ and purchase on Amazon.2/21/12: Ball still going strong. Purchased the small sized for the yorkie, but it is way to small for Mama. I try not to let her have that one at all due to a potential choking hazard.7/1/13: We still have this large item and it is still looking good!
summary: Large Everlasting Treat Ball + 1yo English Mastiff = Fun!

reviewText: I gave the ball with the treat stuck inside to my dog yesterday. He would not go anywhere near it. He sniffed the toy and treat and then walked away and it hasn't been touched since. I think what's turning him off is the smell of the plastic ball itself. It has a VERY strong fake-vanilla scent to it which is unpleasant to humans but must be overwhelmingly gross to a dog. By the way, my dog is not at all picky. He will play with anything and eat anything so this is a real first!Also, I looked at the ingredients for the treat and it's all absolute junk. The first ingredients are wheat and gluten.
summary: My dog will not touch this toy.

reviewText: I have a Boston Terrier puppy.  He is unable to remove the treats from this ball but still works at it.  Once I removed the treat he continued to use the ball as chew toy, and even includes it in his  fetch/retrieving game we play. The ball shows little wear and yet it is chewable .  A safe toy with resiliency.

This treat toy would get 5 stars if it weren't for 2 very important things: 1) the small treat ball is almost impossible to get treats into, as the opening is so tiny; 2) my dog had the disc treat out and wolfed down in less than a minute. Now I also have this treat ball in the large size for my German Shepherd and have not had the same problem with the disc treat coming out so maybe it's a function of the size, I don't know.

I have a toy poodle who is very toy motivated (and heavy into chewing as a puppy to boot), so my husband bought this for her thinking it would keep her occupied, at least for a good 20 minutes. Unfortunately, she had the treat portion out of the rubber holder in less than 5 minutes and our other dog (who, incedentally is food motivated) was eating it, and she was soon looking for something else to chew on as a puppy. The rubber "holder" makes a great throw toy, and is a good food pacer in the bowl of the other dog. It's also good to put a greenie through so they don't eat them too quickly. It is not an everlasting treat at all.
summary: Not suggested for heavy chewers or super smart dogs

reviewText: From everything I've read, you need to get the right size or your dog can pop out the treat.  We have a 16 lb pom/boston mix, she can't get the treat out of the medium.  I can see all the teeth marks in the everlasting treat, she is really working it.  I fill the other side with some of her daily kibble and she'll roll it around and get her kibble out.  I've put in other treats and she'll go after them too.  The flaps are rather thick, which makes it hard for the treats to come out.  Good for keeping the interest, but not so good for younger dogs that lose interest quickly.  She would have ignored this a month or two ago, at 8 months she can play with it longer.  I put in easy things to get out now, I'll make it harder in a week or two.  This treat, and the inserts, are on the expensive side, but it seems durable enough and she likes it.

I was very disappointed when my dog had the everlasting treat out within 5 minutes.  And when I put it back in and let it dry, he had already figured it out and popped it out in seconds.I think this is because it was too small for him.  It says for dogs "under 40 lbs", and my dog is a little shy of that mark.  The large looked really big and the product says that medium is good for under 40lbs... Apparently not though.  Since he could get his mouth around the edge of the toy, he could pop out the everlasting treat.Not sure it's a bad product, just maybe the wrong size.  But now I'm too scared of wasting $20 on the large in case that's a dud too.
summary: Medium is too small for my 37 pound dog!

reviewText: My dog loved the treats themselves, but wouldn't touch the rubber ball part because of the awful chemical smell it puts out! I finally had to throw the thing away because the smell was making me sick as well.. expensive mistake!

I can honestly say that I am not sure how i feel about this product yet. I have two Corgis and one loves it the other not so much. BUT ... i give it to my dogs only when i put them in the crate. My corgi that loves it is a boredom chewer so it makes sense that she would enjoy it, especially since it has "bonus treats" in the bottom. My other one just lies in the crate looking angry, as if to say " you think that treat is going to keep me happy while your gone?"I give it three stars because it is fair.***UPDATE***The company must have changed the formula or something because it made both my dogs sick (both ends).

I foster pups as well as own my own 25# dog.  This toy keeps the dogs busy for hours!!  Whent he insert treat runs out (which does last a long time) I can insert other treats or peanut butter to keep the fun going.  Easy to clean.  Very sturdy!

I have a 9 y/o English Bulldog that is very food motivated. In fact, the only time he seems to be happy is if he's chewing on/ingesting something tasty. He goes through 9-inch compressed rawhides in a day and at $4-$6 a pop that gets pricey. He's got kongs and rollable treat balls but as soon as the food is gone he loses interest (naturally) and if he can't get the treats out easily enough, he gets bored and gives up.The Everlasting Treat Ball, however, is an entirely new ballgame! We had a rough start with it at first. He had the chicken ones that came with the ball and they really upset his stomach. If anyone knows about Bulldogs and their GI "issues" then you know that when their stomachs are upset, the entire house is miserable, if you catch my drift! (pun intended).Another issue we had the first time around was that he was able to get the second treat out within a few minutes (but not the first one it came with). That led me to believe that we weren't putting it in correctly, but no matter what we did, the end result was the same. So we gave up.On a whim I bought him some liver-flavored refills the other day and it's been almost 3 days and he's STILL working on the first one! It's a godsend! He'll leave it alone and come back to it a few hours later then spend another good hour or so with it. The best part about it (for us at least) is that there isn't any belly upset this time around! I paid around $8 for a refill of 2 and the first one alone has already lasted longer than a $5 rawhide...AND we don't have to dig slimy pieces out of his throat after he tries to swallows them. A win-win as far as I'm concerned.

I have two dogs that both like this toy. I'd rate it a 3 for one and a 5 for the other, so I've given it a 4 overall.  For one of my dogs, it's quite the challenge to get treats out of the center and he'll spend hours licking the outside "caps" if I put them on. And, even when he's done with the caps, he'll still lick the ball part getting every last scent of food off of it. For him, it is the perfct toy that amuses him for hours. For my other dog, she can literally pop the caps off and eat them in minutes. Inside treats take her a few more minutes to pop out. She's 15 lbs of pure chewing power with jaws of steel. Of the two of these balls that I own, one is starting to tear a bit in the center from her biting down to allow the treats to fall out.  Even though she can get the treats out and eat them quickly, I'm still rating it a 3 because she likes to play with the ball even when it's empty. Because it has flat sides, she can bounce it and it will roll, but usually stops before it goes under couches etc that will cause me to have to climb under the furniture to retrieve the toy for her. (That's always a plus!)The treats that the manufacturer sells to accompany this toy are rather pricey, so I will often substitute my own, more cost-efficient treats or dog-safe veggies/fruits. In short, I'd recommend this, but it's not a miracle toy that will stimulate every dog and dogs that do chew it a lot should be supervised for safety.

I have 3 Australian Shepherds. This is a great treat for two of them and it lasts a whole heck of a lot longer than any dental treat or the Kongs. My other is smart as a whip and got the treat out in less than 5 minutes. Needless to say, I'm not giving her the treat again because its just a waste of my money. As for the flavors, my guys like the chicken, but that is all we've tried. I didn't realize that these are now available at my Petsmart store, but they don't give you two treats with the purchase of the ball. They toy holder if you will lasts- I haven't had a dog even try to destroy it.  The medium size is perfect for Aussies and Border Collies.

This bal container is good for putting other treats inside it but the ball refills are expensive and they make my dog sick.  They also do not last for very long.  Putting the treat inside it is REALLY DIFFICULT...VERY HARD...TAKES A LONG TIME WITH LOTS OF STREENGTH...and then once the dog has chewed enough to get it out she can eat the whole thing right away and then the next day has diarrhea all day.
summary: not a good idea and not everlasting

reviewText: I originally ordered a package of everlasting treats to see if my puppy would like them. She ate the first one in one sitting, so I had my doubts if I'd buy many more seeing as they are expensive for an hour of chewing. The second one lasted her a couple of days, so I did purchase another pack. The next ones lasted her about 3 days each, so next I purchased the treat ball. She likes to play with it, but can't gobble up the treats. I've got 2 treats in the ball now, she's had it for several days, and everything is intact. She likes to play with it, it seems tough enough to withstand her chewing (4-1/2 mo. old, 45#, husky/g.shepherd). This is a toy we like with treats she enjoys. I wish the treats were made of something more nutritious, but I'm okay with her having them especially since she doesn't eat them in one sitting anymore. My puppy, Akiak, gives this product two paws up!
summary: A toy my puppy can't destroy!

reviewText: I had originally bought the Everlasting Medium Bento Ball for my lab mix (puppy at the time) and she absolutely LOVED it, so when I saw this one I just had to buy it for her.  I've had this toy for about a year and a half now and she doesn't even touch it. I'm not sure what the big difference is to her but she just doesn't like this one.  Hopefully everyone else's dog loves it though!

Great rubber toy and treat that keeps dogs busy while cookig in the kitchen or receiving guest.  Last a log time designed for licking or scratching with teeth.  Dont have to worry about over feed with treats.
summary: Keep the dog out from under me feet.

reviewText: The "everlasting treat" that came with the ball lasted about five minutes. I don't recommend them. Putting kibble inside is a real challenge for the dog -- unless they are very small and fall out they are very difficult for a dog to get to either by biting or using its tongue. The "ports" are very stiff. My dog (a black lab) lost interest because she could not manage to get to the treats that would not fall out. Chewing the ball itself seemed to provide some satisfaction. The material seems very durable. All-in-all I have mixed feelings about this toy.
summary: Durable and a challenge for the dog

reviewText: This kept by 150lb Giant Newf busy for an entire day - he couldn't get the treat discs out and because they are so hard he chewed on it for hours without eating them all.Then my 65lb hound dog stole it from him, quickly figured out how it worked and chewed up the BALL portion until the treats were accessible.  Within 15 minutes of her having it the ball was in pieces all over the floor and she had taken out both treat discs.
