i bought this replacement flap for my petsafe quick fit pet door.  i purchased the small (up to 12 lbs) and it fits perfectly.  tip: measure your flap size because i have found the "small for the ultimate pet door" doesn't fit the "quick fit" model even though they're both from the same manufacturer/brand.  it's incredibly easy to install.  i can do it within a few minutes with a cordless drill but a regular screwdriver will work too.  i usually have to replace it every three to four months (more frequently during the winter season) but with two dogs it seems reasonable.  i use to purchase these from an ebay seller but i was delighted to find them on amazon where it was five dollars cheaper and offers free 2 day shipping with my prime membership :-)
summary: best value around for this replacement flap

reviewText: wasn't sure whether this would fit, since the measurements were off a bit, but it's the perfect size after all

This product came quickly and installed perfectly.  I will probably need to order another one when this one wears out (which is inevitable given the beating that it gets from my dog on a regular basis) but it keeps me from having to replace the whole door.  I'm really happy with this product.

I purchased this to replace the flap on my catdoor that had fallen off. I am not a genius but if you measure to get the correct size and can remove and replace 3 screws its clear sailin'. It fits well and looks heavy duty enough to stand up to the weather. It is raining and gettin' cold here so I got it done in the nick of time. I recomend it .

I really thought the flaps were all interchangeable on the Petsafe doors.  I was wrong.  This fits some Petsafe doors, but not all.  It's best to go to the Petsafe site and see what door you have so you can order the right one.  This was an inch too short for my Freedom model.
summary: Check your model!  This is not universal!  Doesn't fit ALL Petsafe medium doors!

reviewText: Just what I need to upgrade the old soiled, warped flap.  Installs in just a couple of minutes.  Perfect fit and replacement with the magnetic strip, screws, etc.  I'll be back next year.

Very effective!  i have 2 chihuahuas that bark all the time and drive me and my neighbors crazy.  this thing is amazing!  comes with a battery.  easy to use. just point click and say "no" at the same time.  i have used other bark control devices as well; none as good as this one.  love it!  i'll have to buy one for every room of the house.

It doesn't work....sometimes it does, most of the time it doesn't. It worked for about three days and then all of a sudden stopped working after we had it for about a month. We only use it when necessary but unfortunately right now it is completely useless and the batteries work fine. I also do NOT recommend for house with indoor cats.

I have a silky terrier & 2 pomeranians who love to bark at everything & I decided I needed to do something to get a handle on it. I did some research on items like this-knowing that they are not a 'magic bullet' solution, but a tool that could help-& this one had great reviews. I ordered it & what a difference it has made. I let them see it, say "No" & click it once-that's all it takes.....they quiet down immediately. After a couple of weeks now-all I have to do is say "No" in most cases, but sometimes I have to pick up it up, w/o clicking it & they stop. They definitely know what it is!I am very impressed with this little blue thing & am so glad I decided to take a chance.
This worked great the first 2 days. Now both of my dogs ignore it. I would say it's a waste of money for 2 days. :(

I am amazed at how quickly this product worked for us. We wanted to train our terrier to not bark and everything that passed by our window. I used the device to stop his barking after I had already given him the command to "stop." He quickly turned around and stopped barking. It did not seem to cause his distress. The next time he barked I did the same. The third time I just said stop and he quit barking.Read the directions carefully. Only use this device as part of your training plan. Use it in short bursts rather than holding it down. And keep it out of sight so the dog reacts to your commands, not the device. I hope to eventually quit using the device all together. I am going to try taking it on walks too.It is nice when a product works as promised. It is worth the small price for peace and quiet.

We bought this unit to train our Chihuahua to stop barking. She definitely hears it and does respond to it but it does not stop her from barking when you use the unit. I feel it was a complete waste of money.

We have one of the common dog problems: four small poodles who go berserk anytime a doorbell rings or a guest enters the house. And while they've done a good job of teaching each other this behavior, our efforts to use the normal methods of breaking the behavior have been ineffective.One method which seemed to me to have great potential was to use a water squirt gun to squirt the dogs in the face to curb the barking. While that did have some positive effect, our youngest dog simply learned that when we pick up a squirt gun he should run to cover to continue his barking. LOL Then the other dogs join back in.This device has made immediate progress. One short tap on the button gets their attention and stops the barking immediately. I'm then able to call them to me, give them a treat for performing "come", and hold their attention.I did quite a bit of reading about using devices like this before I decided to get one and try it out. I think that the most important tips were (a) to not overuse it and (b) to use it in combination with other interaction and a reward for positive behavior.If you are having a problem behavior which this might help, I suggest trying it. Others have not had any success using this device at all. If you try it and don't have success Amazon will let you return it.Your best chance of success is to do some reading about other training methods which may correct the problem behavior and use those in combination with this device. The usefulness of this device is to interrupt the behavior and get the dog's attention, then use that opportunity to build better habits. It should NOT be used as a punishment for the problem behavior.Recommended.

Tried several other methods to stop my dogs from barking.  Shock collars weren't consistent and I was afraid of hurting my little dogs.  This gets there attention (dosen't completely stop them) and things have improved.  I beleive this is the most humane training method to train my dogs.
Point the device at the offending cat or dog and then push the button.  They don't like the sound, although I can't hear it.I don't use it that much, but it has an immediate effect.
summary: Works well on cats and dogs

reviewerName: Gretchen H. "Enjoying life one strange moment...
reviewText: My husband and I moved into a fantastic apartment building with a huge unused backyard. Since the yard hadn't really been occupied over the years the neighbors dogs started going insane when we were back there cleaning up. As soon as they heard you coming down the stairs they would start and just not stop. I found out about these types of devices in SkyMall (!!) and did a little footwork until I found this beautiful piece of equipment.When it arrived we opened it and my husband did the human thing and pushed the button right next to our cat who proceeded to leap from my arms and run down the hallway. Not only have we managed to train the neighbor's dogs to be quiet but our own cat. We had tried everything from a spray bottle to putting her outside while she pined for food before feeding time. We're talking at least an hour of constant meowing..One of the neighbor dogs is hard of hearing so it's taken it awhile to quiet down, but it still has. Most times we can go outside and not hear a peep and if they start up at all we just push the button once and silence. Another neighbor's dog, a really mean pitbull, used to have the habit of sneaking up on you and when you weren't expecting it start freaking out. Cujo doesn't do that anymore...I really, really, really like this device and I HIGHLY recommend it. Sweet sweet silence...
summary: I like to call this "The Screamer"

reviewText: This is a great little tool to control excess barking. One second press of the button and 10 screaming dogs all shut up.  I use it minimally because the one drawback is that when you use it, ALL the dogs get the annoying ultrasonic (we hear nothing) tone but I consider that acceptable collateral damage.  I have 10 show dogs and there are a few of them who would be unwelcome in hotels, etc, without the PetAgree...as they would bark in the rooms.  It also works on my male when he complains about not having access to girls in heat.  Makes life much more pleasant for all of us as I don't have to listen to excessive barking and the dogs choose to stop the behavior without constant nagging and correction. One reminder is all that is needed.

I have 3 german shepherds (GSD) and a pit bull...I NEED something to help quiet them when something (real or imaginary) sets them off barking!  Unfortunately, this is not it.  I thought it was working at first; one of the GSDs didn't bark the first time I  clicked it to stop him.  But the next day, it had no affect on that one or any of the others. I clicked it when they were lounging to see if it was working and their ears did perk up, so I know it was working.  Returning it today.  : (
summary: Disappointing... did not work for my GSDs or Pit Bull.  : (

reviewText: I bought this to aid my one dog in not barking...she is blind but not deaf and it had no effect on her ...but my other dog who is very calm would run out of the room when I pressed the button...I think it can be an effective tool for the right dog...solidly made

This works great.  I have two digs that bark when people come in the house-  now i press the button and it shuts them right up.  Its to the point after a week i dont even use it anymore,  they either don't bark or they stop when they see me go to pick it up.  Very glad i bought it
summary: works as good as you could expect

reviewText: My two year old chihuahua mix, Jake, responded to it.  At first, I thought it was the greatest invention ever.  He would stop barking right away and come running in the house with his tail between his legs and tremble.  But even after I stopped using it he trembles and cowers most of the day.  He is afraid of people coming over, afraid of people walking down the street, afraid of sirens, scared to death when our new puppy barks.  It has completely broken his spirit.  He doesn't want to play anymore.  I thought I was doing the humane thing by using this noise deterrent rather than a shock collar but I can't imagine anything upsetting him more than this.  Funny thing is, the new puppy, a 4 month old havenese mix doesn't even act like she hears it.  I got a citronella spray collar for her since the ultrasonic collar was so upsetting to the first dog and it seems to be working. It has been almost a month since I last used the ultrasonic collar and he still shakes and trembles all the time when he thinks it is going to go off.  How do I reverse this?
summary: MY DOG IS A MESS NOW! HELP!

reviewText: This is a great training aide, don't expect to just push a button and have your dogs problems go away.  It can work as a bark deterrent for some dogs but others it may just make them bark more.  Like any dog training tool, there is no "one size fits all".That being said I love these type of dog whistles.  You can use it to call your dog in from outdoors very easily, just teach them that this sounds equals treat first.  Or you can use it as a distraction when on walks to help redirect your dog, tell them "leave it" when you push the button. I prefer to keep it my pocket and not point it at the dog.

My original review follows but I have decided to add to it.  I got the nerve to aim it at my dog to see if he even noticed.  He did.  He didn't act like it hurt him (which was good!) but he stopped what he was doing and looked at me.  I have done this several times and the reaction has been the same.  I can see how it would be helpful for training which I don't need.  Well maybe I will point it at him when he is eating the cat poop in the yard!  It will not help you if a dog is charging after you but if you want something to get your dogs attention when he is doing something wrong-that is does.  OLD REVIEW I ordered this on the advice of my vet.  There are many cats that run freely in my neighborhood and use my yard for their bathroom, then my dog likes to eat it.  The vet thought the sound would discourage the cats from coming in the yard. I have tried shooting a water gun at them but it gets cumbersome so I wondered if there was something easer to use plus I thought it would come in handy when I am walking my dog and another dog comes up and starts acting aggressively.  The cats didn't seem to notice it when I have aimed it at them, even at close range and then tonight while walking my dog, a large dog ran up to us and started barking, I aimed it at him close range and it didn't faze the dog either.  The light is coming on so I know the batteries are still good.  Am really disappointed, it would be wonderful if it worked!

I only have two immediate neighbors, but let my two large dogs out early - 4:30 to 5 p.m. - and they often bark at the woods and respond to the coyote calls. Not a good thing that early in the a.m. They look up when I use it, right after telling them "quiet," but don't always stop barking. I suspect the problem is me, not the ultrasonic aid. I will keep working on training.

I have a schnauzer who used to like to bark at the doorbell...... BUT the main problem was she just went ballistic when my grandsons come over.  I had a little family meeting and got everyone on board and we began using the command word STOP for both the doorbell and her frantic behavior when my grandsons come over.  It took all of three times to get her attention.  It really works.  I did not go with a food reward when she stops.... just a simple pat on the head.  You do need to point it at the dog and you also need to follow the instructions.  i.e....... don't let the dog see you holding the device.  I only have to use it now every few days to just gently remind her to stop.  It is a miracle..........  plus my good wife has stopped getting mad at me for not controlling MY dog.  :)
summary: My dog has stopped barking at the doorbell

reviewText: This didn't work for my dog at all. The light lit up and I could hear the sound myself, but it literally had NO effect on my barking dog. Total crap, thankfully amazon is awesome and I got a full refund, don't waste your money

I bought a few different brands of bark off type gizmos, this device works better and faster at getting my dogs to stop compared to the auto ones I put on my fences, but it doesn't work further than 20 feet, I got these things because I'm tired of yelling, they almost always bark for a good reason, they're doing their job, but it is usually when my neighbors peek over the fence which becomes a bigger problem if any other neighbors get pissed at the barking. I bought one that looks like a bird house that so far has the longest range, but it seems to work in one general direction, so if they're barking beyond the device it doesn't work so good, and the bark offs that are on the fences are not as loud, I can tell because they stop barking when they don't get too rowdy, but they don't stop when they're barking their heads off.
summary: Works great, wish it had a longer range

reviewText: I purchased this because my two Golden Retrievers needlessly bark at people/dogs walking by our home. But, before making a purchase, I evaluated what type of barking they were doing to determine if it was anxious/fearful barking or rather just barking to alert one another (or us) of people/dogs walking by. Through watching their facial expression & body language, I determined that they are just barking to bark, to alert one another (or us), or barking out of excitement - there is no anxiety/fear association. As such, I wanted a device that would get their attention away from the stimuli so they can pause & think, without causing them physical discomfort. I have been diligent to provide positive feedback/training & verbal cues along with the use of this device. Here is how I use it:When they start barking at a passerby, I press the button once or twice & immediately say "No bark."  When they stop barking, I praise them & give a treat. This method has reduced the barking to the point where sometimes I can say, "No bark" just before or as they see passerby's without having to use the device, & they will not bark. They know that letting out a bark from seeing passerby's will elicit use of the device. However, with that said, I do not use the device to deter barking all together - only when barking occurs from passerby's. Dogs are dogs, & dogs should bark as a natural form of communication, so I am teaching them when it is & is not appropriate to bark. To this point, they are understanding the distinction just fine! They still bark when we are playing, when they get excited, & they still make barking sounds in the morning & when we come home as their way of saying, "hello" to us.I also carry this with me when we go on walks to deter them from barking at other dogs (which they don't usually do anyway) & to deter other dogs from darting out as us (ex. stray dogs, dogs not kept in a fence or on a leash, etc.). It causes the loose dogs to stop so we can get past them. It is a great safety tool to have with you when you go for walks!Because each of my two girls are unique, one is more sensitive to the device than the other now. Initially, they both experienced the same reaction to the device, but now one of them doesn't seem as bothered by it, while the other is still very bothered by it. So, do not be surprised if the sensitivity to the sound that the device elicits eventually wears off & they are no longer bothered by it. Fortunately, I haven't needed to use the device too often because they picked up on the training pretty quick because I made it a positive situation, & helped them make distinctions between when it is & is not appropriate to bark.For this device to be effective: a) first evaluate the root cause of the barking b) combine it with immediate positive reinforcement c) combine it with verbal reinforcement d) only use it when warranted. Using a device to remedy barking that stems from fear/anxiety is not the correct way to deter barking. In that situation, using a device could elicit a worse response as well as reinforce a negative association with the stimuli causing them bark. You never want to "punish" or negatively reinforce behaviors that stem from anxiety/fear; we should want our dogs to be confident & retain their "spirits." This device could also be useful to deter dogs from jumping up on people, if used consistently & positively; there are many uses for this device.

The battery with a use by date of 2015 was DOA.  I replaced the battery and the red light would come on when pressed but had no effect on either of our dogs or other dogs. I returned it to Amazon for a refund.

I purchaed this product hoping it would work for my Pug.  Well it worked for about a week. All of a sudden my boy became fearful of everything.  I never had any problems before except for the barking.  I made a mistake my boy was almost perfect but he did have a barking problem, we have many agressive dogs near us and he became fearful.After using this for almost a week my boy is now scared of everything.  He does not want to go off my deck for his walk, he has started to urinate in the house for fear of going out. He seems angry at me and will not jump on my lap no matter what I do. He is attacking my cat now. I cannot touch certain body parts sometimes, his barking is much worse. He is now neurotic.  I did not believe the report that said this is a possibility.I gave up the device and now am working very hard to re-establish our very loving bond that we had before.  It is hard but worth it.Honestly please consider that this may happen to your baby and try something else, this is not a cheap fast fix.  If you take note most of these reviews are within the first few days or weeks, that is when the problem started for me and my dog.Get a good book like Fiesty Fido found here on Amazon cheap and do you and your baby a favor.
summary: Danger to dogs please do not buy

reviewText: In short, my 17 old cat just completely ignores it, and 7-year old cat just barely notices there is some sound but it does not prevent him to do what he intended to do. Wasted money!

I do love it except I really didn't have anything to connect it to in my front seat soI had to make some little changes with it so now it works but he can't move to much with it on.other then that I feel more at ease with him wearing it.
summary: pet buckle kwik-connect tether for the universal harness

reviewText: I recently purchased this product to use while my 11-lb. dog rode on my lap on a cross-country flight, as well as in cars at our destination. I appreciated its ease of use and rather solid construction. My only complaint is that the clip that connects the product to your dog's harness appears a bit flimsier than I would like. The stationary side of the clip is solid, but the part that moves aside to allow the clip to fit over the harness loop is less solid looking than I would like. Overall, it made me feel my pup would be secure in a minor accident.

I use it with Solvit-Car Safety Harnesses For Dogs, the best car harness around. It is well padded and comfortable for my golden retriever. Very few dogs are restrained in cars, and that is a shame. The Solv-It harness comes with a secure strap that is attached to the lap or shoulder part of a buckled seat belt. It works well but after nearly three years of strain on my seat belt it no longer retracts as snugly as it used to. But I discovered a different type of secure strap this one: the PetBuckle Pet travel Safety Tether. It secures into the LATCH/ISOFIT latches in every car since 2003 designed to secure child safety seats. So by using the PetBuckle I can attach the dog harness to the car without putting constant strain on my rear seat belt because it is secured to the LATCH attachment.There is one detail I need to clarify. This large strap is supposed to be 30" long.  It isn't, at least on its own. The main strap is 25" long. The adapter strap to use it with a seat belt in a car that doesn't have the LATCH connectors. This adapter is about 5" long, so the two pieces together equal about 30". But because I'm securing a large dog with a long spine, the main strap itself was not long enough to give her enough freedom of movement. And because the main reason I bought this strap was to relieve stress on the same outboard seatbelt in the rear of my car I decided to combine the main strap of this product with the 6" or so (adjusted to its shortest length) strap that came along with her Solv-It Car Safety Harness.  This product is snapped into the LATCH connector, and it is clicked into the carabiner of the safety harness strap and that is then connected to the safety harness the dog is wearing. This all works together for me.  But it is important to keep in mind that the length isn't 30". It may or may not be a concern to you.My dog can sit, lie down, and put her head out of the window and I know she is safe and secure. And my car's leather upholstery is protected by a cover from wet feet, hair, and mud. I'm a happy girl.
summary: Nice latch to secure dog safety harness

reviewText: I previously purchased the Dogit Nylon Car Safe-T-Belt for hooking up to the harness on our 70+lb. pit bull in the back seat of the Tundra.  Unfortunately, it allowed him to climb half way across the center console to hinder the driver's view.  Yes...even in a large Tundra...yes, he is large with a humongous head...and not fat at all. So, back to Amazon for a shorter seat belt attachment.  Unfortunately, no manufacturer makes this thing any shorter.  So, I looked at the various existing designs that might shorten the over all length via attachment options.  The PetBuckle Kwik-Connect Tether did it!  Using this reduced the length by approximately 3 inches...which was like a magic number to discourage him from standing on the center console.  It was a lot easier to get him to back off the console and sit down now...plus using the pinch collar...he is more obedient while wearing the pinch collar.  Whenever he chooses to climb back up on the console, I lift up on the pinch collar, and he remembers the last command and sits down again.  As for the Kwik-Connect feature, I love it!  I don't have to mess with digging for the seatbelt buckle under the pet hammock cover...just simply disconnect to take him out of the truck, and quickly reconnect once back in the truck.  The combination use of the pinch collar and the PetBuckle Kwik-Connect Tether attached to his harness has greatly improved our truck driving experience!

Best device ever, Pet has to be in a harness, One end connects to child safety buck in between the cushions of your back seat, The steel looking buckles, I never knew what they were for, now I've made use of them, The other end clips to your pets "D" ring harness, where leash normally clips. The strap is adjustable for your pet, Mine is set so that he may stand, sit, lay, but cannot get in between the front seats to effect my driving safety. I have one on each side for both of my bullies. In a slow speed collision, I have no doubt this travel harness would keep my pet safe, in my opinion, and at a high speed collision, it's anyone's gamble anyway. When in town traveling to pet smart, the vet or simple errands, My pets love to go for car rides, and this was the only way I knew to keep them safe, and not impair my driving safety also, I rated it 5 stars, Because it's such a life saver.
summary: Best safety device for my two English Bull Dogs

reviewText: better then what I had. Good enough till I can get better. I can't shorten this enough, she can still get to the front seat.
summary: Too Long dog is hooked in back seat and is still getting in to the front.

reviewText: I'm not sure what car this was designed for, but it doesn't really work well in any of ours.  The LATCH clip won't clip to the anchors in an 04 Jeep Wrangler, 99 Civic, or an 01 Saturn SL1, which means using the included strap for each car.  It is also very short, and I don't have much confidence in the clip that goes to the dog's harness, at least if an accident were to occur.  It does keep the dog in the seat, which is an important part.

...and my expectations were high.  If you wonder if this will work with your vehicle, look in your car, near the point where your seatbelts go between the seat base and the seat back - if there is a hard metal loop (like a big D-ring but hard fastened to the vehicle) in the crevasse, then this will work.  It installed in a snap and came out just as fast, but your dog is unlikely to have the dexterity to press the button and pull at the same time.  If you're hoping the tether will disconnect from the base (the black plastic part with the red button) and go into your standard seatbelt receiver, the answer is NO.This thing is solid.  No plastic in the critical path of the tether; metal latch, metal adjuster for length, and metal attachment to your pet's harness.  The extra piece is seatbelt material and probably sturdy enough to lift a small car.PLEASE use a harness with this product, not a choker collar or your pet's everyday (just around the neck) collar.  Sure, using it in this manner will keep your pet in the seat as you go down the road, but you'll break the poor things neck in an accident.
this tether works great you can attach it to your cars anchor points or the seat belt, works great to keep your dog safe from sudden stops or god forbid an accident happens

My Standard Poodle wears an "Easy Rider" harness for car riding and the first tether I got for her hooked right into the seat belt latch.  That was great.  EXCEPT she would step on the latch and release herself so when we got where we were going, she was already loose.  Not acceptable.  So I got this one which attaches to a bar under the seat where she can't step on it and now she stays completely attached and safe...not  that I plan on wrecking...but in a quick stop she is also protected.  Great discovery.  And she can't step up and balance on the console as my other ones have done.  So much safer!
This is a well-made, easy to use tether. We never take our dog in a vehicle without using it. Gave one to a friend for her dog and they (she and her dog) love it too.
Love it. Easy to use.. I set it up with my anchors embedded in the seats and I just leave it there. It's like having another seat belt on huge seat.

Got this to secure our dog when riding in the sedan.  Easily attached to the LATCH point, with the strap running under the headrest.  Connects to the dog's safety harness very easily.  The nylon strap portion extends to about 32 inches;  enough to allow the dog to lie down, move around a bit in the back seat, etc.  Recommended.

I bought this for my 3 year old weimaraner after I had a very scary car accident.  It is very easy to use and seems to keep him in a safe position.  My dog has always been a good car rider, but for people who are looking for something to keep their dog sitting in the back seat, this would be a great solution.  My dog still has room to stand and turn around, but not much else.

This served our late, elderly, yellow lab, very well.  As our girl got older, and had difficulty hopping up and down the two steps to go outside, this became a back-saver for us, and a body-saver for her.  This gave us the ability to assist her with impeding what she could do, kept her from losing her balance and falling, and we didn't have to worry about tripping and falling with her in our arms, because it helps keep your pup right at your side [for lack of a better visual] like a suitcase.  The belts can be a bit confusing for someone who doesn't use it on a regular basis, but overall, it's a great product to assist your pup, elderly or otherwise.
My dog was older, ill, trouble with steps, car, etc.  Took me a little while to get straps adjusted, but after a little practice believe can be adjusted to almost any dog.  A big help to help him.

Hi,I purchased this product to help us walk our injured dog.He is a big lab.It does not help.It may be ok for a smaller dog.It doesn't even help us lift him into the car.The lift slips and he doesn't have a secure hold.I wouldn't recommend this unless your dog is under 50lbs.It might help.ThanksA Dog Lover

reviewerName: Jeri Zerr "formerly a Road Warrior of the Nth...
reviewText: This summer we came home one eve to find one of our German Shepherd Dogs paralyzed... ever try moving a 95 pound German Shepherd several times a day for many weeks while the dog recovers use of his hind legs after spinal surgery? GET THIS, it's a back saver!  Btw the emergency clinic gave us a simple sling to use, we bought this one then both the university vet and the rehab vets office tried to sell us their very elaborate and very expensive mobility harnesses.  We *much* preferred this mobility harness and returned the others. Our German Shepherd did NOT like the style where each of his rear legs had to be lifted and placed through the harness straps as well as it was always in the way of him emptying his bladder or bowels.  This harness was *easy* to adjust under him to free up his "male parts" (not sure which anatomy words Amazon will allow!) for urination and was never in the way of his bowels.  Kudos for a well made and designed product.  Thankfully we no longer need to use the sling nor mobility harness, but this is a keeper in case we ever have to deal with another injury (and would have been very useful to have a few years ago when our elderly 13 yo female German Shepherd was having issues from an old back injury.)Update: sadly our senior male GSD has regressed and is again needing assistance.  I am thankful each and every day that we chose this simple sling design instead of the elaborate and expensive system that both Mizzou and the Rehab Clinic tried selling us.  By removing the extra straps and using this as a simple sling it allows me (despite physical disabilities myself) to stabilize his rear legs while he powers forward with his front legs. I am so thankful this sling allows him to fully evacuate both his bladder and his bowels without interference - we are already dealing with enough other issues.  I recall watching the ordeal the vet techs at Mizzou were going through as well as the discomfort he seemed to be in to get into the other fancy harness and it was always in the way of defecation so clumps would get caught inside and fall out when it was being removed - quite messy at times.  This sling has NONE of those issues!!! So again, I am very thankful I made this choice.
summary: designed to lift the front end, can be used without straps to lift the rear end

reviewText: My dog tore her cruciate ligament, had operation and needed to be carried up and down the stairs.  This harness is very secure.  Secured around the head, shoulder area and also around the tummy.  Dog will not fall out of this if it leans forward.I have had expensive harnesses, 3x's more $$$ and none were worth it.

The sling is simple yet effective. I had a large dog that needed assistance standing. The sling did a good job. It would be nice if the handles were padded but for the inexpensive price it was a good deal.
I ordered this lift for my sister's Dobie who is older and now has arthritis and hip problems.  It has not arrived yet but I am sure it will do the job as we expect it to do.

I have an Outward Bound velcro sling for the dog, but since she got hurt, she needs help at BOTH ends. I got this one for the front of her.What a pain in the neck to put this on! We're talking about trying to get a dog who has trouble standing and walking to move into the straps so it can be lashed to her.I understand with all the straps, this is for the front so she won't fall out of it. I probably should've gone for another Outward Bound velcro model, since my dog is chunky and very unlikely to slip out of anything.It works fine, but God help you if you have a dog with leg problems and you yourself have back issues. You're both gonna be in pain!

My dog is a lab 11 years old, with TPLOs in both his knees and big: 100 pounds.He became terrified of jumping in the car about 2 years ago, as I am sure it hurts and causes damage. He would literally shake and pull back, laying in the ground. He is 100 pounds, so imagine the difficulty to pick him up against his will.So, going to the vet, to visit family, I needed help to practically pick him up.Last weekend I got this thing, put it on, and with a friend we walked my dog to the back of the car, where I had put his own bed in the floor, to give him some height, and encouragement.Voila, he made the motion and I pulled the back up, and he got in the car! As he landed up I softly lowered the sling, so he could rest on his 4 legs. We went to a park, visit family, got back, and next day we came home, and every time his back feet flew with him and landed in the car, without any trouble.Its not that now we can drive everywhere ever day as we used to, but he is more confident and I am too. In a couple days we are visiting the vet, and I feel a relief about the car trip.One great thing is that you can leave it on the dog, no need to put back on.

We have a very finicky and elderly chow who resists anything "strange" but he has not had any problem with this harness and seems to even realize that it is helpful.  It does assist you in giving your pet some extra balance and lift when they have trouble getting up from laying down or need help upstairs.

You can tell that this isn't a high quality manufactured item just by looking at it but I didn't expect it to be. However, for the price this harness works fine. Our 56 pound dog has spine and hip issues and when she has a flare-up we sometimes have to support her mid-section to help her walk. We've used a couple of different homemade devices but the Lift-N-Aid works a little better. It provides a fairly wide area of support, it stays on, and the handles make holding her up easier. I haven't had any problems with the harness sliding up on her like some of the reviews mentioned. Yes it does ride up a little but no more so than what I was using previously. It's a little difficult to get the harness on my dog but that's not the fault of the harness. My dog is squirrelly about harnesses and collars in general. I would't pay more for this product but for $15 it's worth it.

The best kitty litter I have used. There is no clumping - the pellets turn to very fine sawdust after use. Odor is absorbed really well by this litter. I use it for my three cats and won't be trying anything else.

My cats love it and so do I.Pros:No clay dust. No clay mess. No clumps of clay. NO CLAY. My cats do not track it all over my house. Doesn't stick to paws. Flushable.Cons:Requires a unique litter scooper to let pellets pass through. IRIS one works perfect.I highly recommend. This is a must buy for any cat owner.

I really like this product as a day to day litter. When it needs to be changed it comes out easily and is light weight to throw away. When I show my cats though I take a gel crystal litter as the Feline Pine does get dusty and can stain the feet. Household cats don't have to worry about it.

I actually bought this for my dog to use.  I have a mini dachshund and he uses a dog potty called Ugodog.  I tried the dog pottys with the artificial grass on top and they just smelled awful because the urine clings to the grass and my dog didn't want to use it (I don't blame him).  I put the Ugodog out on the patio and he uses a sliding glass doggie door to go out.  I put about 1 1/2 cups of pine pellets in the Ugodog tray which is lined with plastic--I buy the Glad OdorShield Tall 13 gal. trash bags and cut them in half because cat box liners didn't fit.  Then the grate goes on top. I change the pellets about once a week or every 5 days and the pine completely covers the urine odor.  It's easy to lift out the liner and fold up and dispose of the used pellets and solids are flushed.  I tried using paper instead of the pine pellets, but they smelled and were not as absorbent.  Highly recommend the pellets.

Several years ago I litter box trained my Pomeranian dog. We started out with the doggie litter pellets which we mutually agreed were awful so we switched to traditional clumping cat litter. My dog neurotically spins about 50 circles in her litter box before she'll actually do her business, which kicks up a lot of dust. Not only was the dust getting into her lungs and making her cough, it was settling on everything in my house. This was a problem. We had other smaller issues with traditional litter as well, like the occasions when she'd step in the middle of her business and get wet disgusting litter smashed up in her paws (and all over my floors) and just the mess of it in general (picture a tiny fluffy dog spinning rapid circles in a small area, spraying little pieces of clay in all directions). We've been through several brands of clumping clay litter and all have yielded similar results. Finally enough was enough, and with all these gripes about traditional litter I began my search for something better.When I first heard about this product I was a bit leery as the pellets resemble the dog litter we tried way back when but the idea of trying an all natural product combined with the reasonable price B&M; was enough to persuade me to buy a bag.I emptied out her litter box completely and replaced the litter with the pellets. The first time I introduced her to her new box of pellets she seemed hesitant but with a bit of coaxing she spun a few circles and did her business. Since then she's gone in her box without issue, and despite the circle spinning she's not kicking up dust and making herself cough every time she's in there, nor is she making a mess all over my floors.Scooping this stuff takes a bit of getting used to. When the pellets get wet they break down into what looks like fluffy sawdust (see customer images).  I scoop a couple times per day to ensure no sawdust gets tracked through my house. Even when wet the "sawdust" is never sticky and is easily removed from the box. I just scoop a small amount at a time and shake it over the trash can to sift out the sawdust, then return the remaining pellets in the scoop to the box.My only gripe about this product would be the smell. The pine smell was rather strong at first but it does dissipate (although it never disappears completely). Personally I prefer the smell of pine over the smell of perfumed clay litter though so all things considered it's not too bothersome.Overall I'm really pleased with this product. Finally a litter that solves our problems at a reasonable price. Great litter!

I have 4 kitties, and this is by far the best product I have used.  I have tried them all.  I've tried the pearls, the corn litter, the paper litter, and of course the traditional clay litter.  The thing I love the most about this litter is how little it can be tracked.  The pearls can be tracked, and it hurts like a @#$%#$ when you accidently step on it.  The corn litter and the paper litter doesn't mask the smell of urine.  And the clay litter leaves dusty floors no matter how many times you clean.  The pine litter is by far the least tracked litter.  Another thing I like about this litter is the way it can cover up urine smell.  It smells like wood, or the "new furniture smell", even after the cats do their thing.  The litter turns to powder after it comes in contact with urine.  But since it absorbs it so well, you just see saw-dust.  All you have to do is scoop up the solid waste, and when the puebbles turn mostly to powder, you just change out the litter.  The powder can be tracked a little bit, but again, must less than any other litter.Something I recently learned is that if you collect the pine points at the back of the package, you can redeem it for scoopers and litter boxes and other kitty stuff.  And you don't need to buy 100 bags to get something.  I can redeem points from 2 bags for a scooper already.

Pros: Does not smell like cat litter when you pour itFlushableCons: Makes the room with your litter box smell like cat poopTexture may not be accepted by your catI was toilet training my cat and needed to switch to a flushable litter. I gradually mixed this into my cat's standard litter box for a week. He did not like it. At first he held it for about 36 hours before finally, grudgingly using it making sad meows the whole time. The texture is radically different than any sort of litter and is made in very large pellets. As I transitioned to the citikitty, he again would only use it grudingly and twice decided that other locations were more preferable! I switched to "World's Best" litter and he likes it much better and doesn't go to inappropriate locations anymore. It is very flushable, and even flushed after my cat scraped his entire pan into the toilet, causing the liter to absorb all of the standing water in the toilet basin. It may not smell like litter when you pour it, but it doesn't clump and absorb odors so your room smells like cat poop. If you do decide to use this with the Citikitty, you'll need a lot more than the label suggests for standard boxes- every time your cat uses it, he'll scrape about 1/3rd of the litter in the pan into the toilet.

Considering what cat litter products are available to me, this is the best choice. I only have one requirement for cat litter. No odor. Feline Pine delivers. As far as I'm concerned, if you can walk into my New York City sized studio and not smell a single one of my five cats, then this product is doing it's job and doing it 100%.Unlike clay litters this does not leave annoying clay rocks all over my apartment. It leaves absolutely no trace of urine odor. And that disgusting wet urine saturated clay litter smell? Gone forever. When I come home from work, I smell nothing.I don't know if my town even has a feed store to get the cheaper version of Feline Pine. I don't care. I'll gladly pay the extra money. In fact, I purchased two 20 pound bags today and it costs me about $20.00. It's worth it.A word to the unsatisfied. Try using a sifting litter box for Feline Pine or rubber gloves to clean the poop out by hand. Then you won't waste so much unused litter when emptying the feces and urine daily.

the house smells less "cat like" and the cat doesn't seem to mind it... sometimes he's lazy and doesn't cover his droppings, but it works rather well. I've launched the contents of the box in the back yard and it's gone next rain, it's all natural and other critters do their thing out there too. It does track a little across the floor around his box...

I was extremely skeptical at first.  How could pellets do anything for cat litter?  I had come across this stuff at my local pet shop since they had a bag on sale, got out the iPhone and went straight for the Amazon app to check reviews.  I was utterly amazed at the positive reviews.  Almost to the point of not believing them there were so many.  We were clay clumping it for so long, I had no idea there were other options.  I was surprised by the reviews and went for it.  I will never.  I mean NEVER go back to clumping litter EVER.  That stuff is utterly disgusting once you've used this litter.There is zero and I mean zero urine smell.  Yes, their crap stinks, but the clumping litter didn't do wonders on that either.The only mistake I made with this litter was I thought I could make it work using my existing litter box.  You absolutely need a sifting one and after looking all over the net, it sounds like the best one is of course the one Feline Pine makes.  But after shipping, it was over $30.I thought I'd go it on my own and created one using an 11/64 drill bit (that is the perfect size that doesn't allow pellets to fall out).  Yes it took about 2 hours to drill and 2 battery charges and lord knows how many holes later, but in the end, it works and it works well.You can not go wrong with this purchase.  It is as simple as that.

EDITED TO ADD 3/18/2012: Still using this wonderful litter. My 7-month-old kitten uses it, my two-year-old Siamese and my 12-year-old Domestic Shorthair. We have two of the special sifting litter boxes made by the third-party company which makes them for Feline Pine. That is the only way to use Feline Pine, in my opinion, because it is so easy to use that way. Love this litter!EDITED TO ADD 2/10/2010: This is my new favorite cat litter. It does not track. It smells of fresh, natural, wood scent - no added scents, nothing artificial. It has a special litter box made by a third party for Feline Pine that you can buy to sift and separate the fresh granules from the used sawdust. Call the company, Feline Pine, and ask them for details on how to buy their litter box and they will tell you how to order one. I was concerned because my vet said cats have trouble digging in it. In reality, they don't dig at all to urinate, or they dig very little and they defecate on top of it, which is easily removed.Get the sifting litter box, made by a company specifically for this litter, and tilt the box back and forth, sifting the litter once or twice a day to remove any "sawdust" from the top level--this will shift the sawdust to the bottom level of the two-level box. Use the box as directed for best results.I have never been so happy with a litter system in my life. It has made life very easy. No more dusty litter everywhere. No more small clay granules tracking all over the house. (Note: the litterbox is denoted as "self cleaning" but it really is not; however, it is so easy! All you do is tilt it side to side and sift.)I have found my litter. I am 100% happy with this litter, COMBINED with their litter box.How to switch your cats to this litter: Put one inch of this litter on top of your current litter. Let your cats dig into it and mix it up as they use both litters in the same box. Gradually increase the quantity of this litter used and lessen the quantity of your old brand. I switched an 18-year-old cat to this litter!A NOTE ABOUT PINE OIL:  There is no toxic pine oil in Feline Pine cat litter. Many people think of pine oil in products like Pine Sol, which contains phenol, which *is* highly toxic to cats. I contacted the company prior to using this product. I received this assurance:"The production of our Feline Pine products incorporates both kiln-drying at 380 degrees (bakes out oils, phenols, and hydrocarbons) and pressurization (10,000 foot-pounds squeezes out further compounds) before the product reaches its packaging.""Our litters are completely natural and contain zero chemicals or artificial fragrances."My vet, who has a cats-only vet clinic, and who has treated my 18-year-old cat since he was a kitten, highly recommends this litter.~~~~~ORIGINAL REVIEW:I initially tried this out with a litter of four rescued three-week-old kittens and their mother. It doesn't track and is big enough that the kittens don't try to eat it.  If the kittens sample it, it won't hurt their digestive tracts like clay clumping litter could. Downside: It is hard for kittens to dig in as the granules are so big.After the granules are broken down, they are easier for your cat to dig, as they turn into sawdust.Pros:* Low to zero tracking* Produces zero dust* No odor - excellent odor control* Safe for kittens and cats of all ages* Flushable* Turns into sawdust after it is urinated on; and then it is easy for cats to dig in* NOTE: Feline Pine now makes a clumping form of this litter; it is a separate product* Lasts a really long time before you need to change itCons:* Large granules make digging harder for cats (the vet said this but I didn't find it to be a problem)* Doesn't cover poop well when it is in granule form. (However, I scoop poop up quickly)(However, if you leave your Feline Pine in the box to turn to sawdust, it *will* cover poop.)* Is not a clumping litter (but Feline Pine now makes a clumping version of this litter!) This is the granules version; see the clumping version if you prefer that kind.NOTE: This Feline Pine "granules" is not a clumping litter.  (But they now make a clumping litter version of this product if you want to try it.)  For the granules version, once those large granules of wood are urinated on, it turns into dry sawdust.  It doesn't clump and is hard to scoop because the dry sawdust mixes with the granules.  It will stay dry for quite awhile -- a few days or a week or two -- depending on how many cats you have.  The best way to clean this litter is to remove all of it and put in new litter.The great thing about the granules is, zero tracking. And it really covers the urine smell.  If you want to scoop, try Feline Pine's clumping litter. I prefer this to Feline Pine's clumping litter, as the clumping litter doesn't clump very well and it still tracks.To get your cats accustomed to this litter, read and follow the instructions on the bag.  It is very important to put a layer of at least one inch of your old litter on top of this new litter, or your cat will probably not accept this litter. Please be patient with your cat during the transition.The litter granules are made of Southern Pine. Tree farmers periodically have to thin some of the smaller trees to let in sunlight, which makes the forest healthier.  Those smaller pine trees are used in these types of renewable products. This is an eco-friendly choice in cat litter.My vet said cats find it hard to dig in.  I agree, but once the granules are broken down by urination, cats find it easier to dig.  Swheat Scoop ... I plan to give that one a try next time. UPDATE: Actually, I did, but I think I prefer Feline Pine, plus now Feline Pine has come out with a scoopable version. I plan on mixing the two: the Feline Pine granules with the Feline Pine scoopable, as I'd like to scoop but also like the no-tracking granules.
summary: Pro: No Tracking granules! Natural scent! Use the recommended sifting box!

reviewText: Great, environmental litter. Does well keeping cat potty odor out of the house, but way too expensive!Found a great very similar product:  ExquisiCat litter...for about half the price of this stuff!

I have three cats who use litter boxes (the fourth one refuses to use any litter box period, so she doesn't count) and I have tried many different types of litter in my three litter boxes to help reduce the smell in my home, and the effort it takes to keep them clean. Cleaning out three litter boxes is a big, time-consuming job. Clay litters often stick to the edges of the box and need to be hosed down in the backyard. The clay also does not do a good job of absorbing odor, and the dust from it makes me cough. I have tried corn litter, crystal litter, baking soda littler, and even litter made of recycled newspapers. Feline Pine is absolutely the BEST cat litter there is. My cats all love it and have no problem using it. It controls the odor very well, without adding a perfume smell that my cats don't like. When people walk into my house, they can't even tell that I have three litter boxes. It's also very easy to clean. The pine pellets do not stick to the box. I just dump them out, quickly wipe them down, and I'm done. It has dramatically cut back on my litter box cleaning time.It does tend to break down into sawdust after about a week, and this can track all over the house. I recommend using a litter box mat to help cut down on it. Also, if you have kittens or young cats, they might like to play with the little pine pellets. My two-year-old used to bat them around the house, and if you step on them in the middle of the night--OUCH! However, he got over it after only a few days.

This litter does not clump and the cats have feces all around the box in a day.  We won't be buying this product again.  Within a day it STINKS and doesn't serve a purpose.  We will be going back to the normal Tidy Cats we previously used.

I don't believe people should know I have a pet by the smell of my house. Therefore, I like products that keep the smell to a minimum. I also believe in protecting my animals, the Earth AND myself by using organic and chemical-free stuff when I can. I have three cats, and Feline Pine is the BEST I've tried (and I've tried a few). It really absorbs and changes the smell of urine so that the ammoniated smell is eliminated, and it just smells like cedar, and it breaks down to dust, which flushes cleanly and healthily. I've used the expensive stuff, and it comes nowhere close to this.

I have been using Feline Pine Cat Litter for several months. I use it as an extender for my other cat litter. It is cost efficient and adds a wonderful fresh pine smell to the litter box.  It is easy to maintain the cleanliness of the litter box and helps keep it dry and inviting for your cats. I have 4 cats and they never had any problem adjusting to the addition of Feline Pine Litter to their box. Overall, this is an excellent product that I highly recommend for daily use. I purchase my bags through the monthly automatic delivery Amazon provides. It is such a pleasure not to have the worry about the availability at the local store and the convenience of having it delivered to my front door.

This is the only kitty litter I use now.  I like the fact that it has no toxic fumes and has little dust. Clean up is so much easier with this.  I recommend it over Feline Fresh, which is cheaper, but the pellets are smaller and fall through the litter scoop.

I've used all kinds of litter, clay, wheat, corn, and was never satisfied with any of them. I have a cat that always preferred doing her business outside of the box, until I got this litter. I didn't do any break in period, but I did have two litter boxes, one with the old litter, and one with feline pine.. they would use both equally, so when I ran out of the old stuff, I just filled it up with feline pine, and the cats don't even care. We have 4 cats, so I keep the two boxes in different rooms, to give them a "choice" of where they want to go.It DOES take a little more maintenance. It does not smell like cat urine at all, but you will smell poop, so you will want to clean that out daily, I do it twice a day if I need to, but usually just once a day. One a week, you need to sift all the dust out. I purchased a metal mesh grid off of amazon that works great [...] It cost $4. I scoop the litter onto the mesh, and shake it around over a box, then dump the pellets back into the litter box.. takes me about 15 minutes to do two big boxes.One day when I was at Home Depot to do some screen repair, they had a premade sliding aluminum screen, that costed $5, which might work well also.The litter itself lasts forever... I would say more than month with proper care.. and I have 4 cats.Another thing you might want to consider is changing their diet. At first, their poop would be a little on the soft side, which is difficult to clean, but I switched to Blue Buffalo Wilderness Chicken ([...]) which has no grain, and my cats poop is on the harder side, it doesnt smell (much).. and my cats are all around healthier and a lot more active.At first, you could really smell the pine.. it was a little over powering to be honest, but not in a bad way. I just had some friends over this past weekend, and I asked if our house smelled weird.. and they all said no... they were drunk, so I know they were telling the truth.

In the search for a more natural and less waste-producing cat litter, I stumbled upon Feline Pine.  Since I could not find an official Feline Pine cat box to use with it, I decided to try the Tidy Cats Breeze litter box.  My cat seemed to like Feline Pine just fine, and the Breeze box seemed fine, too.  At first.As for the litter itself, the true subject of this review, I really like it.  I especially like that you can actually flush the cat poop down your toilet, since the pellets dissolve into sawdust when they are wet.  Although the pellets did seem to stick to the poop, it was still really easy to scoop out of the box and dispose of.  I didn't notice much tracking beyond a very close perimeter of the box, probably due more to her attempting to bury her waste than to the pellets sticking to her paws.  No tracking upstairs as with the old clumping clay litter, no "litter box feet" smell on the actual cat, and no more licking clay litter dust when she is grooming.  The odor of the box is not horrible, but it certainly doesn't mask the poop odor like clumping litter.  I didn't buy it for that purpose, and my box is in the basement, so no big deal.  The smell wasn't intolerable, just kind of funky.  Wet sawdust meets cat urine meets poop.  And, this litter is pretty reasonable and lasts quite a long time, in my opinion longer than a tub of clumping litter because you don't use as much in the box.  Ultimately, the litter is a great product if you have a proper box to use it with.Now, for the box.  I read many reviews where people mentioned using the Breeze box with Feline Pine.  And it does work.  Kind of.  The wet sawdust falls into the tray below and the tray can be emptied into the trash.  The solid waste stays on top.  Every time I scooped the poop I'd sift the box, bringing the dust down to the tray.  Then I would dump the tray and I was done.  Very simple.  The problem is that every once in awhile you really do need to clean the box.  I don't mean scoop, I mean clean, with actual soap and water.  The tray gets rather nasty with all that urine-soaked sawdust falling down there (sometimes I'd even have standing puddles of urine waiting when I pulled out the tray) and would benefit from a soap and water cleansing about once a month.  So begins the nightmare.  The box is hard to clean with this litter in it!  The pellets get stuck in the sifting grid, and I don't have a utility sink in my laundry room, so I hauled the box upstairs to the tub to try to "rinse" them out.  The pellets dissolve in water, right?  No, they don't dissolve!  They turn into sawdust!  Big mistake.  Don't be foolish like I was and try to put Feline Pine sawdust down your tub drain.  Duh!  It clogs the drain!  I ended up with a bunch of sawdust in my tub, which I then had to plunge out of the drain and scoop out with my hands.  Disgusting.  I should really have tried picking them out first and then washing the box.  Live and learn.  Either way, it is a huge pain to soap-and-water cleanse the box.I am deducting a star because Feline Pine makes a box specifically for this litter, but it's not available!  I guess you could use a regular box, but that seems an even worse option.  You'd have a ton of soggy sawdust sitting on the bottom, and the cat would end up digging in that.  Gross.Feline Pine, I need a decent box for this litter!

If you have an Omega Paw self-cleaning litterbox, this litter will not work with it.  Otherwise, it has a pleasant smell with good odor control and a texture that cats don't seem to mind.  Just be prepared to do a lot of scooping.  I'd still rather go with "World Best Cat Litter" though.
summary: Does not work with Omega Paw litterboxes :(

reviewText: I have 2 cats and we use this litter. This is a wallet friendly option to traditional litters and much better for them. Traditional litters, can cause health hazards to your feline friends so we chose this litter and have stuck with it ever since. It cuts out on odor and there is very little stray litter around the house (though, I admit, my kitties like to play with the pellets). Our pet resort even commented on what a great litter it was!

I don't like this stuff at all, and most importantly, neither do my cats.  I wanted them to get use to a better kind of litter and first tried the Yesterday's News only to have them avoid it like the plague.  Then I thought maybe they would like this if it had a natural fresh scent.  Hard to say because even when I put a little in one box with their regular litter, which is clay, only one of my 3 will even venture in only to hop right back out. I have 3 cats and have 4 boxes set up for them which are cleaned at least twice daily...I know I know, I'm a clean fanatic with that which they are happy about to be honest.  Anyway, this stuff is bright yellow and has an awful smell to it AND it is dusty!  The pieces are so big and I'm guessing it would be uncomfortable to walk on.  Anyway, I can't picture this one being a winner and will probably try the cedar chips as one last try.  After that, I think I'm done trying to fix something that isn't broken.  I mean after all, they all use the boxes exclusively so I may just leave well enough alone.  If they don't want to be eco friendly, heaven only knows I can't make them.UPDATE 12-31-2011:  After several weeks of trying to entice them to using this, I gave up.  I put just a little in one box, out of 4...I have 3 cats, and they all avoided that one.  Even the one who was most curious about it and had investigated it in the beginning wanted nothing to do with that box.
summary: Not a hit in our house...so far.

reviewText: I only use Feline Pine in a top-entry litter box.  Kitty acclimated without any problems.  This has a distinct smell to it, I don't know how to describe.  It tracks less than clay but you do end up with small bits of pine when kitty is overzealous with his burying.  Doesn't do the best job of masking odors.ETA - this used to be on Amazon subscribe and save but was dropped.  Now I don't purchase on Amazon because I can find it elsewhere for less.  Amazon was so much easier than putting a 40-lb bag of cat litter on the back of my bike!

The pine litter is great.  No order; scoop what needs to be changed.  problem is that it is for some reason harder to get - and price has gone up.  I have 3 cats; they use it just fine (for years).  Petco also has one w/slightly smaller pellets which is also good; same w/the Petsmart version.

I have one cat that I adopted and that cat had to do her business in this stuff for the 11 months she was there. She doesn't use it here as I also have the regular clay in the other boxes. Even when the other boxes are full she still goes in the other one.My other cat peed in it and it stunk. Took a while before it soaked up the smell. I think he may have used it one other time. Box has been sitting there now for 6 weeks. They dont use it.They "say" clay is bad. Clay is a natural substance. In fact it's used medicinally (have you ever taken a clay bath to pull toxins out of your body?).

and both of my cats give it a high five!  I love being a cat mom, but hated traditional cat litter... the smell, the mess, and the removal.  Frustrated and searching for a greener path, I discovered Feline Pine.  Now I have no problems with litter box odor and once the poop is flushed, the odor free dust is recycled outside. New to Feline Pine, my pound kitties had no problems adapting to the change (I think they were relieved).  My mother was so impressed that she started buying it and her Sammy loves it too.  I have tried "copy cat" brands, but Feline Pine is worth the extra cost.  To top it off, Amazon delivers the 20 lb bag right to my door.  How cool is that?

I don't quite know where I stand on Feline Pine. It's the litter my cat's breeder used, so as to not cause confusion I bought the same. It does keep the urine odor under control and there's no dust. But of course, it does nothing for fresh feces. It breaks down to sawdust fairly quickly; I scoop 2-3 times a day and change the litter every Monday and usually by Friday it is 80% sawdust. When it becomes more powdery, fresh feces is nearly undetectable, plus I use copious amounts of baking soda. I try to imagine whether clumping litter would be better to use, but I'm not sure yet. I don't believe there is any great litter out there.

I love this litter because...1. It completely eliminates urine odor. It doesn't smell like a litter box typically does (like clay, urine and feces). Feces do smell right after your cat uses the box, but this goes away. The idea that a cat litter is going to eliminate feces odor right when the cat goes doesn't make sense to me...it would have to be loaded with chemicals and perfumes, which I don't want. The odor goes away within a few minutes, and I just scoop out feces at the end of the day.2. It is very inexpensive. You only fill the box a small amount, unlike clay litters. I use it along with the Feline Pine Self cleaning litter box, and this is the best value. I only have to buy a new bag of litter once or twice a YEAR.3. It does not track nearly as bad as clay or other fine grained litters4. Biodegradable materialsWhat would you rather have, a litter box with 3 or 4 inches of clay litter that starts smelling after only a couple of days and is disgusting and must be trashed by the end of the week, or an inch of Feline Pine, that does not smell and lasts for 2 weeks before needing to be changed? I almost want to laugh when I go to people's houses and I see their disgusting clay litter boxes, or see people buying clay litter at the store. Don't they know there's a way that is not only better for the environment, but doesn't smell and is a better value?I would also like to note that my cat is one of those picky sensitive cats that will not use litters with a lot of perfume or with a texture she doesn't like. I purchased the generic pine pellets at the pet store once and she flat out refused to use them, but she ok with the Feline Pine pellets.To those who are saying FP is a "poor value" because you can buy horse pellets at the store and they are the same, first of all I have my doubts that they are exactly the same and break down the same. I also don't understand why it is even an issue, considering that FP is cheaper than clay cat litters and works better. Personally I like shopping for cat litter and knowing that I am supporting a good environmentally friendly company, rather than a company that makes clay litter loaded with perfumes and chemicals.Note about the price: I don't recommend buying it here on Amazon. At most stores you can get a 20 lb bag for only $10, I have even seen them on sale for $8. I would never pay what Amazon is asking here.
summary: This is all I ever use anymore

reviewText: This crate turned out to be too small even for my chia-pom. I thought it would be a little bigger by the description. It's still sitting in the box in the shed waiting to find someone that may need it. Wasted money.

My cat is...shall we say a bit high strung? I had never had a cat before when I adopted her and bought this carrier to bring her home from the pound, intending to use it for future vet vists/general trips. My cat was less than 2 pounds the first time she was in the carrier but she freaked out. She was banging on the sides and trying to get out. One of the bolts that holds the top part to the bottom fell out! I didn't think much of it and just put a plastic tie into the hole and figured it would be ok. Fast forward to almost a year later and her first vet trip. Now she's almost 7 pounds and still wild when you try to contain her. By the time we got to the vet two more bolts had broken and fallen out! Also the cat managed to get on of the two posts that act as locks on the door released. If we had a longer drive she probably would have managed to get out completely! I do NOT recommend this carrier if you pet is uppity. We gave this carrier to the thrift store and purchased a different one. If your pet sits quietly in the carrier then this would be fine. If your pet is heavier or likes to jump around this is NOT a good carrier!
summary: Would be ok if your pet is calm

reviewText: The quality not the best very easy to break with in the first week pieces were breaking on it and my dog was able to find a way out of it!

Not a bad little carry case. I wouldn't send animals cross country in it but for a short trip to the vet. It was fine. It's not expensive and super sturdy but I had my 10 lbs cat in there and she was fine. My husband did put different ties on to keep the top and bottom together but it was here fast and I needed a new one.
summary: It is what you pay for

reviewText: FIRST THING.  DON'T USE THE CHEAP TABS TO PUT IT TOGETHER.  USE SOME STURDY ZIP TIES.  I PUT THIS TOGETHER TO TAKE MY KITTENS TO THE VET AND IT FELL APART AND I LOST MY CATS.  Great price but don't use the cheap tabs.
summary: Great in a finacial pinch but really flimsy

reviewText: we've had this bowl for a while now, not much to say. It does what it says. It doesn't move around a lot and there has been no rust or other issues. I recommend it if you need this size. We feed 1 cup of dry and 1/2 cup wet and there is plenty of room.

I bought this bowl for my German Shepherd puppy. I had one similar for my older (full sized Shepherd/Malinios mix) female and I really like it because it was solid and had the rubber grip at the bottom. This one is almost the same. Its a nice solid metal with a rubber ring to provide grip as the dogs eats. It is more than big enough and seems very durable and easy to clean. I would definitely get another one of these for the next pack member.

Ok some people have complained that these bowls smell.  Well one of mine did and the other did not.  After a few rounds in the dishwasher it went away rather quickly.  We have been using these bowls for 2 years now and have had no issues.  It is great that they do not skid around the floor. They also appear to not tip over easily.  We do not have a dog that tries to do that, like I have in the past, but I have tried to tip them.  We have 2 med bowls (3 qt) for meals and one larger bowl (4.5 qt)for available water. Theses sizes work perfectly for our medium size dog.  there is still plenty of room in the bowl if you need to give more food. I prefer my bowls bigger so that the food does fall out of the bowl.  We feed him 2 cups per meal twice a day.3 qt Med bowl measures 9 1/4 diameter by 3 inches high4.5 qt Larger bowl measures 10 3/4 diameter and 3 1/4 inches high.
Nice dog food bowl. The 3 quart capacity makes this a convenient size for my Labrador Retriever. blah, blah blah

If I could get the stickers off this bowl it would be five stars...I'm not surprised, as other reviews mentioned the difficulty of removing it, but I figured I would win the battle of stickiness...nope...2 months...sticker is still on.

I would recommend this bowl to any dog owner! It does not slide around the floor when they are eating. It is easy to wash which I do by hand nightly & when I use the dish washer they go in the dish washer. The dogs would definitely give the bowl a 5 star & I would agree. Wish I had all my bowls like these, they are great! Love them!! ♥
summary: Convenient Bowl which does not Slide around on tile Floor!

reviewText: I like the fact the bowl doesn't scoot around the kitchen floor when the dogs use it.  The rubber on the bottom is a terrific idea!

reviewerName: Dr. B. Santos "I appreciate honest advertising."
reviewText: Each morning I prepare breakfast for many animals. We use only metal bowls because plastic can cause health problems and ceramic is too easily broken and may contain lead*. Over the years the clanging of the bowls on the tile countertops and floors, has been more than annoying. Other rubber-rimmed steel bowls just haven't worked very well for us. I bought my first Durapet bowl a couple months ago and love it. It is sturdy, quiet, and less likely to slide around on tile. I have since purchased 4 more Durapet bowls.*Pet bowls are not regulated for lead content like human dishes are so please don't use ceramic pet bowls unless the company certifies their dishes as lead-free. Even then I would test them myself with a lead-test kit such as this:Homax 5250 Household Lead Test Kit
summary: No more clanging! Healthier option than ceramic or plastic.

reviewText: I use this large size bowl as a water dish for cats. They prefer a bowl large enough that their whiskers don't touch the side of the bowl.
So far the bowl has been very good for the four weeks I have owned it. I can see some wear and tear already started to take effect within the stainless steel, but other then that its awesome.

I got this bowl for our 25 lb corgi mix. It's perfect size and the rubber bottom helps to stop it from sliding all around the kitchen. Yes, it still does slice when our 100 lb mastiff cleans it up, but he'll move a brick wall with his head.
This bowl fits my dog's head since I call him moose head.  Nice and wide and doesn't slide around.  Heavy stainless good quality.

I bought similar bowls at Petco, and am now going to return them.  While the Petco ones have rubber all across the bottom (this one is a 3/4 inch ring around the edge), the Petco ones are slightly lighter weight, and more expensive.These are a good weight, and don't have that annoying fingernail-on-chalkboard sound that some lighter weight metal bowls make.  The rubber ring is rubbery, not plastic-y, so it does actually grip the floor.I am using this size (1.25 Qt) for water for my puppy and 2 cats.  I could've gotten a bigger one, but I find having large capacity water bowls means you don't end up refreshing their water as often.  Smaller bowl=more refills=fresher water=happier pets.
Great bowl but the sticker was difficult to remove and adhesive leaves residue. But other than that it is a decent bowl
Bought these for our 2 little dogs because we liked the 4.5qt versions.  Dishwasher safe and durable for both sizes.  Would buy these again.

Not much to review on a bowl. It arrived in good shape. The rubber keeps the bowl in place even w/ enthusiastic eaters. I have had another of these in a different size and the rubber is durable and we have not had a rust problem. I also have been washing this brand of bowl in the dishwasher for years and it holds up w/ NO problem. My dishwasher is set to wash at Heavy wash/extra hot wash/air dry. I have washed them on both the lower and upper rack. If you use your dry cycle you may want to only wash on upper rack. Made in India.Update 5/18/2013:  I still see NO signs of rust as mentioned in a few other reviews. Rubber still holding up great as well.

My borzoi puppy chews on this thing for hours and even sleeps with it.  Great way to get work done when I'm home watching the puppy.  The multicolored fur make it look realistic, but gets slightly gross and crusty with dog slobber. The toy has 6 squeakers -- four in the paws, one in the body and one in the head -- and has crinkly ears.  Very fun fun for the dog.

If your dog is a vigorous eater and pushes the bowl all over the place, then this is the bowl for them. They are virtually "no slide" bowls on floors or carpeting.  I wish I knew about them before I bought tons of other bowls.

This is the perfect size bowl for cats or small dogs. We use it for our cats' water, but it is also a good food bowl. I like that it is stainless steel; one of our cats was allergic to plastic and developed sores around his mouth, which cleared up after switching to this bowl. Stainless is healthier, and also rust-free. The non-slip bottom is also great so that the bowl does not move across the floor as a cat eats. Great price, too!
summary: Perfect food or water bowl for cats or small dogs

reviewText: As advertised, it's a big, stainless steel bowl with a nice grip on the bottom. I've had no problems so far. It's a great size for big dogs, and holds plenty of water/food. Stainless steel is always the way to go for pet bowls, and if you want to raise it up, I put mine on a box.

Seems to be as good as a dog bowl can get - stainless steel that doesn't look like it will rust, and the rubber ring around the bottom is a nice touch that keeps the bowl from sliding and making noise when the dogs play with their bowls.  The 2 quart is about an 8" diameter.
summary: Nice stainless finish with convenient rubber bottom

reviewText: Right out of the box this dog bowl was put to use. Heavy enough not to slide with the rubber bottom but light enough to use every day. Highly recommend.

I purchased this product several months ago to use outside for my dogs.  It has increasingly become more and more rusty where the water sits in it.  I rinse it out daily, but the rust still appears.  Also, the blue ring on the bottom leaves marks in my white sink when washing it out.  I do not recommend this product.
beautiful shiny stainless steel, tough and durable, heavy so they won't slide around on the floor, big enough that you don't have to refill the water bowl 10 times a day

Our dog's bowls are on a tile floor so the rubber on the bottom keeps the bowl secure and prevents it from slipping all over the place.  The bowl is sturdy and doesn't feel flimsy.  Unlike other reviewers I had no issues removing the sticker - you need to do it slowly and might have to try from a few of the corners but I managed to get it off with no residue.  Overall I am very happy with this bowl, and for the price is better than what you will find at a pet store!
