I got the 40 lb 'vault'. I was hoping that the screw top thing on the lid would help keep dry food fresh for longer, but unfortunately the screw top is sort of useless. You can't get a 1 lb scoop and your hand in through the screw thing so you have to open the actual lid, making the screw thing useless. The 'vault' closes super air tight, which would be great if you could use the screw top, but as you cannot, I just end up setting the lid on top of the 'vault', so the food stays fresh about as long as if I left it in the bag. The 'vault' is quite sturdy, but is easily knocked over by a persistant and large animal because the base is narrower than the top.
summary: sturdy but sort of a useless lid

reviewText: I own this item http://www.amazon.com/Vittles-Vault-30-30-Pound/dp/B0002DJONY/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid;=1290928919&sr;=8-6I decided to get a new one and with the ratings I figured it'd be just as good but $10.00 cheaper. I wish I would have just re ordered the same thing. Once the top is snapped in, it is locked, there is no way of getting it off unless you break it. Mine is not completely sealed. I don't have bug problems as other people have gotten this for that reason. I just like to order 30 pounds and know it'll stay fresh in the vault. This clearly doesn't hold 40 pounds of food. I would say MAYBE 33-35 pounds at the most. The screw on lid is also not good quality. Spend the extra 10.00 to get the better quality vault. I donated mine to a rescue shelter.
summary: Not near the quality of Vittles 30-Pound Vault

reviewText: I was looking for something tall and skinny about the size of our trash and recycle cans to fit in a small narrow space. This worked perfectly. We needed something to keep the food fresh since we started a different brand that is just cheaper to buy in the bigger bags. We use a 33 lb bag of the small bits of food and it fits fine with room to spare. I also love being able to tell from a distance how much is left. The only thing I wish it had was an option for a black top since all of our things in the kitchen are black and it would go with it a little better. But otherwise, I think its a good price, great size and would recommend it.

I bought this to keep my puppy's food in because we have had mice problems in the past. I keep the food in a closet and when I left it in the bag there would be holes in the bottom of the bag and pieces of food all over. Now that I have this, there has been no problems at all. It seals nicely and keeps the food fresher, which my puppy seems to enjoy. It also holds her entire bag of food with room to spare - 30 pound big bites. Definitely worth it.

This would have been a great container.  The spinning portion of the lid works great.  However, you are supposed to snap the lid onto the base to create a permanent seal.  Both my husband and I could not get it to snap.  I also tried calling the company to see if they could send me a replacement lid, but they never returned my call.

I love this container. It first all of the dog food in there and a scoop for the food.Its good quality, easy to use and a good design.I really advice this container for dog food or any type of food (birds, horses, cats, etc.)

Works fine. However the seals do come off once in a while when taking off the lid. Also quality control could be better- on the interior there are some rough sharp plastic edges. The seals always fall off especially the long thin ring that goes around the circle lid. It does what it is supposed to do. My regret would be that Menards, (probably Home Depot or Lowes too) sells food grade buckets with gamma seal lids. In total you can get those for $10 or less. Much less than what these sell for. Also those are buckets- very tough in comparison to this container and no quality control issues.

I purchased this product last year ($20) and its great...wanted to buy another for cat food and its gone up $13 plus.  I found it at another website for $18...will not pay $33 for a plastic container...NOPE!
summary: Like the product but the price is much higher on Amazon

reviewText: I've been reading a lot about pet foods lately.  We fed our kitten, Leo, Science Diet kitten food for the first year of his life.  It was a fine food.Then I started reading about the process of making pet food and became concerned about feeding him "meat byproduct" and corn, which is an allergen to many pets.  I wanted to find the best food I could to make sure he stayed happy and healthy for many years to come.So, at the one year point, we decided to give Blue Buffalo a try.  Leo loves it and we are happy knowing that our baby is eating real food and just the castoffs and junk from real food.

We've been feeding this food for several months now and have had good luck so far.  We switched from Core food due to the dietary needs of one of our cats.  We are currently serving Blue Buffalo dry food in conjunction with Weruva canned foods.None of the cats have suffered any ill effects from the change to this food; coats are healthy, energy levels are high, they are eager to eat, and we've had no problems in the litter box.This seems to be an honest and dedicated company, and our experiences with their representatives thus far have been very positive.We're glad that we found Blue Buffalo cat food!

We have two cats--one is overweight, and the other is elderly and underweight due to hyperthyroidism.  We decided to stop feeding them the cheaper, name-brand stuff which they loved to eat (Meow Mix) and switch to Blue Buffalo.  They don't like the flavor quite as much, but they did accept the change over without as much fuss as some other brands we've tried.  The vomiting has slowed down for our older, sick cat, which is great, and she has started to pick up some weight because the vomiting has decreased.  The fat cat is still fat.

I mainly feed my cat canned food because it's generally healthier than dry, but I give him a small scoop of dry food when his wet food has spoiled and he's whining for a midnight snack or something. They gave us a bag of Science Diet with him at the shelter, which is just filled with terrible stuff (although the cat loved that too, lol) but I wanted another dry food as a supplement, but one that was healthy. Blue Buffalo is very healthy and my cat LOVES it. I still prefer to feed him the canned food, but a scoop of this is great. I foolishly tried a different type canned food one day, and although that was healthy stuff too, his stomach hadn't adjusted to it and he was meowing at me for hours in the morning in misery before I realized the problem (he had diarrhea--luckily he's litterbox trained). I gave him a small cup of dry Blue Buffalo and he ate it right up. It really settled his stomach, and no more problems since then. This really is great, healthy stuff.

reviewerName: N. Ferguson "Two, Daisy, Hannah, and Kitten"
reviewText: Blue Buffalo Spa Select is great! Top of the line ingredients, human food grade-- in addition to the indoor cat formula there's a chicken version and a fish version. This food meets a very high standard. No yucky meat "by-products", meat and meat meals are the top ingredients, plus a host of wholesome and varied ingredients and probiotics.On top of that, this is an incredibly palatable food. My cat LOVES it. In fact, she scarfs it right down, when she typically has just grazed on a piece or two at a time of other premium foods. I have to be careful to use a measuring cup and not overfeed her, 'cause she will seek me out and meow for more!Blue Buffalo uses a unique process to manufacture "lifebits" which are added to the food. These smaller, darker pieces are cold formed in order to maintain nutrients. I don't believe any other company incorporates this kind of element into cat or dog food.I came across this cat food at the local Tractor Supply. I'd never heard or read about Blue Buffalo, but I respect what they are doing, and I've changed to Blue Buffalo dog food for my golden retrievers, too.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Here's a summary of the nutritional information:-Recommended daily feeding chart-- amount varies based on age, activity level, breed, and environement, but in general a 5-9 pound cat will eat 1/4-1/2 cup, while a 10-14 pound cat will eat 1/2-1 cup.-One cup contains 478 calories-Major ingredients:Deboned chicken, chicken meal, whole ground barley, fish meal, oatmeal, whole ground brown rice, whole potatoes, chicken fat (preserved with natural mixed tocopherols), natural chicken flavor, dried egg, dried cellulose, whole sweet potatoes, whole carrots, cranberries, blueberries, flaxseed (natural soource of Omega 6 fatty acids), barley grass, dried parsley, alfalfa meal, kelp meal, taurine, l-carnitine, l-lysine, ycca schidigera, green tea extract, turmeric, salmon oil (natural source of Omega 3 fatty acids), black malted barley, dried chicory root, fructooligosaccarides, oil of rosemary, the expected vitamins and minerals, and several probiotics (lactobacillus acidolphilus, bacillus subtilis, bifidobacgterium thermophilum, bifidobacgterium longum, enterococcus faecium).I hope this helps you evaluate whether or not this food is a good match for your feline friend. My cat and I have been really happy with it.
summary: a great premium food-- human grade ingredients, thoughtfully chosen, with unique manufacturing process

reviewText: I had to go from regular cat food to the diet kind (kitty is getting pudgy), and there has been no change in her eating habits.  Great cat food, that is also healthy.  The only downside is it is very expensive online when they do not offer free shipping, so keep your eyes open for the free shipping deals.  :)
Cats absolutely love this food. We have three cats and they all run for the bowls at supper time.  I gave it only four stars as for at least one cat, a sensitive stomach food may still be necessary.

I've been looking for a natural cat food for my cat that has developed a pretty bad case of cat acne and I had heard good things about this brand of cat food, so I thought I would check it out.  However, when I looked at the ingredients, I was very surprised to see cranberries, blueberries, apples, blackberries, pomegranates, and carrots listed, since all of these things are toxic to cats.  I realize that there are probably only small amounts in this food, but I still think that it seems foolish to put toxic ingredients in the food, especially if your cat will be eating it every day like mine will.  I'm not risking his health and I wanted to let others who might not know that these ingredients are toxic, know.

Our cat is obsessed with food. The fatter she gets, the more she wants to eat (sounds a lot like humans too). I put her on this food hoping she would lose weight and she HAS. It's a miracle. I tried a lot of things before this but nothing worked. I was also looking for cat food made by a company that cares about animals and has no animal parts mixed into the food (do your research; most cheaply made cat foods contain euthanized CATS and DOGS! Pretty despicable and unbelievable, right? Sadly, it's true). This is healthy great stuff and slowly but surely her swinging gut is going away. Nice job, Blue Buffalo!

I bought this food when it became obvious that my cat needed to lose weight.  I did quite a lot of research on cat food and what cats need to lose weight and Blue Buffalo was the best choice that I could find.  The expense is well worth it.  My cat loved this food and showed definite signs of improvement with his weight.  The only negative is that there are darker bits mixed in with the food that are supposed to be extra nutrients and my cat did not like those for whatever reason, but he is a picky eater!

I really can't give enough praise to this food! My 3 year old calico, Luna, was slowly becoming one overweight kitty. I didn't free feed her, so I didn't know what I was doing wrong. I had always fed her Purina (my old vet assured me that this food was just as good as the more expensive brands--wrong)! After doing some of my own research and comparing ingredients, I decided to give Blue Buffalo Weight Control a shot. Luna LOVES it! I feed her 1/2 a cup a day and break it up into 3 or 4 small meals. When I took her to the vet yesterday, I found out she has lost a pound since her last visit! She's only been eating this food for a few months, so I assume she'll keep losing. I'm a happy kitty-mama; thanks Blue.
summary: Giving praise where praise is due...

reviewText: WHOA! My cat turned her nose up at this in the beginning. Now, 2 months later she can't get enough! People who commented on this suggested this would happen and they were right! I totally take back what I said about this at first. I almost want to eat some of it myself!But I won't...

My cats aren't picky in the least. But every time I get a new bag of this food one attempts to tear it open and eat it right away! You'd think she was starving. It's good for them and last a fair while. Love it.

When my kitten was about six months old, I switched her to Blue Buffalo Spa Select Weight Control dry food, chicken and brown rice. She's been to the vet twice since then for shots and check ups and her weight is just over 7 pounds, which the vet said is ideal for her. I had been told when I first took her in that she would be prone to gaining weight because she's a calico. Well, I am lucky because she's not a big eater, first of all and secondly, she loves the weight control food. I'm sold on Blue Buffalo products and so is my cat!

I used this for my 15yr old lab Bailey who has since left me sadly in October of 2011.  This was the best thing I came across to use for his little drip issue we were having. I just remodeled and I wanted to be comfortable and I wanted him to be comfortable as well.  Bailey knew he had an issue as he tried constantly to clean up after himself, I started using this and he was so much happier!  Now a few pointers!!I used Poise Ultra Absorbent people pads inside and they were fantastic VS the Simple Solutions pads which sadly were terrible and a total waste of money. Simple Solution pads are just over priced expensive Kotex pads that could not handle the amount of urine that can occur unlike the Poise pads, remember this is what Poise pads are used for. You should get the ones that fit how much you dog drips so it may take some experimenting my dog was large so mine were the most absorbent I could get. Great thing is you can get them in-store and on sale almost anywhere!I bought baby wipes to wipe him down and keep him clean, remember it is the same concept as a baby wearing a diaper and sitting in it, I didn't want to risk any infection. No alcohol!Make sure you measure your dog, to tight can cause a lot of chafing!! Mine was the right size but I ended up sewing micro-fiber cloth on the elastic part where the material scrunched up as this was causing chafing behind his manly area. He was not use to anything rubbing his skin in that area and the material is pretty stiff. I had to leave it off till it healed and sadly I never had the chance to see if the microfiber would have relieved the problem. Make sure you check your dog to make sure this is not occurring due to some dogs have a higher tolerance to pain. It would be great if they could use a softer material in the elastic area. I wish they were a tad cheaper in price, I did purchase one at Petsmart and the other on Ebay for a fraction of the cost, if you don't mind used(they are washed!!) it's a deal!  I would recommend but def do some shopping as they are not cheap!
summary: Male Wrap is Great-Liner Pad is Not

reviewText: These might be okay for some dogs, but for mine it was a disaster. She is an older dog who can no longer make it through the day without going to the bathroom,  so we've tried a few different methods: wee wee pads, these diapers and diaposable diapers.  These diapers do not hold much.  My dog would poop and it would fall of the diaper liner pad and end up in the mesh of the reusable cover. An utter mess to say the least! We usually ended up with poop or pee everywhere, so we went back to the disposables which fit better and held a lot more.

The simple solution liner is actually a very good product, for a medium sized (35-50 lbs) bitch in heat, so I have to give it 5 stars.These are actually old school pads - very simple.  They have soft cover, and old school thick absorbent filling, which seems to stay close to the skin and prevent leaking. So this pad seems appropriate and comfortable for my dog.Because of the price I think other things could be used instead of this pad.  However, those who compare this to "always" or majority of other feminine products are a little wrong.  "Always" are too advanced to compare to this dog  pad.  I bought "always" instead of buing these simple solution liners the second time for economic reasons; I couldn't find anything "simpler" .  "Always" (maxi, no wings type) have dry weave and and leak guards and are a little longer which is not what I was looking for.  Well anyway, for now I'll buy "always" because the package of 48 pads at $7.50, beats a package of 10 at 6.99 any day, which is funny considering "always" is more technologically advanced than simple solution disposable liners.  So even though it's a 5-star pad for a midium sized bitch, I say spend 17c/pad instead of 70c/pad, and don't panic when you have to use few per day.
summary: great for medium sized bitches in heat

reviewText: To be honest I have not bought these but who in there right mind would? 10 pack for $6-7? I don't think so! My puppy came into heat, I bought the washable covers that the liners go in. Then I purchased store brand panty liners. They work great and I paid $2 for 70+ liners.  The great thing about buying Panty pads/liners instead of these is that you can buy higher absorbency Ones, So if you're using it for urine accidents it won't be as messy. Simple solution you have a great concept but way overpriced.

I have to rate this HIGHLY since it is simply the "Always" panty liners for women, they just put a DOG on the front and called them Diaper Liners.  There is one BIG difference here, it's MONEY.  You can save yourself half by purchasing "Always" instead of the Dog Diaper Liners. Because you are buying a specialty item (and most pet products cost more) you will pay more.  So the choice is yours, Pay $7.00 for "Always" or $14.00 for "Dog Diaper Liner" since the only difference is the price.
I have a very large dog she is not to old but she has a leaky problem.  these simple solutions worked great for her.thanks
I have to agree with the majority of the reviewers. These things are so small... I had to use two of them. Looking for alternatives now.

An absolutely wonderful harness. I've been using harnesses for years and with one I noticed my dog pulled less than half as hard right from the start. I was so impressed I bought 2 more for my other 2 kids. There's something about that front hook-up with Easy Walk harnesses that gets a dog's attention right off.(Amended 12/24/2011)These harnesses continue to amaze me. Years of being dragged along by Louisiana Catahoula Leopards can be tough. Not anymore.
summary: Absolutely Wonderful: You Need To Buy This To Save Yourself

reviewText: Been struggling with dog for over a year.  Collie thought she was a husky sled dog.  Simply wouldn't stop pulling.  Tried all the internet techniques, Cesar's (Milan) techniques, nothing worked - until this harness.  It's like magic.  She's never even tried to pull, not even once, since wearing the harness.  She's happier, I'm happier.  Easier on her neck too.  This harness is totally humane - nothing hurts the dog whatsoever.  It's simply that the pull-point is moved to her chest.  She's naturally redirected to heel.Bought at least a size too big.  Don't recall a chest to size conversion.  Figure too big is better than too small?  Should'a returned for smaller, but ended up sewing it smaller instead.  Easier than returning.I highly recommend this harness.

Bought this harness a few months ago for our Lab puppy who is now 7 months old. She loves to pull while on walks, but with this harness it reduces the pulling by 90-95%. It is amazing in regards to that. The only bad thing about it is it chafes her armpits and is causing her to lose her hair and get a pretty nasty rash/scab on the one armpit where the buckle is. We have it fitted correctly, but we can't use it everyday or her one armpit start bleeding.
summary: Stops dog from pulling, but a few problems

reviewText: encourages good leash behavior. is comfortable for my dog to keep on when i take him off leash in the park. well made.

For my Lab mix anyway, this didn't do what I had hoped. She tended to fuss and fight with her gentle leader and never really did "get used to it." So I spent the money on an easy walker. First of all, she escaped. Horrifying enough on it's on, but she is Houdini in disguise I think. Our trainer suggested hooking it to her collar as well. Okay, fine. Did that.It made no difference in her behavior what so ever. I was pretty bummed out.NOW, with that said, this particular harness works well for our Coonhound. She is a puller (forward, where as my Lab tends to pull up, down, left, right, where ever) and this stops some of that. It doesn't work magic with her like in the commercials. I firmly believe most dogs need consistent work and training to get to that point. If you're one of the lucky few that experienced magic results with this harness then that's wonderful!! I just wasn't one of them.
summary: Wasn't what I had hoped for.

reviewText: Good quality material but it rubbed the fur on my dog's chest and belly, so one star taken away for that. Also, despite very closely following the fitting guide, this does not fit my dog well. It is too small in some areas and too large in others. It also doesn't stop him from pulling that well. We will need to find another harness.
summary: Rubbed fur almost matted and didn't fit well

reviewText: Good quality product, but could not get it to fit my dog as instructions directed.  The next larger size would have been way too big for my Lab.

Great harness, but now owned by a company that promotes and sells shock collars which need to be banned. If you have a pulling dog, google how to fit this harness. There are videos, and it's important to the effectiveness of the harness. Once properly fitted, it works like a champ! If your dog is shallow chested, you might need a carabiner clip to affix the front ring to the collar to ensure it doesn't drop too low and catch the shoulder.

Great product, and I wanted to exchange for a larger size, but unfortunately I was not offered that option.My dogs (Bernese Mountain Dogs) have very deep chests and I thought I measured correctly, but apparently I didn't :)Super product though!
summary: Awesome - unfortunately didn't fit my girls

reviewText: I am so impressed with this harness. It's super adjustable so you get a good fit (although I've found that I have to attach the leash to the two adjusting rings rather than the leash attachement ring). When the dog pulls, it actually turns them around to face you, allowing you to get control of them very quickly. My dog doesn't pull at all anymore. I like this much better than other harnesses that seem to reinforce pulling.
I bought these for my Labs.  Labs can be very stubborn and are always testing their boundaries.  These harness's allow my wife to walk them with out concern that she will be pulled down.
I bought this a month ago and it broke already and I cannot get my money back. It's junk!! Don't buy it!

I cant believe how effective this is. My dog CANT pull....and when we run into other dogs, if she tries pulling, the harness makes her flip or do some sort of twirl. It's so funny. My arm doesnt hurt anymore from all the pulling :) and her neck doesnt suffer anymore as well!  GREAT purchase!
I found this complicated.  I couldn't figure out how to put it on my pup.  I was looking for something that didn't require more than one snap.

I got this for my American Stafforshire that weighs 75 lbs.  It is a great no pull harness, however, it isn't meant for barrel chested dogs. It didn't fit him good through the chest area.  as tight as we could get it, it still slipped down.  The harness itself is a great concept, but just not meant for all dogs.
summary: Good harness, but not meant for all breeds of dogs

reviewText: I had a hard time adjusting it to fit my golden retriever at first. Once the size was right he responded well as a pup. Now that he's larger its a little harder and he has done most of his training with a chocker so I rarely use this. It definitely allows you to force him to pay attention to you and pulls his chest toward you, but I feel like it confuses him and almost trips him up when pulling him back.  I can't control him as well as with the chocker. Maybe if he was trained on this only it would be a better tool.

I had initially bought the medium size and found it way too big for my beagle mix puppy even though her weight range was in the "medium dog" size.  I had completely tightened everywhere I could and it hung off of her.  My husband was supposed to return it but never did so I ordered the "small" figuring we'd have better results.The size discrepancy between the two sizes was ridiculous!  The small was so tiny even fully extended for it's full size that it wouldn't even go half way around her chest area.  We still had the medium to compare it too.  As it had been awhile since we bought the medium and she had grown a bit more we tried it on our dog again and although still big it wasn't as loose as it had been but it still did not fit tightly as the instructions told you to adjust it.  It was quite loose around both her back and around the front and the only part that we could adjust it enough so it was fitted right was around her belly area.  I ended up gathering up some of it across her back and sewing a few stitches in it to get it to be as snug as the directions indicated.Although the front was still a bit loose we decided to give it a try and took her out for her walk. Seemed to make the walks much better as she was still pulling but not as much as she had been and the walks were much easier with her being much easier to control.  So that was a few days ago. Went to put the harness on her today and noticed that the part of the harness where you attach the leash the material there had split halfway through and if I hadn't noticed it I'm sure it would have ripped the rest of the way and my puppy would have been loose. Glad I noticed because we not only live on a busy street we live in a heavily wooded area with a marsh in the back and lots of coyotes and we never want her to be off her leash for fear she could get hit by a car or disappear into the woods.So definitely a one star for me, product does seem to work but the discrepancy from the small to medium makes it impossible to find a size that will fit properly and the fact that it was in danger of breaking all the way through after just a few outings is really bad.  I did sew up the tear and will continue to use it but will be checking it constantly to make sure it hasn't started to rip through again.
summary: Problems with sizing and broke after a few uses.

reviewText: I have a 1 year old American Staffordshire Terrier(aka pitbull) and she is probably just about 60lbs of pure energy and muscle. I had the gentle leader before and it worked great but I was tired of people thinking my dog had a muzzle on. Another issue with the gentle leader is Tasha would try to rub it off her nose and it was frustrating when I would walk her and she would roll on her back on a patch of grass to try to rub it off her nose. So I found this and decided to give it a try. I bought the large but Tasha was just below the size but I knew she is still young so she would grow into it. I have it adjusted to the smallest and it is a bit big for her but it still works fine and there is no way she can slip out of it. I feel I have a bit more control with the gentle leader since it controls their head but I have not used it since I receive the easy walk.
summary: Makes walking my Am Staff much easier!

reviewText: I have a 70lb dog that loves to pull on the leash.  I've tried just about every no pull device out there.  This works better than anything else I've tried.  It does discourage him from pulling when fitted properly.  The problem is when he pulls the straps loosen.  Once the straps are too loose it stops being effective.  I have to readjust the straps frequently in order to keep it fitting him properly and thus working.  It is a great product but the design could use some work.  I have a friend who has also used this harness, and has had the same problem.  She stopped using it because her dog figured out how to get out of the harness once the straps were loosened.  All in all, I think this harness is worth the money as it does work, you just have to watch the straps and adjust regularly.
summary: Works but could be designed better

reviewText: I have an 11 month old, 55lb mixed breed dog and he is learning to go on walks. He needs a little help to stay with me and I feel very uncomfortable using a head-leader. Just something about wrapping material around my dog's head doesn't sit right with me. It's far too easy for him to pull with his regular harness so I gave this a try - and WOW! It's helped tremendously! The very first time we went on a walk with this new harness, my dog stuck right by my side. Any time he tried to pull forward, away from me, he ended up turning awkwardly and having to wait. This is an excellent harness for walks!

I have an English Springer Spaniel pup, 6 months old, who always pulls on her leash.  I was getting so frustrated, even with obedience training.  Because of all the good reviews on the Premier Easy Walk, I purchased this.  I tried it for a week -- she would still try to pull, she flipped over once, and I was afraid of her leg being hurt. I was ready to pay $400 for a personal trainer just to teach my dog leash walking. My pup pulled no matter what.  I finally mentioned my concern to my instructor, and she suggested the pincher collar.  I first tried this on myself, and it didn't hurt -- just a sensation.  The minute I put this on my pup, she started walking great -- she still "tries" to pull every once in a while, but the walks are so much more pleasant now.  Lesson is -- each dog is different, and you have to keep trying until you have found the right item.

I have an oddly shaped boston-terrier lab mix who pulls like a maniac. I struggled to make sure it fit her properly and it still didn't really help her to stop pulling. So I tried it on our lab mix puppy and it worked well for her and got her to stop pulling.
summary: some dogs aren't built for it

reviewText: I have a very excitable golden retriever and my 11yr old dog no longer drag me literally on our walks. it took a few times for him to get used to but now he realizes it's a good thing to take it slower for both of us. They will find themselves stumbling along to try and get beyond the limitations of this yoke. it is NOT a harsh restraint and THAT I love and appreciate the most about it along with the price
summary: Oh boy no more dragging me

reviewText: I have to admit the easy walk does make walking our Alaskan Klee Kai a lot easier. Being from the husky family she wants to pull us as we're walking but with the easy walk it doesn't allow her to run fast or get ahead of us. We only used the harness for 6 days 2-3 times a day and it already broke. She chewed the harness in the front near the loop probably as she was waiting for us to get ready to leave the door. We went on a hike yesterday and noticed in the car that it was ripped all the way to the edge. Good thing we saw or else she would have came lose on the hike. This is cheaply made and should be made from a strong nylon and thicker straps. Highly disappointed but the only reason why I'm giving 3 stars is because it helped our dog not pull on our walk.
summary: Dog didn't pull anymore but broke within a week of use

reviewText: I have used this harness and the Sporn no pull harness and I prefer the Easy Walker.Pros: This harness is easy to put on and take off, its comfortable for the dog and it works right away. I do believe something about a regular collar just makes some dogs want to pull more. This harness eliminates that in a gentle way. Make sure you get a regular leash for the harness (not extendable) with a light clip because a heavy one will drag down the all important front strap which needs to be tight across the chest. Otherwise when it hangs it jerks with each dog step. The harness has wide, sturdy straps. My dogs a chewer but the Easy Walker is snug and out of reach and he hasn't touched it after several weeks (he destroyed the slim Sporn harness day two and another dog chewed it clear through in a second while playing, but after it hauled on the Easy Walker it showed no damage).Cons: Sizing is hard to go by. My pyrenees/collie mix has a 30" girth so I got the large harness and the chest strap is too loose no matter how I finagle all the straps. I ordered the medium and its too small. Then I come to find out on the box there's a medium/large size. I wish I'd known that. The strap adjustments tend to slip, but once I found a happy adjustment I eventually duct taped the buckles to deter slippage. Because you hook the leash up front at the chest, when the dog switches sides of the road/path, you have to swing the leash around the front of the head to clear it from being wrapped round the neck. Not a huge bother, but something to think about dealing with if you prefer a leash not semi wrapped around the neck and not making full use of the no pull effect.Overall I like the Easy Walker no pull harness. Its inexpensive, comfortable like a regular collar for the dog (though I take it off at night) and well worth the price for dissuading annoying pulling. Sometimes I go back to just a collar and the dog goes right back to pulling  so I'm reminded the harness works. My dog and I are both happy with the Easy Walker!
I like using this harness when working with untrained dogs,  It is gentle and makes it a  lot easirer with unruley dogs
summary: Good on hard to lead dogs

reviewText: I love this harness. I have two dogs to walk and before I purchased this harness I would dread the dog walking. My youngest dog is a puller. She can't wait to get on with the walk and so would pull me like she was a dog pulling a sled, nearly pulling my arm out of its socket. Not to mention the other hazards that could result from this type of behavior. More than once I was literally pulled to the ground and I knew something had to be done. Walking one dog at a time was not an option because the dog left behind would be in quite a state when I returned and I have had to replace the shades on the window because of the dog trying to get out while I was gone with the other dog. When I received this harness I thought, hopefully this one will work. I have tried other harnesses that only seemed to increase the pulling. When we got outside on our first walk with the Easy Walk Harness I realized that a miracle had taken place. No pulling, both of my arms can hang comfortably by my side now and I can walk both dogs at the same time and usually without incident. Of course that is not counting when the dogs see a cat but even then it is much easier to bring them under control. I recommend that you make sure to get the right fit but other than that this is the best product I have found to prevent pulling. I have nothing negative to say about this product.
I noticed a change the first day and I'm a lazy trainer (good enough is good enough for me), if you actually spend some time training loose leash this harness should help a lot.

I now have 2 of these and absolutely love them. They really do make a difference when walking the dogs. I altered this a little by wrapping fleece three times around the gray band (that goes under the front legs) because one of my dogs gets chafed and blistered so badly by the band itself.I have an (overweight) 69 lbs. lab-min aus shep mix and a border collie beagle mix ~30-40lbs. They both walk so much nicer on these and the first day we used it I saw an amazing improvement. Try not to constantly tug or pull on the leash, so they know what it should feel like to walk "loose" leash.While my dogs still sometimes pull every now and then to get something they see- this is still much better than the pinch collar which provoked aggression in one of my dogs when people or other dogs were around.

I ordered this according to how it was supposed to be sized.  I have a large female Doberman and this fell off her and tripped her.  I was very disappointed in it.  The way it was shaped I didn't think another size would be any better for her because of her chest.  It fell wrong on her.  I was looking for something to replace the gentle leader.  That works but she hates it.  She spends half the walk trying to get it off.

I ordered this because my puppy still pulls a bit and have been a bit lazy working with him. Before  I tried this harness I was using a choke chain.  He learned to pull with the choke chain and I always felt like I was hurting him.  Switching the choke for the harness, I found that he doesn't pull as much.  There are the moments when he wants to go rabbit chasing, but he is easy enough to control with the harness on.  I use this along with a double leash (so I can walk both dogs at once), so may not work as well if it was just a single dog.  There were a couple of times that I made a turn and he fell, (I think from turning so abruptly), but no harm.  I think that even after I work with him to be leashed trained, I'll still use the harness.
summary: stops a bit of the pulling

reviewText: I purchased the Premier Easy Walk Pet Harness on the recommendation of my dog trainer.  It was potentially the best purchase I have made for my puppy.  You simply slip the unit over the dog's head, and buckle the strap under the body, and clip the lead to the front of the unit where the clip is. It took my wife a few tries to get it on the right way (the dog won't really want to walk if you have it on upside down or backwards, that's your indication it's on incorrect).You may get a few licks putting it on, but it is much better than the common harness straps.  In terms of walking, it prevents the dog from pulling, and forces the dog to stop pulling. If you tug the lead the dog is gently tugged to the side rather than pulling her front legs up into the air.  My dog is also a lot less prone to jumping on people when she has this harness on.One note, this is actually my second Easy Walk Pet Harness, the first version our puppy chewed threw when I forgot she had it on after a walk.  Since it sits around the front of the chest, she was laying down and was able to get her mouth under it and being a puppy chewed it right up.  My mistake, but it is always recommended to take the harness off when your dog is unsupervised.
summary: A World of Difference in Preventing Pulling!

reviewText: It rubs my dog a, pitbul, raw right behind her front legs. I bought it so it would take the stress off her neck but im going back to a collar this time at least 1.5inches to distribute the pressure off her neck.

I trust Premier pet products so I wasn't doubt about functionality. Sure enough, this simple harness that goes around the chest area in unique way, prevents and discourages dog to pull. I have a Black Lab who was beyond being rambunctious when she was between puppy to about 2 years old, and there are many occasions that she pulled me unexpectedly very hard, which resulted me to not be able to keep the leash and let go, and there she goes free! I tried to train her but squeals are too tempting to my dog... After I started to use this harness on her, I'm happy to say she won't be able to do that anymore. I believe it'll make her feel uncomfortable when she try to pull, so it took only couple occasions of pulling for her to know that she won't be able to pull anymore. After she became 2 years old and started to calm down a bit, I switched regular chest harness, but she still thinks she won't be able to pull like crazy anymore. Totally recommended!
summary: It works effectively to discourage the pulling!

reviewText: It was a little big for my dog but I bought it before I got the dog so that's bad on me...I was past the the refund deadline so I just grabbed some string and needle and stitched parts of the harness to tighten it up.

I use to have the old Easy Walk Harness but the new one is much nicer. The different color under body strap makes it much easier to get on. Also just like the old one it helps keep the dog from pulling as much. Don't think that this is going to stop a dog from pulling but it makes it easier to minimize the strain from pulling. When my dog would try lunging or running after something it pulls him around so he is facing me. The best part is there is very little jolting from the lunge. After a few times he started learning he was not going to get anywhere any quicker by lunging or pulling. By the end of our first walk he was walking by my side 85% of the time. Yeah he would try pulling or chasing a animal every now and then but quickly changed his mind and even saw a rabbit with out trying to make a charge for it. I only have two draw backs with this harness. First the bottom clip sits slightly under his front leg. Most of this is because my dog is between two sizes so I went with the larger one because he is still growing. If you have a dog that is done growing and you are between sizes go with the smaller size. The second issue is if your dog is determined to get out if the harness they can back out of it. Mine did this by accident easy fix is to clip the leash to there collar and the harness. It still works and also helps keep the harness on straight if they pull to the side. Over all this is a great product I would highly recommend.

I wanted the Black and Silver, but i ended up getting a black and blue, and I thought this would be the regular nylon one but nope. I got an ECO friendly one which didnt seem that sturdy and make noses when my dog walks around in it. But I contacted the seller and got a full refund.

I was initially skeptical of this product since I had tried several other harnesses for my 75-pound Shepard/lab mix, all with mixed results at best. My boy doesn't mind wearing this and, unless confronted by a rabbit bounding across our path, he walks calmly and respectfully, he even appears to appreciate the gentle tug now and then. I gave it 4 instead of 5 only because it takes a bit of finagling to adjust it well, but after that it's great.

Love this harness! Ever since I got it I have not gone back to the traditional collar. It was like night and day- huge difference in the pulling. My dog (a Samoyed) can still pull, but it's a lot more controllable and not as bad.

Love this harness.  I do not walk my dogs at night, so I cannot speak to the reflector as aspect (but I would get a vest for night walking).  It is a sturdy harness and I get no pulling from my 48lbs, 6 month old pup.  Would purchase it again!

Makes walking easy, controlling our very strong and emotional 65 lb. Aussie Dingo mix, Rusty, without struggle, strong words, or injury to his trachea (I refuse to use choke chains for that reason). The harness has lasted us for years with little sign of wear.The only negative, a small one, is that he resists it being put on...he'd rather be more free to sniff and scavenge. What Rusty doesn't know is that we walk him more often and much further every day because of this harness. Better for us and better for him! He does seem to like the harness better than the almost as effective Halti.Rusty is very resistant to leash training. In other respects, he's been easy to train. He brings in the daily newspaper, has quickly learned dozens of tricks, and is generally very smart, loving and cooperative. There may be a breed specific thing about leash training. We've not had this hard a time leash training most of our past dogs.

My dogs are both rescues who came from icky situations.  One was. A. Puppy mill dog who spent 9 years of her life having puppies, and the other spent 5 years of his life being passed from house to house and kennel to kennel, he spent much of his life in cages.  Teaching them to be dogs was actually challenging.  They both love to walk, but when they walk together they pull in order to be first.  We tried the back clasp harnesses, we tried individual walks and training sessions, but they just get so excited to go out for walks they pull like crazy as if there is a finish line.  I got the front easy walk harness for Jack first, it was like night and day, he walked next to me, no pulling, no straying off the path he just walked.  When he walked well Pepper had no desire to pull ahead.  The only draw back I had for these is that if we take these onto the hiking trails jack is no as agile.  The harness does restrict some leg movement.  That is in a sense what makes it wor k so well.  On hilly terrain this is a bad idea, so for rugged trails we go back to the buckles on the back harness.
summary: Love it, but can't use it on some rigorous trails

reviewText: My dogs are not particularly thrilled when I put on these harnesses but the harnesses do indeed prevent tugging. Now on walks I have two well behaved dogs at my side or behind me. I am very pleased with the results.But honestly, my dogs practically run away from me when I pull out the harnesses. My thought is that they are not the most comfortable. I bought large, but had to adjust it significantly to fit my dogs (each 75lb) - to the point where I wonder if I could have used a medium. As far as I can tell, no bruises or scratches, just awkward for them to wear and they don't like it.
summary: Perhaps not the most comfortable but hinders tugging

reviewText: My lab pup has grown out of the medium one she had so we got the bigger large for her.  Still love it.  It wasn't black and silver though, it was blue and black, which is no big deal but the order did say black and silver.  It's also made of a different fabric than the old one but it holds up so I'm happy.
summary: Already had one, just got a bigger size

reviewText: Our dog just chewed through this last night.  We bought the correct size and not one just below it.  Our dog was 2 inches into the next highest size, large, and it was way too big.  On the tightest settings he was able to bend is head down and bite the front part of this.  He chewed half way through it last night.  It's definitely not Kong-like.  No effort at all, took about 10 secs to get through it.  If you are on the low side of the size, buy the next lowest size.Positives: Dog hated the harness but stopped pulling as muchCons: Cheaply made.  If you buy a size that's too large, the front loops? don't hold tight so they come loose after one walk.  I'm trying Caesar's collar next...Update: Caesar's collar, the Illusion Collar, is a POS!  I'll review that later. I'm going back to this harness, although it seems cheaply made.  It did do the best job with stopping the dog from pulling.

Product seems very well made,  but it did not work for my dog. He is super strong, pulls like crazy when he sees a squirrel, and it didn't deter him one bit.  It actually seemed to encourage him to pull, because there was nothing around his neck.  He pulls so hard that the harness loosens as we walk,  and droops in the front,  becoming so loose he might actually slip out of it if he wanted to.  Plus,  when it's loose,  his legs hit the front strap on each stride,  making it loosen even more!  And then, the attached leash clip bangs him in the leg,  annoying him and making him pull away.He's fresh from the shelter and still getting used to us,  and learning how to walk,  so I wouldn't absolutely condemn this product for others.  It seems like a great idea, in theory - the D ring is attached to a loop of fabric on the front,  which tightens when you pull it, compressing the entire harness.  It might be the way he is built, with kind of a thick barrel chest and strong neck.  Just know if you have a really big strong willful puller, it might not work for you.  I'm going back to chokechain/slip leash for now.
summary: Disappointing, but it didn't work for me.

reviewText: Pulling can be a real issue with some dogs and I have an arsenal of alternative devices to deter this behavior. I really like this harness because it essentially turns the dog back into you if it hits resistance and it is my current go-to for walks. I did read in the manual that the effectiveness can diminish in time if you do not follow through with additional training to prevent pulling in conjunction with the harness but I haven't done anything differently and I have still seen a sustained difference. It is kind of confusing to put on so you will want to keep that manual around for a little while to use as reference while you are getting the hang of it. My only issue is that since the loop is on the front of the dog, on the chest, it is a little difficult to use with my preferred leash which has one short loop right at the clip. It creates kind of an awkward length to keep the dog right by your side so that takes a little adjustment.

Sturdy, well constructed and easy to clean.A must have for large breed puppies who do not want to walk on collar and lead alone.My German Shepard puppy (4 months old) would not cooperate with just a collar but became instantly compliant with the harness.Best purchase I have made for training him (except treats)!

The directions  on how to size it were easy to follow.  The price was $10.00 less than every place in town.  I can walk my 70 pound goldendoodle in this harness with one arm and hold my tiny chihuahua in my other arm without worrying about losing control of the goldendoodle. Works great.

The Easy Walk dog harnesses were recommended to us by an animal behaviorist after we experienced problems with our two adult Bullmastiffs getting out of control on walks. The behaviorist explained that the regular harnesses that we had been using require the leash to be attached over the dogs back, which actually encourages dogs to pull.  And we already knew that regular neck collars caused our dogs to pull.  The Easy Walk harnesses were great, giving us complete control over our dogs on walks, which is extremely important when you are the owner of a big scary looking dog!  Owners of smaller breed dogs and the "cuter" breeds like labs and goldens, expect Bullmastiff and other scary breed owners to be in complete control of their dogs, even when their own "cute" dogs are completely out of control!Last summer we got a new Bullmastiff puppy, and needless to say, she has been wearing an easy walk harness on walks from the very first day we brought her home at 9 weeks old!  We knew we couldn't begin her training soon enough since she will grow up to be a very big, very scary looking dog to most people.  In December, when she was six months old, I took her to obedience class, which was comprised of all puppies her age, but they were all the cuter breeds, labs, goldens, and toy breeds.  Over the course of the class, the trainer fitted every puppy in class, except Molly, with HEAD HALTERS (like this:Sporn Pet Head Halter, Medium, Black) so that their owners could FINALLY gain control of them while walking them.  When the other puppy parents questioned why they couldn't use an EASY WALK HARNESS, like Molly, the trainer explained that since Molly already responded extremely well to the harness, she could continue using it, and she didn't need a head halter!  Needless to say, I was really proud of both of us!!I do recommend that before you buy your first harness, go to the Manufacturer's web site and double check the sizes, and be sure to measure your dog before choosing a size.  I liked ordering from Amazon, because the half sizes are more readily available here than at the pet stores, but it can be difficult to get the right size, especially for a growing puppy. Molly started out with a sm/m then graduated quickly to a medium, which didn't last long, then to med/large, which lasted her several months, and now she has graduated to a large at 8 months old.  The prices at Amazon are REALLY good, way less expensive than the pet stores, so keep trying!  They are definitely worth the money!!!!
summary: Great for large breed dogs that tend to pull with a collar or regular harness!

reviewText: The Easy Walk harness is great! I've been through obedience training with my 70 lb, 14 month old puppy (when she was 12 wks old). We tried a pinch collar and a pinch collar/step-in harness combo. It didn't stop the pulling or the excitement when she'd see another person or animal. Immediately with the Easy Walk harness she learned she had to walk beside me all the time (not just when it suited her or she was tired). The pulling when she sees other animals or people is minimal, because it gets her nowhere. She's not choking/gagging because something is tight on her throat, and hopefully now will learn to "heel" appropriately so she won't always need the harness. Two paws-up!
The harness is sturdy and easy to put together, a lot better than collars that go around the neck. No complaints over here.
THESE HARNESS ARE PRETTY GOOD,  I GOT A LARGE, AND ITS A LITTLE TOO BIG, BUT MY PUPPY IS STILL GROWING AND WILL FIT INTO IT BETTER SOON.
summary: THESE HARNESS ARE PRETTY GOOD, I GOT A LARGE

reviewText: This harness changed my dog. He would pull and pull with a collar, and after one walk with this he doesn't pull anymore. Save your energy and quit fighting with a puller, get the easy walk harness!

This harness is a must for dogs that pull.  The harness hook goes accross the front of their legs instead of on the back so it is hard and awkward for them to take off.  My vet recommended this and it made our walks much more enjoyable.

This harness is phenomenal! I have never been more satisfied with a pet purchase. As a runner I find it difficult to run when my dog is just on her collar, she tugs, stops and gets completely distracted. With the harness I've found running with her much more enjoyable. She walks by your side, runs by your side, and doesn't pull with it. It did take me a few attempts to adjust it correctly, but once we found what worked we haven't had any issues since. It hasn't loosened despite her swimming, rolling, playing, running and being 'off leash' in the woods with it. The size L fits my 60LB leggy Airedale/Catahoula mix very well. The back clip harnesses seem to encourage pulling, as does the collar. The way this harness fits and where it puts pressure on the dogs when they walk makes it the best of all the brands. I've tried the gentle leaders as well and found those useless.

This is a fantastic harness for my dog, who has to learn how to walk on a leash.  It's comfortable and easy to slip on and off and gives me control of his walking.  I would recommend this to anyone with a "walking issue" with their pet.  Adjustable too to fit body shape and was priced so nice and packaged and delivered on time
This is exactly what we needed it to me.  Love the harness and the way it fits.  Exactly how it is shown in the picture and description.

This thing did absolutely nothing on my standard poodle and his pulling issues.  He continued to pull just as hard with this one as he does his regular leash...and this one is obviously more annoying to put on and cost more than his regular collar.I don't know if it is because the dog's torso is different than other breeds...but this was completely useless to us.  We switched to an over-the-nose halti and it has worked the magic we needed.  It always blows my mind when I hear that this thing works for someone....perhaps they have less eager dogs than I do.
summary: Doesn't work on a standard poodle.  Only the over-the-nose halti works for us.

reviewText: This worked very well with our Golden to make walks more enjoyable during his crazy puppy stage - although we no longer need it. He did still attempt to jump up on people with this on, so still be sure to watch your dog!
Try as I might with various sizes, I couldn't get this to work on my 80 lb English lab.  His chest is just too full to let the straps line up as indicated in the instructions.

We absolutely love this harness. We have a belgian tervuren (sheepdog) who is strong and very alert, and isn't fond of bicycles, motorcyles or buses. He walks fine unless one of these happens by, which he then tries to lunge at. He will also sometimes be so distracted with a smell, he'll forget to stop on the extendo lead.Plus - stops him dead without hurting him at all.Minus - started rubbing his long hair off. Not good for a show dog. We are buying Strap Wraps - I figure they should work just like the fleece we used to cover horse halters with. Assuming that works, it's fabulous.We never had a problem with the harness coming off. I frankly don't see how that can happen if it is adjusted correctly. Also, although they say not to use it with an extendo leash, we've had no issue at all with that.If it weren't for the rubbing, I would have given this 5 stars.
summary: Fabulous difference in walking, just needed a cover

reviewText: We got the large harness and it works great for our 100lb Alaskan Malamute.  He was born to pull and if he gets in that mode he could hurt himself on a regular collar or just pull you along with a regular harness.  This one is great since it redirects the dog rather than directly challenging it so you can give a better correction rather than a challenge.  With this and a bit of training he really calmed down and now walks like a pro.  It was difficult finding the right adjustment to fit such a furry dog, so we ended up using it with the light strap on top.  You may have to do some experimenting.  Luckily it doesn't loosen much on its own with use.  I would say this is a good middle ground between a collar and one of those harnesses that go on the face/head that offer more direct feedback but can be more restricting for the dog.  Just my two cents, I can't say I'm the Dog Whisperer!
We got this harness while looking for a good way to walk (control) our husky. He hated the muzzle collar but this works well and it helps minimize pulling too.

We had this harness in the medium size for my goldendoodle as he was growing, but had to upgrade to the large. The medium worked really well, but the large just doesn't stay tight on him!  As we are walking, it loosens up to where I feel that he could shimmy out of it.  We sent it back and ordered the Sense-ation harness (direct from that company, not on Amazon) and that is working really well for us (Sense-ation is also easier to put on him - only one buckle).  The medium size I would defnitely recommend... the large, though - no.
We have 2 of these and works great especially if you start using them when they are puppies. Great for training class as well!

We have a 75lb Mastiff/Lab who loves to pull! When he was a baby, I had an ankle injury (not from him), and I was afraid to walk him for fear that I would injure myself further. We tried several harnesses, including the face one, which he just learned to slip out of when he jumped and twisted the right way. I finally asked our vet and she recommended the Easy Walk Harness. I could not be happier, and neither could our dog! He is a lot less restricted than in other harnesses we used, and the control I have over his pulling is amazing! Also, I love that the clip is on the front, which is better and safer for you pet! I would and do recommend this to anyone who has a dog that pulls!

We have two smaller mastiffs (both just over 100 lbs.) that have their ups and downs with leash walking.  We have used prong collars in the past, but were open to a friendlier solution if we came across it.  A trainer recommended the EZ Walk Harness because she said if the dog pulls it spins them in the opposite direction and corrects it.  Now, this thing is not the EZ Walk, but the Easy Walk, so I wasn't completely sure we got the correct thing.  After our first walk with our female (she's the better leash-walker of the two), I was convinced we did not get the right product.  Wasn't this supposed to be a gentle, easy, correcting harness?  Then why did it feel like she was a sled dog and I a sled?  After my arm recuperated enough to fit back into socket, I ordered the other brand, the EZ Walk Harness (they look almost identical and appear to work the same way, but I wanted to try each to be sure).  Our male is a new addition - a rescue that had never been on a leash before.  Pro - though thrashing dramatically, he did not manage to slip out of the harness as he does regular collars and the Gentle Leader head harness.  Con - this harness, like the other, provided no correction for pulling.  It actually seemed to encourage it since the pressure was spread out evenly across the chest instead of just the neck.  He delighted in flopping on the other end of the leash like a fish on a line.  Entertaining?  Yes.  Easy walking?  Not unless you have a dog that doesn't weigh anything.  I would not recommend this for strong dogs or dogs that take off quickly after things.

We have used this harness since my 8 yr old lab mix was a puppy. It keeps her from pulling when we walk on leash, yet is easy to get on and off and is very durable. I think we've only gone through 2 or 3 over the years, and it's mostly just the metal getting corroded because we go to the beach a lot. I really love how this harness doesn't choke the dog or take a hard pull to control her. It just gently guides her where we want her and naturally prevents pulling as it tightens across the chest.It takes a little getting used to putting on and off, but once you figure it out it's as easy as putting it over your dog's neck and snapping one buckle.My dog is 70 lb. lab mix and a size L is plenty big for her.
summary: Been using for 8 years and still love it.

reviewText: when he was young and full of himself... the head collar had him bucking like a bronco and yes, while he probably would have given up and gotten used to that, I hated to feel like I was killing his spirit like that.  The halter with the connection point in front did not tug on his head or neck.  The connection point he was very responsive to, where the halters with the connection point on the dog's back he could completely ignore.  He's 4.5 now and we're still using these... he walks nicely on leash now, but I still believe these halters provide firm control in the least harmful way.  I have reached down and grabbed the back strap just to make sure he stayed right with me when he was younger.  The halters lasted quite awhile despite heavy use.  One finally gave up the ghost when the stitching broke, but we have a second one on another dog that is original and is probably going on three years still working like new.
summary: Had trouble finding a product to walk our German Shepherd

reviewText: I AM NOT HAPPY WITH THIS COMPANY! Slowest shipping ever. I ordered my products over a week ago and when i tracked them with the tracking number provided they are still 2 days out. I needed these and i am still waiting. I will never buy from this company again. I foster for a rescue and train them to help them get adopted faster. I am always in need of these kind of items and i will not be purchasing from this company again if this is the way they handle their shipping.

My large German Shepherd loves to ride in the car.  To keep her safe and reduce the risk of having her go through the window or land in the front seat if I have to stop suddenly, it works.  She has the drill down pat.  I put the harness on the floor in front of her.  I lift her left paw and move the harness' "left" side under that paw, then touch her right paw (which she lifts) and slide the harness' "right" side under that paw.  Then pull the harness up and close the clasp and adjust it if necessary.  It fits very snugly so she can't step out of it.  After attaching the connecting strap to a seat belt clasp, she is ready to go.  This also keeps her out of the front seat if I have to leave the car for a few minutes.  There is enough play in the straps so she had put her nose out either back window.  She knows when I take the harness off the hook in the house, she gets to go for another ride with the humans.

The constriction on my dog caused him to sit.  He didn't pull very hard but it was enough to make him not want to go forward.  He later slipped out of it and chewed through one of the straps rendering it completely useless.  The product is described as for Large dogs so I would think they'd use a material not so easily chewed through not merely making it large enough to fit around the pet.  I will not be replacing it.

The price is great. That's about the best thing I can say about this product. Then again, price doesn't matter if the product is useless. The first time we tried it, I didn't really notice it working very well. My dog actually pulled on the leash MORE than when I used a regular collar. And when he did pull, I thought that the ring on the front was supposed to redirect him. Didn't seem to be the case. On the second use, one of the plastic snaps just broke. He wasn't even pulling very hard at the time. I tried this product because a close friend recommended it to me. But I just don't see the point. It also did nothing to stop his jumping (note that the product is not advertised to stop it. But again, whats the point?). Its a good idea in theory.... but the price point is too low to make anything of quality. I would have loved to have given it some more time and use, but it broke so quickly and easily. I will stick to the prong collar. I've gotten great results with that!

This doesn't deter my dog from pulling.  It doesn't even make him think twice.  I don't get what all the hype is about; all these reviews must be fake.So I payed 15 bucks for something that at best will cut up my dogs underarms.  Great.

I have a 50 pound labradoodle, who is just a ball of energy. She is excited twenty four hours a day, and lucky for me, she gets even more excited when she goes for a walk. Walking my puppy used to be a nightmare (well, it still is, a little bit). On her old harness, she could pull me down the street, no problem, and at the end of our walks my hand felt like it had lost circulation. More disconcertingly though, with her old harness, she was able to wiggle around and almost get out of it. She can run much faster than I can, so if she ever gets out of her harness, I might never see her again.I knew I needed to find her a better harness, and I found this one. I was a little worried that this would be a waste of money, because I imagined that having the leash dangling in front of her legs would distract and annoy her, but I decided to try it, because I just could not stand the pulling, and this harness claims to remedy that.In the beginning, she was a DREAM. I loved walking her because any time she started to pull, the harness would work its magic, and voila! I have the perfectly behaved puppy. But when she gets really excited (e.g. when she sees a bird, or a dog, or person, or a balloon, etc., etc.), the harness does not have as great an effect. I notice that even in these moments of ultra excitement, she's not as bad as she was without the harness, but she's still not perfect. I also notice that the effect has somewhat diminished over time. I've had this harness for about two months now, and she goes on walks every day, twice a day. While her pulling still isn't as bad before the harness, in the beginning of our walks she does exert a lot of pressure. Plus, this doesn't get my dog to walk at my side. She still walks ahead. Not that this is a big deal. My dog's a big, fluffy wacko. I don't think she'll ever be perfect on her walks, but I love her anyway.Fortunately, this harness eliminates the worry that she's going to escape. Despite all her wiggling, I have not seen her come close to getting loose from the harness (even when she pulls backward). Also, I love the fact that there are buckles for the bottom strap and the one that wraps around her chest. This harness is so easy to put on. I usually leave the one that wraps around her chest buckled all the time, and just slip this over her head, and then bend down and buckle and bottom strap (the one that goes behind her front paws. I no longer have to turn her harness around and around, trying to figure out how to put it on, and I don't have to stick her paws in (which takes forever because she always takes them back out and gets tangled).Overall, I think this is a great harness. It's not perfect, and does not eliminate all pulling. But it does help with the problem, and does make walking my puppy much more enjoyable.

I have a seven month Old English Sheepdog/Poodle mix who is already 65 pounds and growing fast. I realized when he was only 30 pounds that a regular leash and collar was not going to provide enough control if he decided he wanted to chase a squirrel or leap several feet up in the air to greet another dog up the street (he STILL does this, which is quite the sight!) This harness gives me immediate control over movements and allows me to keep both of us safe when walking near a busy street or crowded areas. It does not hurt him in any way, but instead redirects him when he tries to pull or go off in a different direction (a common event!) Though it is a great product and I highly recommend it, I have to give it 4 stars instead of 5 because it is merely a band-aid for the greater problem of him not being fully trained to loose leash walk on a regular leash and collar. If you need something for day to day use to help start the training process or simply to ensure safety I highly recommend it, but it will not ultimately solve the greater issues behind proper leash walking.

I have a trained dog but I decided to see what the Gentle Leader and this Easy Walk harness offers (used separately).  My dog doesn't constantly pull on a flat collar but he is a very powerful dog so I thought with him I could on occasion throughout some walks see how this harness works any differently than a standard Y harness, a flat collar, prong and Gentle Leader type.I got the harness and it seems to be well made with good nylon, hardware and buckles.  The Large size fits my dog at its maximum size.  My dog is 75lbs but has a large chest.Walking with the harness, my dog will slow or stop with a little pressure even if I'm not queing him by stopping myself. The harness seems to communicate the slow and stop better than a Y harness which the dog has to figure out whether you want him to stop or pull harder (my dog carts, bikes, and ski-jores in a Y harness but will also walk in one).  I can see how this harness would be useful for walking but not for pulling anything, but pulling is under-rated.There is no practical way to give a good positive punisher (correction) to the dog with this harness.  That's true about any harness.  So if you use positive punishers in your training, you will need a collar with a second line or tab or a remote.  There's lots of pet owners that don't use positive punishment or won't have any reason to use it on a walk.So the only thing I don't like is how the lead has to wrap around his shoulder and it will chaffe him after a while.  Since the martingale strap pulls out a little, the bronze lead snap rubs on him.  Maybe if the dog was lagging a little behind the handler then the lead wouldn't wrap across the shoulder but then the dog is basically walking with a totally loose lead or being pulled by the handler.  You could train your dog to walk in that lagging position but this harness won't create the behavior.  I think most people using this will have the lead wraped across the dog's front leg.I like the Herm Sprenger prong collar, especially in the smaller sizes even for big dogs.  I've used it on my own neck and leg and I'm satisifed it can be used in a very humane way and that it is far less likely to cause the painful injury that choke chains can cause.  The evenly distributed pressure of the prongs around the neck when pressure is put on the lead using the live ring works better than anything I have tried (I use it for pressure not corrections; it's good for corrections on very hard dogs but too much for soft dogs).  The sensitivity of the dog's neck to pressure from the prong collar is why I would absolutely never want to use it unless I was actively training my dog.  Any other use is going to desensitize his neck.  I know some people will use the big (less effective than small) prong collars just to keep their dog from pulling on walks.  This is killing the neck's sensitivity slowly, toughening it up so that you'll never be able to use it to steer the dog in training.  That's why I love harnesses for puppies (just let them pull), and harnesses for just walking the dog.  That's why I see this harness as useful, and for people who don't want the adult dog to pull so much it's maybe better than a Y harness, but otherwise less useful overall.I rated it "OK" (3 stars) because the lead rubs the dog's shoulder, and it's less useful overall than a standard Y harness.  The quality seems up to snuff, and it could be the right tool for some people that just want to walk their dog.

I have a young, powerful, and energetic  Labrador Retriever.  He hates the gentle leader over his nose and tries to rub it off shortly after I put it on him.  Sometimes, he is successful and I end up back to a collar and leash on the same walk that started with the "Halti".  In some cases, I have been able to use a flexi and choker, but this can be exhausting.  With surgery planned and lifting restrictions for sometime thereafter, I knew I needed to try another method.  I took a chance on this one and my dog and I are both very pleased. It took some trials and walks to get it perfectly adjusted, but what a difference! I can walk him without straining. He maintains a heel position most of the time on his own, and doesn't mind the harness in the least.  Walking in town is a real pleasure now. I am happy with the purchase, but I would caution a buyer to be patient and adjust it properly. Then, it will be very helpful.  Shipment includes an instruction sheet and tips for those with dogs that continue to tug.  I used their instructions with quick success.

I love this product. I don't even like taking my dog out on the lawn for a minute without using this. We tried the dog trainier's tips to get her to stop pulling for a month to no avail. I didn't want to use a choke chain or prong collar. I figured we would give this a try first since it seemed the nicest way to remind our dog not to bolt to the end of the leash at every opportunity. Our dog is 80 lbs and counting and this has kept her from pulling me around or hurting my shoulder. It is easy to put on if you just unbuckle the bottom silver strap and slip it over their head. I went from high stress walk dreading to easy long walking trips in one day.
summary: Now I can walk the dog!

reviewText: I tried this on my 10 month old puppy who had been pulling and getting a little crazy on a regular collar. I didn't like that he was choking himself so I tried this product after some recommendations.  I got a medium/large for my 42lb pup, but he was so uncomfortable, not with the size, but with the width of the nylon. He walked funny and it looked like it was rubbing under his front paws near the chest.  He also fell once when he tried to run, as the breastplate part dropped a bit and made him trip. So i returned it and tried a smaller size (medium). That fit much better and he was more comfortable with the smaller width of the nylon. However, he from time to time on the walk sat down and refused to move forward.  I know that it wasnt just a behavior issue and he really still was uncomfortable with the feel of this.  I think the front pull was making him too hesitant to move forward.  Once i took the harness off he was totally fine and also was much better about not pulling. So i think, in short, that this is good to use as a short time training tool in certain situations. This is just my opinion based on how my pup reacted. So now i use it when go for long walks in the park with another dog friend of his that tends to make him a bit crazy...and on the way home, i take it off and let him have a break from it...and i do see he is a better walker after having had that on..  I see some dogs in the park or dog run wearing them while they play and it looks like they are uncomfortable

I use Gentle Leaders when I need good control of my dogs, but my foster dog hates it on her face.  She's fine on a regular collar until she sees a squirrel or a bunny.  While we work on this issue, I need a way to control her so she doesn't choke herself.  The GL works great, but she stops periodically on the walk to try to scratch it off her face.  I feel bad that she's uncomfortable and worry that she's going to scratch herself, so I've been looking for alternatives.  Now I remember why I gave up on these harnesses with my other dogs.  They don't fit every dog, and even when they do fit, they chafe under the arms unless your dog has a really thick coat.  My pittie mix immediately tried to rub this off her and I could see why - the buckles were pressing right into her armpits no matter how I adjusted the straps.It's going back without even a walk.  It looks less comfortable and more harmful than the GL.  I may try the Freedom Harness with the velvet straps next, or she'll just have to get used to the GL.This harness might work if your dog is perfectly proportioned for it, but it didn't work for my pretty normally proportioned dog.
summary: High hopes dashed - awkward fit, unfortunate buckle placement make it unwearable

reviewText: My dog got what looked like carpet burns under her arms. This product cannot be easily adjusted and when you do adjust it, it does not always stay that way. Plus the part on the front of the harness cannot be adjusted at all. These kind of harnesses are horrible if you have a puller because it only gives the dog a broad band to pull with. Basically, your dog gets stronger if you have a band around their chest and it makes walking horrible.

My puppy's a puller and despite frequent walks with efforts to either use verbal correction or muscle him back on course, nothing seemed to dissuade him from pulling. At 6 months old he's already getting strong enough to pull me off balance- I wasn't looking forward to him trying to pull me with his adult weight.  So finally I decided to try this, and at first use he seemed to walk slower.The surprise (pleasantly) came when I took him out for a walk in a promenade. Some bikers rode by and my dog doesn't chase cars, but he immediately made a run to go after the bikes. My thought was "OH NO" and there was this fraction of a moment of panic thinking I couldn't brace myself in time to keep my shoulder in its socket when he pulled, but he got to the end of his leash and immediately snapped back, turned around by the harness.  The weather was nice that day and there were lots of bikers out, because he tried it again about a half hour later when another biker rode past. Again, he sprung to the end of his leash, and immediately got turned around.
