This thing saved my shoulder -and probably saved my dog's life, too.If you have difficulty with a dog that pulls, I'd highly recommend giving this a shot.

Okay I have 2 very large dogs who almost pull my shoulder out of scoket on walks using a traditional leash. This has solved my problems! This is my 2nd one, have one for each dog now and now I walk the dog...the dog no longer walks me! It's great how it works, there's no way they can really get ahead of you. I'm lovin this product. It actually pulls the dog into your side. Walks WITH you! I honestly can not stress how helpful this product has been to me. I almost gave up on walking the dogs! I do have a huge backyard for them to run free, but there's nothing like seeing their tales waggin and happy to be leashed!Enjoy, I know you will.

This is the best no pull harness I have found. I have one for both of my dogs. We already had this harness for our first dog who used to pull. We broke him of that habit but still use this harness as it is much better than a collar for going on walks. When we adopted our second dog he pulled like no other. I immediately ordered another harness and can't believe the difference it made.
this was great because my dog didn't pull, but she got cuts under her arm pits from the harness rubbing her skin.

With one small change, this harness would get a 5 star rating from me.  I made the fix myself, so I give MY version of the Easy Walk harness 10 stars (please watch the video with this review).  The front-leash harness makes walking with my active standard poodle puppy fun.  With a slip collar neither of us enjoyed our walks - me because I was being pulled, and puppy because I was constantly correcting her with snaps of the collar.  HOWEVER - as other reviewers have stated, DOGS CAN SLIP OUT OF THIS HARNESS UNDER STRESS.  My puppy did this when she encountered a favorite playmate on our walk.  She rolled over on her back, legs flailing, and bingo, she had slipped the harness.  (I do have it adjusted properly - I watched the video 3 times to be sure).  I didn't want to give up on the harness, so I spent about 15 minutes creating a simple fix for the problem.  I hope the attached video helps you.  If you are using this harness now, and your dog hasn't escaped yet, please be very careful - it can happen in an instant.  Dogs are born escape artists!
summary: Instructions for adding a fail-safe link to collar

reviewText: Our vet saw this on the dog and strongly recommended that we stop using it.  She said it's putting pressure on tendons, changing the dog's gait and will eventually cause problems.  It is not as easy to use as other harnesses and it definitely does not discourage her pulling behavior.
summary: Vet says changes gait, bad design

reviewText: This really works for any dog that pulls your arm off! It really is NOT that complicated to use AT ALL! The Humane Society in my area uses them all the time on their big dogs. Make your walks more enjoyable for you AND your dog! Especially nice for new moms who have to push a baby stroller and walk the dog - with this harness it can be done with ease and safety. I can't recommend this product enough! Every time I see someone walking down the street with a big dog pulling their arm off, I want to stop and tell them to get this!

I have been using these harnesses for my boxers since they were puppies.  They do not pull at all with it.  If it is on to tight it does rub on their armpit a bit on long walks.  They are very durable.  I wash them all the time to freshen them up.  Great walking experience!

I am currently enrolled in an Animal Care Program at a local college and ordered this for my Boston Terrier after I learned this is the best harness to use when helping to leash train a dog. (I used the one with the D-Ring in the back, which doesn't help inhibit the forward pull motion).My dog will be 4 in October. He is about 23 pounds, which is a good size for a BT. He is great on the leash, but can get very excited and pull a lot when he sees other dogs and kids, or you know, a moving plastic bag.Anyway- this leash worked great! The instructions were easy to follow for fitting it properly to my dog. I did remove his actual collar when I walked him though, as his dog tag hangs a bit low and it was bumping into the D ring the whole time. He didn't pull at all and we had a very enjoyable walk. I'm glad I made the switch to this harness and would recommend to anyone, regardless of the size or age of your dog.

I measured my dog multiple times and the harness still didn't fit even though he was in the appropriate range for the size I bought. This product is made for dogs with flat broad chests. It cut him very badly under his front legs as a result.

First, I want to say that I read every review here before purchasing, and while I was a bit worried when I first ordered it, I had to do something. I have a 100 lb malamute who is now 11 and a bit senile. I have always had trouble walking her, as she likes to eat little dogs for breakfast, and medium sized dogs for lunch. In the past, I tried the gentle leader with her, which I use with my other dogs, but she decided that the way to make me stop using it, is when we cross the street, right in the middle of the street, she would immediately roll over, especially if she saw a car was coming, and attempt with all her might to get the gentle leader off. After several times of stopping traffic, I decided to order this instead.Fitting it was simple, the strap that is a different color makes for very easy identification of which way to put it on, and walking my malamute is super simple. She does not mind it one bit, actually, she seems to really like it. Even if she sees a small dog in a fenced yard, I am able to maintain full control, and with only one hand! I don't remember the last time I've been able to walk the malamute so simply, I don't think I ever have. So far I have not seen any evidence of skin irritation or anything like that, but then she has a lot of fur.I did also try this on my 85 lb short haired German Shepherd dog, who walks just fine with the gentle leader, and I decided that I prefer this over the gentle leader, and will be ordering a couple more for my other dogs. Overall a great design, great product, very happy, and so are my dogs.Update 08/12/12I wanted to send an update as I have completely switched to using this harness over the gentle leaders. All of my dogs now use this, and all of my dogs love it. We do a lot of hiking, and one of my German Shepherds has always been a problem when it came to squirrels running in front of him that he really wants to chase. Well, this thing does the trick. After doing a few 180's with out any harm to me, he quickly learned that I have full control, and he stopped trying to chase squirrels when on leash!!About the only problem I have found, is that when the dogs try to jump in the back seat of a full size pick up truck, they have a little trouble because of the harness, and I have to help them, but this too was a blessing in disguise because now I get to decide when I'm ready for them to jump in.I'm extremely happy with this harness. My dogs are happy too.
summary: I can walk my malamute again!

reviewText: It took forever to fit.  The buckle lay right behind the leg.  I fiddled around to adjust the fit but the strap is still close behind the leg.  She couldn't sit comfortably.I didn't like the design very much.  I tried to walk my dog with it but I could see she was uncomfortable.I bought another harness.  The Freedom No-pull harness.  Not available on Amazon.  It is beautifully made with velvet lining on the chest strap.  It is a lot easier to adjust and fit  and in my opinion is a better design.  It has the pull front ring on the chest and also a martingale pull ring on the back.  I walked my dog in it and she did great.  I am training my dog to heel and this harness makes it an easier job.  For a few extra dollars the Freedom no pull harness is worth it.For  those of you who like the Easy Walk Harness.  I  have  come across a new product called "Strap Wraps"  from petexpertise they are fleece wrap covers that wrap around the straps on the Easy Walk Harness to help protect dog's underarms from getting sore.
summary: Bought it today will return it

reviewText: The harness rubbed, burned and cut the underarm of my dog.  Maybe it is good for larger dogs with heavy fur, but definitely not for small dogs with fine hair.

I could not walk my 7 and 9 month old boxers without this product.  It is amazing how nice my dogs walk with this product.  It took some time for them to get used to them, but with gradual increase of wear time they got used to wearing them and wow it is awesome to take them on walks with these.

This item broke at the "D-ring" after the second time it was used. The ring literally separated from the harness. I contacted the company that manufactures it and they sent me a new one. To my surprise, it was actually a higher quality product than the one shipped through Amazon. Comparatively, the Amazon shipped harness didn't even have the Petsafe name logo on the harness and was made of a much cheaper grade nylon and had more flimsy metal components. The one that Petsafe sent me in replacement was the same product but had much higher quality metal components (they were actually larger), the nylon was thicker, and their logo was actually on the product. I'm not sure if the first one wasn't some sort of knock off placed in the Petsafe package.  On the positive side, this worked wonders with my dog, helped with pulling tremendously.
summary: Broke after 2 days, but it worked well before that!

reviewText: I couldn't believe how fast the gentle leader easy walk harness worked!  First time out with the harness, our son's dog - a real puller on walks - transformed into a tame labrador that my 95lb wife could now walk with ease.  Way to go!

Works great! We had a standard harness where the lead attaches atop the puppy's back, but she pulled constantly.... even when she was held in position so she couldn't move forward! When she tries to pull with this type harness, it's uncomfortable for her (but doesn't choke like a simple collar would) and she stops pulling. Be sure to measure the puppy's girth before buying. Had to return the large to Petco and got the medium from Amazon. BTW, Petco charges more than twice as much for the same harness! This harness is SOOOOOOOOO Easy to put on.... no need to lift the pup's legs to "step in". Just undo the buckle on the black belly strap, put the red part over the pup's head with the leash loop facing forward, then buckle the black strap under the belly... making sure it's behind the front legs. Too easy!Update 10/24/2013: My 9-month old Plott Hound has almost outgrown the medium, so I just ordered the reflective med/large as a replacement.

I have a 47 pound lab/besenji and who knows what else mix.  Reilly (his name) is the most docile dog in the house you will ever meet.  On a regular collar in the house he heels, stops and sits, stays and obeys all the other commands a good dog will follow. However, 3 feet out the front door on a regular collar and leash and he forgot who I am and just wouldn't listen. No amount of scolding or treats would change his behavior. Pound for pound he is one heck of a strong dog.  So much so that with a regular collar, he dragged my 82 year old father to the ground.To make matters worse my neighborhood has an abundance of friendly deer and squirrels.  Of course, he wants to chase everyone he encounters. I first went with a choke collar and he laughed that off.  He would still strain and get up on his hind legs while I held the leash and yelled NO.Next on the list was the Easy Leader. After going through a lot of trouble to put this on (he learned quickly it wasn't something he would like), it worked to a degree. The frustration with this device came soon after we started a walk. He would try to rub his face against my leg, stop and attempt to push it off his face with his front paws or go pushing his face along the ground.  Also, there were a couple of times that he would still strain at the leash regardless of the pressure being applied to have him stop.Finally, running out of hope of ever enjoying a walk, I purchased the Easy Walk.  I purchased the large dog size and had to adjust it to the lowest limits of the straps. The first thing I noticed was that he didn't resist it being fitted or snapped closed. It is easy to put on over his head and snapping the under chest strap is a breeze.  I am a fairly large guy and have no problem with the size of the buckles.  The buckles also are designed to snap only in one direction.  So if by accident you gave the under chest strap a half twist while putting it on the dog it will not snap. Removing the harness is a one hand two finger exercise.  When I take it off, he doesn't even shake himself.From his first walk with the Easy Walk he became the dog I wanted. Although he will give the deer and squirrels an occasional bark, he no longer pulls and strains.  He immediately stops when I stop, doesn't rear up and all this is accomplished while barely holding onto the leash.I recommended this to my neighbor that has an unruly 115 pound sheep dog. She purchased it and said, "finally after 7 years, I walk the dog instead of the other way around."I highly recommend the product and Amazon's price is less then at the pet stores.
summary: Best bucks you can spend when you have a dog that wants to walk you!

reviewText: July 2013: And yet another harness, #4, the result of fostering Malamutes. The current Mal is 3-year old Giant Mal, 30" at the shoulder, 54" long, a trim 160 lbs. He requires the girth (belly band) of the Extra-Large harness due to his deep chest, but his shoulders remain narrow yet, and the Extra-Large shoulder strap (with the chest pull ring), is too wide even at it's smallest adjustment. The Large harness fits his chest well, but the belly band is way too short for him. So, I purchased the Large Easy-Walk, about a 24" piece of webbing to match the existing belly band, removed the original belly band and made a direct copy re-using the original strap's hardware, but one and a half times as long. Any household sewing machine with upholstery thread and an upholstery needle will suffice. Just match the stitches and you're good to go. This Giant Mal pulls like a locomotive (no walking manners or training), but is easily handled using an Easy Walk. Be kind to yourself, daughter and I have Malamutes, Siberians and Shepards... they all wear an Easy Walk. We take our dogs for walks, the dogs do not take us for a walk (or worse).I purchased this Easy Walk Harness as a replacement for a heavy-duty web harness worn by my Malamute (extra-large, 120 lbs, large barrel/girth, yada yada). I also bought it because its a) easy to put on, b) easy to adjust, c) works great, d) cost is great, and e) I purchased one some years ago for my Siberian.As with any harness, you'll need to do some fitting, took me about 15 minutes, and another 2 minutes a day later. Do the obvious: if the dog walks out of it, make it smaller; it if chaffs, make it larger. Otherwise, consult a dog professional if you need help figuring this out.When walking casually and allowing my dogs some freedom, I put their harnesses on with the metal loop ON TOP; when I want to walk them in more crowded environments and not allow them to pull or charge off, I put the metal ring ON THE CHEST, as prescribed in the literature. The chest attachment keeps them from turning me into a human sled, they walk quietly or end up falling down on their side. They learn fast.ps: Dec 2012; We just adopted another very large Malamute (again), and bought our third Easy-Walk. At 135 lbs, this XL harness fits and still has some adjustment remaining. I think a 150 lb Mal is about the limit of this harness, fit may vary depending on your dog and breed.pss: I finally learned an obvious trick -- adjust the harness with the lead/leash ring on the chest, as intended. Then, ADD a simple round metal ring on the top strap, the strap that passes over the withers (it has a buckle to accomplish this addition). I use a 2-inch diameter ring often found at hardware stores.Why do this?, well, so that you always put the harness on the same way every time, and the additional ring on top allows you to connect your lead to it whenever and wherever you want. A 2-inch ring slides freely along this top strap. And, if you have 2 heavy haulers as I do, you can use these top rings for attaching a splitter, aka, a dog-to-dog yoke, and connect your lead to the splitter. (A splitter should have a fixed ring or similar lead attach hardware in the center.) And then enjoy your forthcoming ride!
summary: Premier EASY WALK DOG HARNESS -- perfect for Malamute & Siberian

reviewText: This easy walk harness is like a miracle worker with my Lab!  We had been through numerous training classes and she would still tug on the leash like crazy making it very annoying / embarrassing to walk down the street with her.  The very first time I put this harness on her it worked like a charm.The best part is that the harness is very comfortable for the dog too.  Unlike harnesses that attach on the back, this takes away the dogs power as it pulls them to the side and moves their center of gravity if they start to pull.  One thing to note is that I have noticed rubbing under my pup's front legs if she has been swimming and then runs with this on so now I just take it off when we're at the lake.Get this product!  Sooner rather than later!  It will change your life =)
summary: Best Harness Out There Hands Down

reviewText: I bought this because my puppy constantly pulled ahead on the leash. I liked how the leash connection is in front, on the chest. It prevents him from pulling (as hard). When he does pull, he's forced to walk sideways which is a lot easier to get his attention with a treat. With this harness and some help from puppy kindergarden, we're getting there. He's learning to walk by my side now. I couldn't have done that without the harness.

Normally, I prefer to train a dog to walk well on a leash over relying on hardware. But I have a hard-pulling foster dog and not enough time to train her, so I purchased this after seeing some friends have great results with it. I quickly discovered that it's tricky and may not work with every dog.First problem is getting the fit right so that the front-fastening loop sits high enough on the dog's chest, because if it sits too low the "stretching" you get with the loop can cause the leash to hit the dogs front leg with every step. It's quite annoying for me and possibly for the dog as well. But if you tighten too much to get the fastening assembly to sit higher and not stretch out so much, it seems uncomfortably tight on the dog and looks like it's cutting into her underarms. So getting the fit right seems to be a long process of trial and error and tightening or loosening the four places you can tighten or loosen. I've had to stop in the middle of walks and start fiddling because I'm too annoyed to let it continue.There is a slight decrease in the amount of pulling she does in this harness, but I'm in the process of trying to decide which is more annoying: a dog who pulls like a tractor or trying to get this stupid %$&#@* harness to fit right.I really think that the harness would work better for my dog without the loop assembly at the fastener. I understand that the idea is for pulling to cause the harness to gently squeeze the dogs chest and exert some calming pressure, but my foster dog seems to be part freight train and doesn't seem to notice the squeezing. The only thing that seems to make the pulling less annoying is that the leash fastens in the front, so when she pulls the slight sideways pressure reduces the amount of force she can use to drag me along with her.I have a Gentle leader head harness that I used on another foster, and I think I'll try it on this one. But mostly I'm going to make time to actually train this dog how to walk nicely (see the Kikopup channel on YouTube for great leash-walking training tips--it won't let me post a link here) so I don't keep wasting my money on crappy harnesses that promise what they can't deliver.
summary: Probably not the panacea you are hoping for

reviewText: My beagle used to pull and pull, and when his nose catches a scent in the wind, he's impossible to control. With a choker, he'd pull til he was about to pass out, I tried Ceaser Milan's Illusion collar, that was ok, but still not very good. I didn't like the fact that it was still a choker.This one is amazing. When my beagle first put it on, he's automatically a Much better walker, I can't explain it. And best of all, No Choking! He no longer pulls like he did before, he's much easier to control. The only this is the Size.. He's the the large end of the "Medium" size dogs, and the smallest end for the "Large" dog category, so got the Large harness its a little looser than we would like, and the Medium would be too tight. But other than that, works great!
summary: After trying other products this is the best

reviewerName: Maddely "So many books, so little time"
reviewText: Just got home from walking my dog using this harness for the first time. Thought I'd rave about it because it worked!!! My puppy is 6 mos. old, a poodle/golden mix, and weighs almost 50 lbs. now and expected to put on another 15-20 more lbs., so I really need to get control of him when we walk. Obviously he's not fully leash trained... yet... still working on it. He outgrew his Halti (muzzle lead like the Gentle Leader brand) almost a month ago and I actually just ordered one through Amazon this week because it was the only thing that worked on stopping his leash pulling. I've tried other so called 'no-pull harnesses' and he was still able to pull me. And the bigger he gets the more he can wrench my arm. But I might just return the Halti because this harness does the trick. I haven't actually read the directions other than how to put it on. I'm wondering if the black and red straps are color coded for something. Anywa, we just walked like normal and it worked. Took a tiny bit to get used to the leash hanging so low, on his chest, but not a big deal. Was a very big deal that he wasn't choking himself on the entire walk like he usually is when his leash is just attached to his regular collar. He's the worst when we first start our walk because he's so excited to get out and get going, but right out the door he did NOT pull! It was amazing! We usually walk an hour at night and for the entire walk he was unable to pull me!!! I love it! Totally recommend this harness.

This is especially great for a female dog walker.  Gives a lot of control and when the dog pulls, they will stop immediately.  Have two large bouviers that are very strong and head strong too.  These are great.  Highly recommended for large, strong dogs.
summary: easy walk harness for large/strong dogs

reviewText: This has completely changed our lives! It works so perfectly to prevent my 2 dogs from pulling/taking off etc!When new, make sure the loops are adjusted several times, as you walk the first  couple times, you will have it perfect for each dog; they all have different body shapes, so don't expect it to be perfectly adjusted the first time you put it on.They rapidly understand that "bolting" will only make them fly and fall, this collar will not let them take off! Then, you get a nice polite dog, enjoying the walk!My dogs are so rambunctious, so active and they weigh the same as I do (110!) that I never walked them on the street, only at the park.Now we WALK  ANYWHERE, all 3 at the same time, in peace! I love this and recommend it over the prong collar I used for 6 LONG years with my lab!

PROS:  It's decent.  I like the concept of the front clipping harness.  It works ok with my 80+ pounder.  I like to clip the leash to the harness ring AND the collar for extra security.  I think it does well but then again my dog isn't a serious puller.  The few times that I've had to redirect him, this harness definitely worked better than if I had the leash attached only to his collar.  And it's certainly safer for the dog than a pinch collar, which I've used in the past.CONS:  The nylon is not friendly on skin and dogs (with short coats especially) can get serious chaffing on their bellies and armpits - to the point of raw skin.  If you do get this harness, I would recommend also buying the "strap wrap" from Pet Expertise, or sewing one of your own if you're handy like that.  It's basically soft fleece with velcro that you can use to cover the strap that goes under the belly.  Until this harness manufacturer makes use of better materials, this wrap is a pretty good solution to the bad chaffing issue.

Our little frenchie pulls a a lot, but not with this.  Tweener size is perfect for his 23 lb little built body.  Love knowing we are no longer straining his neck.  Stitching is very good and if breaks you can get a replacement from the company.
Waste of money. Good product but poor design in my opinion. Constantly has to be tightened. What a shame.

Our 35lb lab-whippet mix fits perfectly in the S/M. She reacts well with the harness on, so that's awesome. The reason I didn't give this 5 stars is because the front of the harness doesn't stay adjusted very well; this is understandable, given how much our dog pulls when she's on the leash. Luckily, she fits fine with the adjustments at their biggest, but if you are between sizes I would go smaller, and use the harness with the adjustments out all the way.
summary: Great control, love the in-between size

reviewText: Like most reviewers this really worked to curb my sheppard pup of pulling, but after a couple of days we noticed the unpadded nylon straps had rubbed away the hair #1 and #2 he had some raw rub lines under his front legs(armpit area). I also went to the one link mentioned and ordered the padded over straps for the original ones to reduce the raw spots, which they did. Nice product but would like to see them pad their straps for the animals comfort.

I have two Cocker Spaniels who have pulled my husband and I around the block ever since we got them.  As they got bigger the pulling was harder and harder on us and not fun.  We got these harnesses yesterday and my husband took each dog by himself today and each of them walked calmly next to him because the harness' design won't allow them to pull ahead.We'll be able to enjoy walking the dogs now instead of having a tug of war twice a day.  We highly recommend this product.
summary: Made Walking Our Cocker Spaniels a Breeze

reviewText: Our female rottie weighs in at a hefty 95-100 lbs, she's no small girl! She get super excited when it's time for her walks and she will pull me down the street (my husband raised her from a pup before I came along, and let's just say he's a big softy) since she was not taught proper leash manners from an early age.  I watched them take off down the street for the first time with this harness on and it looked pretty good...when he returned he was very shocked.  He didn't think it would work, but he said from the get-go this harness stopped her from pulling.  She did try a couple of times at first, but that was it!  We don't know how it works, but it does, she no longer takes us for walks!
summary: Great product, really truly stops pulling!

reviewText: I should have never purchased this harness as my 90# Pit Mix is a leader, not a follower. I like my dogs to enjoy their walks by giving them some freedom to sniff. But if you're a person who demands obedience while walking your dog, this harness might work great for you.  We are all different in our preferences.

This harness works, kind of, but shortly after getting it, we ended up getting the gentle leader which works much better. Honestly, this harness doesn't do much for strong, stubborn pullers. It made virtually no difference with my puggle and he's not even very big. We sometimes still use this harness because it's better than just using a collar, but not much. If your pet is extremely stubborn or extremely strong, I would just get the gentle leader instead, it's much more effective in my opinion.

I have a 9 month old terrier mix puppy.  He is the master of wriggling out of collars and harnesses.  This brand is the best one we've tried.  It is secure and does not irritate or rub his skin.  Be sure to tighten it a bit after several uses.  Normal use causes it to loosen a tiny bit.  I don't consider this an issue--it is expected with the material used for the harness.

This harness definitely works to redirect a pulling dog, hence the 3 stars. However, the sizing is tough. I started with a large for my 70-lb hound but despite his weight he has a slim build so the belly strap fit but the chest strap, even at its tightest, drooped and tripped him up. I then ordered a medium because the belly strap on the medium/large didn't seem different enough from the large, and it was pretty tight at its loosest. When we were walking both sizes slid around and needed constant readjustments. It's also annoying to be flipping the leash in front of the dog's head as he goes from one side of you to the other.I am also terribly disappointed that this isn't made of sturdier material. I was distracted for less than 30 seconds while I thought my dog was chewing on a toy, and he sliced through the chest strap like his teeth were knives! I tried to post a picture with no luck.

Oh My God!  I wish I discover this product sooner.  I was having a hard time walking my 40 lb golden retriever, who is always pulling and charging hard when seeing other dogs.  This product allows me to have a better control of her.

I got one of these for our Boston Terrier who is barrel chested. I was concerned that it would rub and chafe as some reviewers mentioned. I had a different model for our other Boston Terrier and that did chafe her. Different dog with this one but same concept and after months he shows no signs of irritation. It has made our walks more pleasant!

We have 2 large labs and they are pullers. Since getting these harnesses for them, we have noticed a drastic improvement. They pull at least 80% less! Our walks are so much nicer now :).I think this harness coupled with a leash that has a double handle - the handle where you can hold them closer to your body really helps a lot. Definitely recommend this product!
summary: Keeps my 2 Labs from Pulling Us Down the Street!

reviewText: This is my second; the dog ate the first. She doesn't like wearing it when she's not on a walk. She's an obedient walker, and this harness helped train her. I take my dog for rides on my bike: I ride and hold her leash on the left handlebar with three fingers, and she trots and walks along side me. This harness is more user friendly that collar attachment when on bike rides.

Purchase for a 4 mo old puppy who was starting to pull. Works better than the gentle leader for him. He really didn't like the gentle leader and his anxiety went up as soon as you put it on. This one fits just like a harness so he's fine with it and he learned really quickly from feeling the tension on his chest that he need to slow down and let the leash slacken.

Although this states that it is up to 25 lbs., my 35 lb. ESS is still wearing this harness.  Works well and eliminates the pulling on our walks.  I do not recommend using this if you run with your dog.
summary: Easy to put on and stops the pulling!

reviewText: This is a must have if your dog needs work on his leash manners especially if he/she is stronger than you.

My dog is hyper. He likes to pull me down the street. We brought a trainer in to help us get a handle on our guy, and she suggested the Easy Walk harness. It works great! The other day we had to switch to another leash and it was a non-Easy Walk and you know what, not easy to walk! So well named and use it every day. Highly recommend!
summary: Easy Walk makes it easy to walk a hyper pup

reviewText: this thing has been a life saver.  i've been using it on my blue nose pit puppy and it has made teaching him to walk on a leash a smooth process to say the least.  he learned very quickly that he couldnt run and pull with this as it would fling him off balance.  my only gripe about this harness is that the material does irritate the skin behind the front legs.  to fix this...i applied some sports tape to the strap that goes behind the front legs and no more irritation.  i'd highly recommend this for puppies, new dog owners or anyone who has a dog that loves to pull while walking on a leash.
summary: LOVE this harness!  Made teaching my pitbull puppy how to walk on a leash a smooth process!!!

reviewText: I had trouble fitting this on my dog Phoebe. I ended up trying on a size and color Amazon did not have from Pet Smart. Adjustment of that front tab that fits over the chest, always loosened up. Currently kept what we have from Pet Smart private label.Plan to try the Kurgo unit that works with pressure on the chest but connects behind the neck. These do help stop pulling

The Easy Walk harness is an awesome device and works as advertised.The harness is nicely constructed and made of high quality components, with thick straps and robust plastic clips.  I have the red version with the black under belly strap, so it's easy to tell at a glance which end of the harness is up.The collar is easy to set-up and there is a small pamphlet that shows the way to achieve a proper fit.  Getting it fit for my ~25 pound Wheaton Terrier was quickly done in about 5 minutes, and only needed some additional small adjustments over the course of the first day using it.  I purchased the medium size, as my dog was sort of in between the small and medium, and I'd rather it be a bit too big than too small.  It does fit her well, but I found that the strap for the part of the collar you attach the leash to would loosen as we walked.  To remedy this I tightened the front strap completely so that the seam on the end of the straps was pulled through the claps.  This took some work, but as a result they don't loosen anymore.  I was only able to do this since my dog is the smallest breed that will fit the medium size, I doubt I would have been able to pull them as tightly if she was bigger.In use this harness is a wonder.  As soon as I put it on my dog and we started our walk I noticed she was walking at a more relaxed pace and if she attempted to run off after another animal she was quickly stopped in her tracks.  The way the leash attaches to the harness below the dog's neck is a bit awkward, but the results speak for themselves, and I would have picked up the Easy Walk a long time ago had I know it would be so effective at stopping my dog's pulling.  The dog doesn't seem to mind wearing the Easy Walk either (although I'm sure she's not thrilled since she can't pull anymore), and I've haven't noticed any irritation on my dog's skin from it.All in all... if you've tried all the training methods and are still contending with a pulling dog, try the Easy Walk.
summary: The magic harness... it really works!

reviewText: Was too small for pup as my pup has a lot of hair and the harness was too thin so the harness was buried in his hair

I really like this harness, it works well with deterring pulling. My only issue with this is that after a few weeks (it might have even been a few days) the front loosens up. Then it loosens with every walk. This is no good for a dog who can escape or for an aggressive dog. And if you have one that is both, then you need a better harness. A martingale collar/harness combo might be better for you.

My dog definitely did not like this product.  There's not much else I can say except he would not walk in it and seemed extremely uncomfortable.  I did return it, and would not recommend this for larger, stockier built dogs as no matter how it was adjusted, it did not work out.

I bought this because my puppy was yanking my arm out while pulling me in every different direction.  She still needed a lot of training on what I expected of her while she was on lead, but at least I wasn't getting upset at her for hurting me while doing it.  She's grown out of the medium and I bought a large, but I find now I don't need it.  She still pulls sometimes, but now knows what "easy" means, and knows she's supposed to walk with me.I only used this while she was on lead.  If she was hanging around the house or playing with dogs, I'd take it off.
summary: Still needs to be trained not to pull if you ever expect to go back to a flat collar.

reviewText: i bought 1 in august and it ripped apart near the d ring and adjustment bar in less than a month. i thought it was a fluke, so I ordered another one in early September, it ripped again in the EXACT SAME SPOT in less than a month.i really like the design, it does work in helping to lead your dog where they need to be while walking/running. However, two shouldn't have ripped that easily or quickly.I have a 70lb. german wire haired pointer. Yes he is big, yes he is active, but in no way would i describe him as an excessive puller on the leash. i got the harness because he really has a hard time going the same direction i do, meaning he will move to the right while Im trying to go left. so, the harness really did help him gently turn with me. plus its better having any pressure in the front and not on his neck.he is in basic dog obedience and the instructor liked the easy walk harness but had actually recommended another one, should have listened.i liked that the D ring was in the front of the chest and not the back, like a husky pulling a sled.either way, if they decide to make more durable harnesses and i will consider buying another.

The red goes over the top of theback, the place where you hook the leash goes in front, and the stretchy black goes under the belly/behind the front legs :)So, puppy tugs... and turns... it cinches a little and puppy no longer wants to tug!  So far, the most humane, safe, and pleasant way to get puppy to NOT tug.  My puppy is a golden retriever.  Before him, I had a boxer/red bone coon hound mix who hurt my shoulders and back with her tugging ALL the time and the use of a pronged choker was the only way to get her to NOT hurt me and yank SO hard, but I HATED using that collar on her as much as she hated having it on her.  It's a huge relief to know I will never have to go back to that dreaded collar ever again :)  YAY!!!!I love the leash that comes with this harness as well (it comes with a 1" thick, very well made, red leash)

This product fits my french bulldog puppy really strangely.  The buckle on the bottom strap is right in her armpit and rubs her skin raw.  That being said, it does cut down on the pulling.  I will probably try a different size once she gets bigger.  This may just be one of those products that just isn't meant for the weird frenchie body shape...
I tried everything to keep her from pulling me over, which has happened.  This is the first gizmo to work.  This does not hurt her throat or neck.  I would recommend this and the seller.

This product worked the second I put it on my 45 pound Carolina dog. She knew not to pull or else she wouldnt be able to walk normally. But then..maybe because my dog is so damn rebellious or because she likes to see me pulling my hair out from her antics, she decided it would be a great idea to act like a sled dog and pull me down the street while wearing her harness, despite the fact it squeezes her front legs together. So after a day of use, my puppy was able to rip the front strap in half from the insane amount of pressure she used to pull me around like a rag doll. i think if you have a normal puppy and not one who can be possessed by satan like mine, then this is a great harness. I think a dog that is so headstrong, impervious to pain, and obsessed with working her way up the pecking order, like mine, should use something else.
summary: works well until the dog flips out

reviewText: I purchased this harness to help teach my dog to heal better. It does that very well. The downside I see is for smaller dogs, such as my 40 lbs mix, is they quickly tangle themselves in the lead, or the harness quickly starts pulling to one side or another. (now before you tell me I don't have it adjusted properly, I don't think there are many more ways I can adjust it without just lashing it directly to my dog.). The lead also quickly drops and starts dragging on the ground which annoys the dog and me.With that said, I think it is a fine product. Well made. but perhaps not best for dogs medium and smaller... (I would totally use this on a lab, shepherd or my old collie if needed.)
summary: Might not be optimal for smaller dogs (40 lbs or less)

reviewText: I've tried several different types of collars and walking systems, but this worked best for my dogs—especially my bull terrier. She used to be a freight train. Now she trots happily beside me and the minute she feels pressure, she eases up. I love that there is no pulling on the neck area and the front placement of the hook-on makes it natural for the dog to walk next to you, not in front.
summary: Finally, a walking system that works for us

reviewText: I use these harnesses on my dog - always.  It changed her from a puller, who would almost choke herself, to a calm easy to walk dog.  It works. The medium size runs a tiny bit small.  If you are concerned about size, order the M/L instead of the M.
summary: Great product - runs a bit snug

reviewText: This harness was a life saver.  I have a 46lb rescue dog...not really sure what she is breed-wise but she is kind of built like a pit bull with a barrel chest and belly.  I got the medium and with some adjustments it seems to fit her just right.  She has some pretty bad trachea and neck scarring issues from the past (likely chained up) and with her previous leash attached to the collar, she was constantly choking herself and going hoarse, even when she wasn't pulling hard.  This harness has completely changed our walks....I am so glad I found it and I recommend it to anyone with pulling issues.  I have not tried the gentle leader (around the snout) but for a dog with mistreatment issues in the past, I just wasn't comfortable with that style, and I don't feel I need it at this point.
This is a great quality harness. Its very simple to use and to put on your dog. It's basically the easiest and best harness I have ever spent money on.
This is the best dog harness out there. It's durable and very easy to use. Even if you have it upside down it still works! IVe used other cheaper versions but none compare. I highly recommend!

I wanted to wait a few weeks after using this product to give it a proper review. I have a medium sized dog which has A LOT of energy and he ALWAYS wants to pull and dart off after lizards, squirrels, etc. We have begun walking a few miles a day and I realized that anything over 10min was getting annoying with all the pulling as it takes him at least an hour to calm down enough to stop pulling. I tried this harness and was surprised to see "immediate results". I will start off by saying that it does not fit my dog exactly like it is supposed to meaning around the torso it's a perfect fit but around the chest it's supposed to be able to let you put about 1-2 fingers underneath but after adjusting the straps, my dog has too much space (the small was too small so it had to be a medium). Regardless of this, I've seen a big improvement and the first time he lunged at something, he was somewhat "confused" and I barely felt the tug. I can now let the leash loose and have him smell and do his business without fear of pulling as well as walk for 45+ minutes without being annoyed at the constant yanking. He is enjoying our walks and so am I which in turn makes me want to go out more often. I wish I would've tried this years ago! Also, I did notice at first there was a small rash on the underside of my dogs front leg (just on one side) but I put a little neosporin on it, let it heal and it hasn't happened again. I read some reviews where some dogs get irritated, this is not the case for us but I continue to monitor just incase. Note, we are walking about 10 miles per week. Hope this helps!

I have adjusted this harness to fit my Boston terrier but it still fits so awkwardly. It sits so low on the chest that the ring where all the straps are joined is right on her armpit and she limps and looks so uncomfortable. I have the belly band as long as it can go but it isnt enough. I can't go a size larger because then the other straps are too big. Not a good fit for a Boston-shaped dog.Plus, the martingale on the front doesnt even work like it's supposed to. Instead of tightening when she pulls, the whole harness just twists to the side. I wanted to like this harness, I really did, but it needs to be completely redesigned.
summary: Poor sizing design makes dog limp

reviewText: I had high hopes that this would work. I have a dachshund that is about 14 pounds. She has developed a bad habit that I have been trying to correct by pulling hard when we get close to another dog. She seems to want to go meet the new dog before I get there. I know I'm bad in that I use a retractable leash, however we walk on a sidewalk and she refuses to use the bathroom close to the side walk.Anyway.... The small harness did not fit. It was too small and I for the next size larger at a local WallMart and it was too big. I couldn't get it adjusted small enough with the one from WallMart and the small was cutting into her front legs and too tight around her girth.
summary: Just not what I thought it was going to be

reviewText: I really love this collar and it works great on my older dog but sadly it only lasted less than a half hour on a puppy before she somehow chewed it up I will buy another when she gets older and out of the chewing stage.
summary: Not a good idea for a young puppy

reviewText: Previous to this, I had just been walking my puppy on a regular collar. I had tried several harnesses, but they either didn't fit right, were impossible to figure out how to get on, or my obedience teacher told me not to get them, as it would just make my dog pull more.This harness is color coded so that it is easy to put on. You slide the black part over your dog's head, and then buckle the other color behind the front legs.Once I got this, it took my dog 2 walks to get used to it. That's it! 2! I keep it on him pretty loose behind the legs and he doesn't mind the harness at all. (I only put it on him for walks and take it off when we come back inside)As far as sizing, I would suggest going to a store and trying it on and then buying it on Amazon. For my dog, he is a shih-tzu/toy poodle mix, weighing 5 pounds. I got the petite(the smallest one) and there is lots of room for him.I highly recommend this product!
summary: Made my dog the best heeler!

reviewText: I began using this harness with my Spanador (Cocker Spaniel and Lab mix) when she was a puppy (now 1 year old). I used this because I did not know how to train her properly and heel during walks in the neighborhood and my dog walker was also having trouble. I like the harness because it does keep her at my side and automatically turns her when I need to correct her. Now that I have started training classes, I have not used it and have been using the choke collar. It depends on your dog. Honestly, I believe that the harness works just as well, if not better than the choke collar with my breed. It really depends on your breed. If you plan on training your dog, than ask your trainer and research your breed. My dog still pulls and will choke herself at the sight of a squirrel or another puppy with 100-degree weather. Know your breed. Enough advice, the product does what it says.
works well but still requires some effort on your part to redirect the dog on how you want him to walk until behavior is changed. no instant results

This is my favorite type of harness for walking dogs and I recommend it to everyone. I have a couple of entries on my Blog at Alangus Aussies about different kinds of. collars and leashes for walking. I have purchased them for myself, for family with dogs and also for friends in multiple sizes. They come in small, medium and large but also in tween sizes.

Must admit, it took more than a few minutes to figure out how to put this together and fit it to my dog...so have patience or maybe you are better equipped reading instuctions than I am.BUT, this harness is the best I've ever used.  Since Willow EATS harnesses...I use this only to walk her.  Since she is walked 5 times a day, I dreaded having to put it on a springy hopping Lab puppy!  Thank goodness this harness is so easy to put on!  I keep the leash attached to the D-ring so I am quickly oriented to the front of the harness, then just place over her head and buckle.Also, from the first time she wore it -- no jerking!  As a person who trains their dogs to behave and have fun - I've always used a harness with the D-ring in front of the chest.  This is where you get maximum control.  Since this harness tightens as it is pulled and reminds the dog not to pull, it is only that much better.I intend to only use this type of harness from now on.

I was hesitant on purchasing a harness, but wish I would have bought this sooner.  I have a 7 month old lab puppy and this has worked wonders.  I was under the impression that all harnesses promoted pulling, but this one is designed differently.  I have had some of the most enjoyable walks.  We first purchased a large, but she ended up needing the medium.  We love it!

I have a 1 year old dog who is overly excited on a leash, even in a normal harness. With this harness he just doesn't want to pull! It's so much nicer to take him on walks and not have to constantly hold him back from squirrels and other pedestrians. Great product.
I was planning to return this, because it was too big for my dog.  Fortunately I found a dog owner who could use it.
I bought a second one of these since our new home's yard is not fenced in. Doesn't hurt our puppy & it doesn't slip sizes like some collars do.

This really works on dogs that pull.  After a couple of walks, I was able to walk my dog much more manageably.  If you have a truly strong dog that will yank you along, be cautious.  This product doesnt prevent your falling flat on your face!

This the perfect item for a 12 yr old rednose and his not so young owner. His neck is so big that collars just slip off his head and most harnesses just don't work on his broad chest (he's a little overweight). He's happy, I'm happy so what more could anyone want. Gotta go for a walk now :)
summary: Perfect for an elderly pit and owner!

reviewText: I really like this harness.  I've tried the Gentle Leader and liked it a lot to keep my blue heeler from pulling on walks.  The problem was that it is not very strong and my dog was able to wear through it and eventually bite and break it.  This harness uses a similar concept of pulling/correcting from the front and redirect them when they try to pull.  It is strong and the dog is unable to get it in her mouth to try to chew through it.  So far I do not see any signs of wear and it helps her walk better on a leash.  I definitely recommend it.

My large male shepherd (100+ lbs) is fine walking on a leash...until something else captures his interest.  Another dog, small children, or odd smells turn him into a nightmare on a leash, though. He's an incredibly strong dog when he starts pulling.A little over a year ago when he hit his first birthday, I enrolled him in some search-and-rescue training classes.  He loved it; but his enthusiasm for following the scent made the typical collar/leash ensemble a misery for both of us.  I was dragged along behind and he was gagging because of the collar pulling against his throat.  The instructor recommended this specific harness for my pooch.  He felt that conventional harnesses wouldn't work for two reasons.  One, they're bad for the skeletal structure of the dog since they force a splaying of the front legs; and, two, they actually provide the dog with additional leverage for their pulling.  He assured me that the Easy Walk harness would work much better.I ordered the Easy Walk harness for my guy and the results were amazing.  Unlike with a regular leash where my dog would tend to pull harder once he had the pressure of his collar pulling on his neck...with the Easy Walk, the pressure or pulling is centered on the front of his chest.  And, for whatever reason, it worked...he doesn't like to pull when he's wearing it.  It's easy to put on my dog and I can still leave his regular neck collar in place since he has his tags and ID on it.  It doesn't get in the way of the Easy Walk harness.The only downside that I've found with it is when I'm walking both of my dogs on retractable leashes.  On a short leash in side-by-side walking, the harness works fine.  However, when the dogs are at the full 16' extension of their retractable leashes, it becomes awkward with the leash connecting to the center of the chest.  I'm constantly having to readjust their leashes so that the leash doesn't wrap their bodies.
summary: Recommended by my dog's trainer...it really does make a difference when walking a dog that pulls

reviewText: I chose this harness in a size medium and it fit my 45lb Austrailian Shepherd perfectly with room to spare. This worked like magic the very first time I used it and my dog instantly stopped pulling. I thought that it might be a hastle to take it on and off (I didn't want her to chew it off if I left it on), but it's actually pretty easy. I just leave the leash attatched to the front and unclip the black portion of the harness so it slides right off..plus it's just as easy to put back on. Worth every penny.

My dog trainer suggested this as a way to prevent leash-pulling.  It's the best!  I've tried a choke coller and a martingale collar and this is the best.  The hook at the front (chest area) of the harness causes the dog to pull to one side if they tug on the leash, so they quickly stop straining.  No discomfort.  I suggest this to everyone I know that has a dog that pulls on the leash.

I have an 80lb Golden Retriever that is usually off leash for long runs or in my yard with an electric fence so he is rarely on a leash. When I do use a standard leash, he is constantly pulling the walker which is quite annoying and out of control. This harness works as described and stopped the pulling instantly. Although it is a bit confusing to put on, once it is there it works perfectly and I can walk without constantly looking like an idiot with an uncontrollable dog. A real life saver.

My Border Collie mix is large and a puller. My new trainer recommended this harness. She demonstrated it first, and I was amazed at the instant reaction he had to it. I could see he was trying to figure out  what was going on, why he kept being turned about (he couldn't go straight if he pulled!), and within seconds he just stopped pulling. Of course, Border Collies are smart, and pick up things quickly. It may take other dogs a little more time, but I highly recommend it for pullers, My arms are certainly relieved. I actually use a Wacky Walker leash attached to the harness, then attach a European lead to that, which allows me to wrap to European lead cross body, keeping my walks mostly hands free. If he gets distracted, I lightly pull the Wacky Walker, and we are back on course. Make sure the bottom part is good and tight, fit a finger through but that is about it. I am going to but for my little terrier and see if it works for him as well.
It's a solid feeling harness that's easy to get on and off. No complaints! Sizing it for my mom's dog was a bit of a pain, only because he moved around a lot.
summary: Easy to put on and remove

reviewText: I was excited to try this product but it didnt fit my dog properly despite being adjustable. I'm returning it and debating whether or not to try a smaller size because it fit my dog around the waist but the chest strap in the from was loose

We've had our adopted dog for 6 years. She came from the shelter where she was scheduled to be euthanized because her original owners did not want her back. She had been abused and taught to kill critters and run wild in the neighborhood, terrorizing dogs and cats. We have been successful in teaching her to the contrary and she is a very loving yet protective dog. Knowing we were the ones who needed training, we've watched numerous videos, read books, etc. Because we live in a wilderness setting, we never had much need to teach her how to walk on a leash. When we tried, though, we found out we needed a solution very quickly!Reading all the positive reviews here convinced us to try this harness. From the moment we put it on her, she responded like magic. No pulling or yanking our arms out. We are truly amazed at how well this very inexpensive (but well made) product works. The directions on the package are easy to follow. Because she chews on toys, we are well warned about not leaving the harness on her unattended. During the first couple of times we put it on her, we gave her a treat. She now gets excited whenever she sees us grab the harness/leash (we bought the combination), knowing she is going for a walk with us - no treats necessary now.

shipping was fast and efficient.  I love the front leader, it is a great help when training your dog to learn out to walk with you, and it is wonderful especially for those pups that like to lunge and pull, it gives much better control to me when handling those moments.  Even my beagle who has a really bad habit of pulling with all his might is learning to slow down some.  I even use it on my boston/pug mix since she is a strong puller too.  Our walks are starting to get much easier with less pulling.

This was recommended by my dog trainer as a way to help my anxious 45-pound dog (a rescued stray who in uncomfortable around traffic and general city activity) be calmer on leashed walks.  While it works well for general training and for deterring pulling on a non-eventful walk, I found that if my dog gets anxious or excited and pulls, the harness tightens up into his armpits and loses it's effectiveness.  Unless I stop and adjust it, my dog just gets used to the discomfort of the tension on his tender parts and continues to pull.  That annoyance and the fact that he hates to have the harness put on him -- and the pink skin I see in his armpits after a walk-- has led me to conclude that this is not for him.  I switched to the Sporn halter (an upwards correction, and fleece-covered arm straps) with good results.Another huge annoyance of the comfort harness is the attachment clips.  They do not release easily, especially with my mildly arthritic hands.  The darned thing is not easy to put on, either.My general impression of this halter is that it's most appropriate for a headstrong dog who does know how to do a loose heel but won't comply unless constantly reminded.  I'd suggest that users do the kind thing and line the straps that go behind your dog's legs with fleece.  Imagine how those straps would feel in your armpits.

This was one of the more awkward things that I've tried on her...and it didn't stop her from pulling. I think the only thing that will do that is a lot of practice on better behavior on a daily basis.

I love these harnesses, both my dogs ware them and I recomend them to everyone.  My dogs walk great one on one but have to compete with each other when they go for a walk together so this keeps them from pulling really hard and gives me more control when the squirles tease them.

First, some background on my dog. He is a rescue dog whom I got in May 2013. After a month of having him his true nature started coming out. I found out he can be a puller and did not like other dogs. He would lunge at dogs and bicycles. I was using a regular collar on him but he would pull and would go after other dogs on walks. He also developed a habit of barking when I got to a house that he knew had a dog. So, even if other dogs were not barking at him if he remembered the house he would start barking which made it hard to walk him in the morning. My dog is 30 lbs, I am over 200 so it is not like he was stronger than me. But I knew this was a bad habit of his.I got the Easy Walk in hopes it would keep him from pulling. With the Easy Harness he did get better in not pulling as much but would still pull at times. But, it did nothing to curb his lunging at dogs and bikes. It was getting frustrating walking him as he would bark at no apparent reason. If you know how to use it, this collar can be helpful in training your dog to not pull as much. But, don't expect miracles, you still need to do your part to train your dog.Fast forward 3 months to the head halter. I heard about gentle leader but was apprehensive in getting it. In putting on the gentle leader my dog did fuss and not want it on him. He would try to take it off by pawing at it and rubbing his face on bushes. It has been 5 days and still does it but he is getting used to it. Reward him with treats after so he associates as positive. So does it work? YES! But, be sure you know how to use it. Watch the DVD! it is important you don't send your dog mixed signals by keeping it tense. On our first walk the dog did pull and lunge but he did not like the feeling, especially when lunging. But on our first walk I could tell he was staying by my side much better. I did not expect it to prevent lunging but it has. I think it makes him think twice. I have taken him past houses where dogs will bark it him, in the past he would try to go to the barking but now he just whimpers and keeps walking. This produce truly is working wonders (the gentle leader).So in short, I would recommend both the Easy Walk and Gentle Leader. If you have a problem it does not hurt to try both and see which one works better for your dog. But keep in mind you have to do your part to still train your dog. These products are meant as tools. For my purpose, Gentle Leader has done wonders.
Dogs chewed right through this one.  Also with the other ones I had it rubbed the dog raw.  Wish it had more padding.

I read the measurements, and I read the reviews - this item does not fit my dog. Either size does not fit either dog.  Both are supposedly "tweener" size - and both are too big.  Drawback to that is that I can't begin to imagine how a smaller one would work,  so I am returning both - end of story.  Seems to be well made, lovely workmanship - but buckles in the dog's armpit? The chest strap is the closet thing to a fit on either of the ones that I ordered, both still too big though towards the front where the pull ring is at.I must have the weirdest dogs on earth, this makes half a dozen that simply don't fit.  arghhhh

My very rambuncous 1.5 year old russel terrier is as curious as a dog can be. As a result going on walks with her requires 110% of my attention as she runs ahead, stops, turns around runs the other way, stops to run under a bush, and down every single driveway..... Walks were way more work than needed to be.I had her on a regular harness and I would give her a little tug back when she would start running. She'd stop....then start running again.I have used this same easy walk harness on a previous dog that I babysat for a week and it worked okay. Maybe after more time we would have seen more results. I also paid $30 for it at Pet Food Express....Quick note on measuring/sizing, my dog was 16 inches around her chest. Which is right between the xs and small. I went with the small and it works much better. I suggest going with the bigger size if you run into the same problem. They are adjustable, so you can make it smaller, but you can't make a too small size bigger.I ordered this one about a week ago and paid $14 on Amazon for the small black version. It takes a bit to get it adjusted which can be frustrating with a squirmy dog like mine, but once we got it on correctly it was pretty easy. Also, the fact that I left the instructions on the ground and my dog decided to rip them up didn't help either....I found the instructions confusing, basically to get it on there are 3 parts. 2 black and 1 other color (mine was silver). The 2 black: 1 has the easy walk logo on it, that goes behind the dog's head around the shoulders, the other has the metal loop you attach the leash to, that goes in front of the dog's chest/legs. The silver goes behind the dog's legs under the chest. I always unclip the silver then put it on with the black loops still clipped.The instructions are helpful for troubleshooting the fitting, the basic concept is fitted snuggly around the shoulders & chest, and loosely in front of the legs.After I got it on her and adjusted it. I took her for a walk to see how it would go. It was instant results! She ran ahead a little bit, but when I gave her a little pull back and causes her to stop. The placement of the ring you attach the leash to is the secret to the magic. Because the leash attaches in front of her chest, the rest of the leash hangs on either side of her body instead of straight down her back like a normal harness. If she pulls, the leash will pull her to her left or right, which turns her around to face you. The side to side pull screws up her balance which she doesn't like at all.To be fair she is fairly uncoordinated, she's in the awkward gangly teenage stage. The other dog I tried this with was 3 years old and very agile. It didn't work nearly as well. I highly suggest trying it if you have a curious puppy like dog like mine, it's also the perfect time in their developement to teach them what loose leash walking is all about.
summary: Instant Results for one dog, okay results for another

reviewText: First a tip:  if your dog is a chewer, don't leave this on (shouldn't anyhow).  I made the mistake of grabbing a phone call after a walk and didn't take it off right away.  After a 10 minute call, she had chewed it off.  Make sure you have it on right.At any rate, I bought another and I'm happy that I did.  It's not a miracle worker, but it sure does help the pulling.
summary: Helps my pulling puppy on walks

reviewText: My dog is so tiny, I'm having trouble fitting it to her. It's a nice quality, and not too difficult to put on her. But, she needs to grow a little more.

I measured my dog twice and this is too big for him.  He almost hurt himself because his paw slipped through one of the straps and it tripped him.  He's ok, but I'm disappointed.  It seemed to be working OK, but it's useless because he can pull his leg out easily!Edited on 4/10/14:  I upgraded the review to 4 stars.  Beware that the sizing chart is not very accurate.  Amazon sent me a M/L and I sent the L back.  The M/L fits my dog.  The L was within the size range of my dog, but as stated earlier, it was way too big...dangerously so.The harness works better than anything else I've tried.  Of course, my dog figured out that he could tangle it around his neck a bit to make it less effective.  We're working on it!

Dog slipped out of it twice; unable to tighten it enough to hold him.  Seems too loose at his chest.  Taking it to a training class so that the trainer can determine if I have the wrong size or if I just didn't put it on him correctly.

I have been through countless harnesses trying to train my 24 lb poodle to heel when walking. He is a puller. This harness finally did the trick. He still zig zags in front of me but he cannot "pull" with this harness. I saw a similar leather (lot more expensive) harness being raved about on Facebook for stopping pit bulls from pulling on a leash and started looking for he same design in a nylon webbing type material that would work for a smaller dog when I found this. The size is perfect because my dog is a little too big for the small size and we had to adjust the medium to it's smallest making it kind of bulky when we tried them at the pet store. Although 24lbs, my dog does not have a huge neck or chest but is bigger then an average miniature poodle.

I have a large female chocolate lab who likes to drag me around the neighborhood.  I've tried several different devices to correct this.  Some worked a tad, most not at all.  None were designed to inflict pain or discomfort, something I avoid like the plague.In my seemingly endless quest for the perfect harness, I decided to give this one a try.  First time out, it worked like a charm and she behaved like a true darling....no pulling....hoorah. :)The large size was plenty big enough for my 100# little girl.  Easy to adjust and easy to put on.  Works for me, hope it does the same for you.Happy shopping :)
summary: First Harness to Actually Control My Lab's Pulling

reviewText: I intentionally purchased one a little too big.  I did this because the extra small has buckles which are difficult for me to unclip...they are way tinier!  I looked at them at Petsmart.Also, the sizes on amazon confuse me... Petite small...what the heck?I think the loop on the front is too big for a small dog, giving too much leeway (even when harness is sized correctly).  It doesn't prevent my dog from pulling, but it does require a little less effort on my part to curb her.I really love the multiple buckle system.  I put it over her head and clip it under her belly to clip it on, and to take it off I simply unclip the back and let it fall.  This is wonderful because before a walk she gets too excited to hold still for a step-in harness.It's durable; it endures saltwater and sand every day.The only other thing I wish this harness had was a clip on the back so that she could pull easier if I allow her to, like on an extendi-leash.This is the only product out there like this, and it's wonderful.
I used this harness on my foster dogs which are usually pit mixes and it kept me in control all the time.

I got the petite/small, the one with the Jack Russel on the cover, and nope — it's incredibly small.Went to the store and tried other sizes — all either way too small or way too big. I have a pom mix, he's small and skinny enough.Had to go out and buy a different brand, and this couldn't be returned because we already opened it and tried applying it. Too bad, really. I was stoked to have it.

I have not had any problems with rubbing or chaffing. However here's an easy way to remedy that problem. Use fleece horse halter cover on the belly strap. It is thick and soft and will pad the strap and stop the rubbing just like it does on horse halters. And it is also washable. You can buy them in different colors right here on Amazon under Horse halter fleece, fleece halter tubes, basic fleece halter crown cover.Basic Fleece Halter Crown Coverthis is a link for the different colors. You can also cut these with scissors to the correct length. Hope this helps with any issues people are having. I use one to prevent it from happening in the first place. This also should not interfere with the way the harness works.
summary: Tip if your harness is rubbing

reviewText: I purchased two of these. This harness has failed on me on two separate occasions with two separate dogs. The first instance was with my golden retriever as a puppy. He simply put his head down and in seconds was able to snap the front strap. The second occasion was with my smaller corgi mix, while on a walk he lunged and the buckle snapped. I always double check the snap buckles as a precaution so I believe its a fault product.
summary: Worst purchase Ive made for my dogs

reviewText: We have two Boston Terriers. A two year old and a five month old puppy. The two year old has been using the Easy Walk for a long time -- I like it for many reasons one being because they are bracciophallic I don't feel like it is effecting her breathing at all -- and we hadn't ordered one for the puppy yet. Today he was pulling as usual on our daily walks and it started to drive me insane so I decided to switch their collars as an experiment. IMMEDIATELY after putting the Easy Walk on him our walk became a million times easier! No pulling and no running ahead. He walked like a super good boy who had been doing it all his life. I am ordering a 2nd Easy Walk today. THEY ARE AWESOME. You won't be sorry!
Worked right away like a miracle ****BUT*** Biscuit backed out of it and ran home.  It was my fault because I stopped and crouched next to him and should have just kept walking.
summary: Great, but don't give them an opportunity to back out.

reviewText: Great price and stopped my dog from pulling! LOVE it! Highly recommend!Make sure that the harness is very snug on the dog so the dog doesn't slip out of the harness.

I gave this product 3 Stars because eventhough this product doesnt work for one of my dogs it works really well for my puppy (I use a small for him)I got this to help with what it is for PULLING, but my dog seems to want to pull more.I have had this product for about 3 weeks now it seems to be working now... well sort of, the straps do not stay in place once adjusted and every time my dog pulls (even a little) the ajustment falls/slides out of place and I have to adjust it yet again. I am starting to think that this is the reason for my dogs pulling.I got the Small/Medium for my dog because the Small is too small and I cant use the belly strap with out squeezing her to death and the Medium is too large for her frame. Her grith size is 19 in which is the cut off size for the small and the begining size for the small/Medium but the s/m seems to still be a bit too large.What I like.... the color and the fact that it works well for my other dog.
summary: Could be better, Works for some not for all

reviewText: My dog can move light lightening. If she just wore a collar, my holding her back might hurt her neck. This harness does a good job at protecting my lovely dog.
summary: Does a wonderful job at protecting my dog.

reviewText: We've tried the gentle leader and other harnesses and this thing wins hands down. A normal harness just encourages them to turn into sled dogs. The position of the attachment on the chest is just the opposite. Our 90lb field lab who is very strong, is fully tamed by this harness. We're buying another for our "wonder" dog that pulls way too much. Thank you for such a simple idea that really works. They hold up well too. UPDATED: Make sure to get the sizing correct because Amazon does not accept exchanges on this item. Changing my rating due to this because returns are such a hassle, why make your customers lie about why they are returning it?

I have tried many collars and harnesses to restrain my 93 lbs. Doberman when he sees a squirrel. The Gentle leader did work, but my dog absolutely hated it. So I didn't use it. I had tried a harness that hooks in the front, but it was tight, which made him just pull harder and the chest is where he has the most strength.This harness works perfect because it is lose in the front. Now, when he takes off, as soon as he reaches the end of the retractable leash, or I pull back, it spins him around, taking his eyes off the squirrel and back on me!!  Yea!With the two different colors it is easy to put on. It doesn't hinder my dog at all. But it sure does control him.

My real-world observations indicate the efficacy of this harness is highly dependent upon the breed of canine to which it is attached.In plain English: how good or bad this is depends on what kind of dog you've got. This didn't work too well on our dog, a 40-pound Whippet/Shepherd mix. I think it had everything to with her body type. Her greyhound-like chest ensured that the harness wouldn't stay put, and since she's kind-of low to the ground, she would constantly trip over the leash. Five minutes into a walk, the thing was completely out of sorts and needed to be readjusted. Since the harness moved around too much, it was actually wearing down the fur at the top of her front legs. We switched to thePremier Gentle Leader Head Dog Collarand have been much happier with the results.However, I can definitely see the potential benefits of this harness with the "right" dog. It came highly recommended by the trainer at PetSmart, and everyone in our basic training class was using it, many of them with great success. The general principle is sound -- when your dog pulls, the harness squeezes their front legs together, forcing them to stop. If you want to give it a shot, I'd recommend buying it at a retail store to make it easier to return in the event that you don't like it. It's worth trying for a few days to see if it works for you.
summary: Didn't Work for Us, but Might for You!

reviewText: This is a great product, but honestly nothing beats training to stop a dog from pulling on leash.I bought a similar no-pull harness and got this one afterward.  The extra tension on the chest strap gives more control than the Sensation Harness I first purchased.FIT is most important with this harness.  The store where I first purchased it did not carry the intermediate size harnesses.  According to the package sizing, the Large size met my dog's proportions, so I got it.  But it was much too large.  I had to shorten each section to the max and the chest strap was still much too large.Premier should add that chest dimension to the chart.  My dog is a Weimaraner.  His girth would fit into the Large category,  but his chest from side to sde is slim.  I returned the harness to the store and ordered the Med/Large size online, which is perfect!

I love this harness.  I originally tried this with my very rambunctious 64 pound boxer lab.  I had previously needed a prong collar to control him.  It was wonderful and much kinder and he didn't knock me down.  It is now also working wonderfully for my very active 6-month old Miniature American Eskimo.  Nothing works for every pet but this is a no brainer for anyone who is having a difficult time controlling a pulling dog.  I am a veterinarian and I recommend this harness to all of my clients.
summary: Just try it!  Great harness.  Won't work for every dog but will work for most.

reviewText: I take my 9 month old pitbull on frequent walks in public places and I have had no luck with stopping her from pulling during the majority of the walk. FYI: I typically use a "regular" harness.Today I tried this harness for the first time and I must say that I'm impressed. The only problem we had was that when we first started the walk she was very excited and pulled so much that she fell over and fell/slipped right out of the harness!:?  After I restrained her and put the harness back on it was easy sailing. I was not sweating and exhausted by the end of our 2 mile walk because this harness virtually stopped her from pulling me. I will continue to use this harness for every walk and I know that it will only get better as my dog gets accustomed to the harness and knows that she won't be able to pull so easily when it's on.p.s. I was worried about the harness being too big (I ordered a large) because it seemed loose in the front, so I went to Petsmart and one of the employees said it fit perfectly. I still wish I would have ordered the Tween size - think it would have fit a little better.

I returned this item. Sizing on Girth is off by two inches. Despite measuring carefully. My dog was within the two inch. However the chest part could not be adjusted to make the T formation shown in instructions. Just not enough belting. This was a constant fight to keep in position.
